      60             : // exclude unsupported compilers

      70             :     "unsupported GCC version - see https://github.com/nlohmann/json#supported-compilers"

      73             : 
      74             : // disable float-equal warnings on GCC/clang
      75             : #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
      76             : #pragma GCC diagnostic push
      77             : #pragma GCC diagnostic ignored "-Wfloat-equal"
      78             : #endif
      79             : 
      80             : // disable documentation warnings on clang
      81             : #if defined(__clang__)
      82             : #pragma GCC diagnostic push
      83             : #pragma GCC diagnostic ignored "-Wdocumentation"
      84             : #endif
      85             : 
      86             : // allow for portable deprecation warnings
      87             : #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
      88             : #define JSON_DEPRECATED __attribute__((deprecated))
      89             : #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
      90             : #define JSON_DEPRECATED __declspec(deprecated)
      91             : #else
      92             : #define JSON_DEPRECATED
      93             : #endif
      94             : 
      95             : // allow to disable exceptions
      96             : #if not defined(JSON_NOEXCEPTION) || defined(__EXCEPTIONS)
      97             : #define JSON_THROW(exception) throw exception
      98             : #define JSON_TRY try
      99             : #define JSON_CATCH(exception) catch (exception)
     100             : #else
     101             : #define JSON_THROW(exception) std::abort()
     102             : #define JSON_TRY if (true)
     103             : #define JSON_CATCH(exception) if (false)
     104             : #endif
     105             : 
     106             : /*!
     107             : @brief namespace for Niels Lohmann
     108             : @see https://github.com/nlohmann
     109             : @since version 1.0.0
     110             : */
     111             : namespace nlohmann
     112             : {
     113             : /*!
     114             : @brief unnamed namespace with internal helper functions
     115             : 
     116             : This namespace collects some functions that could not be defined inside the
     117             : @ref basic_json class.
     118             : 
     119             : @since version 2.1.0
     120             : */
     121             : namespace detail
     122             : {
     123             : ///////////////////////////
     124             : // JSON type enumeration //
     125             : ///////////////////////////
     126             : 
     127             : /*!
     128             : @brief the JSON type enumeration
     129             : 
     130             : This enumeration collects the different JSON types. It is internally used to
     131             : distinguish the stored values, and the functions @ref basic_json::is_null(),
     132             : @ref basic_json::is_object(), @ref basic_json::is_array(),
     133             : @ref basic_json::is_string(), @ref basic_json::is_boolean(),
     134             : @ref basic_json::is_number() (with @ref basic_json::is_number_integer(),
     135             : @ref basic_json::is_number_unsigned(), and @ref basic_json::is_number_float()),
     136             : @ref basic_json::is_discarded(), @ref basic_json::is_primitive(), and
     137             : @ref basic_json::is_structured() rely on it.
     138             : 
     139             : @note There are three enumeration entries (number_integer, number_unsigned, and
     140             : number_float), because the library distinguishes these three types for numbers:
     141             : @ref basic_json::number_unsigned_t is used for unsigned integers,
     142             : @ref basic_json::number_integer_t is used for signed integers, and
     143             : @ref basic_json::number_float_t is used for floating-point numbers or to
     144             : approximate integers which do not fit in the limits of their respective type.
     145             : 
     146             : @sa @ref basic_json::basic_json(const value_t value_type) -- create a JSON
     147             : value with the default value for a given type
     148             : 
     149             : @since version 1.0.0
     150             : */
     151             : enum class value_t : uint8_t
     152             : {
     153             :     null,            ///< null value
     154             :     object,          ///< object (unordered set of name/value pairs)
     155             :     array,           ///< array (ordered collection of values)
     156             :     string,          ///< string value
     157             :     boolean,         ///< boolean value
     158             :     number_integer,  ///< number value (signed integer)
     159             :     number_unsigned, ///< number value (unsigned integer)
     160             :     number_float,    ///< number value (floating-point)
     161             :     discarded        ///< discarded by the the parser callback function
     162             : };
     163             : 
     164             : /*!
     165             : @brief comparison operator for JSON types
     166             : 
     167             : Returns an ordering that is similar to Python:
     168             : - order: null < boolean < number < object < array < string
     169             : - furthermore, each type is not smaller than itself
     170             : 
     171             : @since version 1.0.0
     172             : */
     173             : inline bool operator<(const value_t lhs, const value_t rhs) noexcept
     174             : {
     175             :     static constexpr std::array<uint8_t, 8> order = {{
     176             :         0, // null
     177             :         3, // object
     178             :         4, // array
     179             :         5, // string
     180             :         1, // boolean
     181             :         2, // integer
     182             :         2, // unsigned
     183             :         2, // float
     184             :     }};
     185             : 
     186             :     // discarded values are not comparable
     187             :     if (lhs == value_t::discarded or rhs == value_t::discarded)
     188             :     {
     189             :         return false;
     190             :     }
     191             : 
     192             :     return order[static_cast<std::size_t>(lhs)] <
     193             :            order[static_cast<std::size_t>(rhs)];
     194             : }
     195             : 
     196             : /////////////
     197             : // helpers //
     198             : /////////////
     199             : 
     200             : // alias templates to reduce boilerplate
     201             : template <bool B, typename T = void>
     202             : using enable_if_t = typename std::enable_if<B, T>::type;
     203             : 
     204             : template <typename T>
     205             : using uncvref_t =
     206             :     typename std::remove_cv<typename std::remove_reference<T>::type>::type;
     207             : 
     208             : // taken from http://stackoverflow.com/a/26936864/266378
     209             : template <typename T>
     210             : using is_unscoped_enum =
     211             :     std::integral_constant<bool, std::is_convertible<T, int>::value and
     212             :                                      std::is_enum<T>::value>;
     213             : 
     214             : /*
     215             : Implementation of two C++17 constructs: conjunction, negation. This is needed
     216             : to avoid evaluating all the traits in a condition
     217             : 
     218             : For example: not std::is_same<void, T>::value and has_value_type<T>::value
     219             : will not compile when T = void (on MSVC at least). Whereas
     220             : conjunction<negation<std::is_same<void, T>>, has_value_type<T>>::value will
     221             : stop evaluating if negation<...>::value == false
     222             : 
     223             : Please note that those constructs must be used with caution, since symbols can
     224             : become very long quickly (which can slow down compilation and cause MSVC
     225             : internal compiler errors). Only use it when you have to (see example ahead).
     226             : */
     227             : template <class...>
     228             : struct conjunction : std::true_type
     229             : {
     230             : };
     231             : template <class B1>
     232             : struct conjunction<B1> : B1
     233             : {
     234             : };
     235             : template <class B1, class... Bn>
     236             : struct conjunction<B1, Bn...>
     237             :     : std::conditional<bool(B1::value), conjunction<Bn...>, B1>::type
     238             : {
     239             : };
     240             : 
     241             : template <class B>
     242             : struct negation : std::integral_constant<bool, !B::value>
     243             : {
     244             : };
     245             : 
     246             : // dispatch utility (taken from ranges-v3)
     247             : template <unsigned N>
     248             : struct priority_tag : priority_tag<N - 1>
     249             : {
     250             : };
     251             : template <>
     252             : struct priority_tag<0>
     253             : {
     254             : };
     255             : 
     256             : //////////////////
     257             : // constructors //
     258             : //////////////////
     259             : 
     260             : template <value_t>
     261             : struct external_constructor;
     262             : 
     263             : template <>
     264             : struct external_constructor<value_t::boolean>
     265             : {
     266             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     267             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j,
     268             :                           typename BasicJsonType::boolean_t b) noexcept
     269             :     {
     270             :         j.m_type = value_t::boolean;
     271             :         j.m_value = b;
     272             :         j.assert_invariant();
     273             :     }
     274             : };
     275             : 
     276             : template <>
     277             : struct external_constructor<value_t::string>
     278             : {
     279             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     280           0 :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j,
     281             :                           const typename BasicJsonType::string_t& s)
     282             :     {
     283           0 :         j.m_type = value_t::string;
     284           0 :         j.m_value = s;
     285           0 :         j.assert_invariant();
     286           0 :     }
     287             : };
     288             : 
     289             : template <>
     290             : struct external_constructor<value_t::number_float>
     291             : {
     292             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     293             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j,
     294             :                           typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t val) noexcept
     295             :     {
     296             :         // replace infinity and NAN by null
     297             :         if (not std::isfinite(val))
     298             :         {
     299             :             j = BasicJsonType{};
     300             :         }
     301             :         else
     302             :         {
     303             :             j.m_type = value_t::number_float;
     304             :             j.m_value = val;
     305             :         }
     306             :         j.assert_invariant();
     307             :     }
     308             : };
     309             : 
     310             : template <>
     311             : struct external_constructor<value_t::number_unsigned>
     312             : {
     313             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     314             :     static void construct(
     315             :         BasicJsonType& j,
     316             :         typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t val) noexcept
     317             :     {
     318             :         j.m_type = value_t::number_unsigned;
     319             :         j.m_value = val;
     320             :         j.assert_invariant();
     321             :     }
     322             : };
     323             : 
     324             : template <>
     325             : struct external_constructor<value_t::number_integer>
     326             : {
     327             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     328             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j,
     329             :                           typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t val) noexcept
     330             :     {
     331             :         j.m_type = value_t::number_integer;
     332             :         j.m_value = val;
     333             :         j.assert_invariant();
     334             :     }
     335             : };
     336             : 
     337             : template <>
     338             : struct external_constructor<value_t::array>
     339             : {
     340             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     341             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j,
     342             :                           const typename BasicJsonType::array_t& arr)
     343             :     {
     344             :         j.m_type = value_t::array;
     345             :         j.m_value = arr;
     346             :         j.assert_invariant();
     347             :     }
     348             : 
     349             :     template <
     350             :         typename BasicJsonType, typename CompatibleArrayType,
     351             :         enable_if_t<not std::is_same<CompatibleArrayType,
     352             :                                      typename BasicJsonType::array_t>::value,
     353             :                     int> = 0>
     354             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j, const CompatibleArrayType& arr)
     355             :     {
     356             :         using std::begin;
     357             :         using std::end;
     358             :         j.m_type = value_t::array;
     359             :         j.m_value.array =
     360             :             j.template create<typename BasicJsonType::array_t>(begin(arr),
     361             :                                                                end(arr));
     362             :         j.assert_invariant();
     363             :     }
     364             : };
     365             : 
     366             : template <>
     367             : struct external_constructor<value_t::object>
     368             : {
     369             :     template <typename BasicJsonType>
     370             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j,
     371             :                           const typename BasicJsonType::object_t& obj)
     372             :     {
     373             :         j.m_type = value_t::object;
     374             :         j.m_value = obj;
     375             :         j.assert_invariant();
     376             :     }
     377             : 
     378             :     template <
     379             :         typename BasicJsonType, typename CompatibleObjectType,
     380             :         enable_if_t<not std::is_same<CompatibleObjectType,
     381             :                                      typename BasicJsonType::object_t>::value,
     382             :                     int> = 0>
     383             :     static void construct(BasicJsonType& j, const CompatibleObjectType& obj)
     384             :     {
     385             :         using std::begin;
     386             :         using std::end;
     387             : 
     388             :         j.m_type = value_t::object;
     389             :         j.m_value.object =
     390             :             j.template create<typename BasicJsonType::object_t>(begin(obj),
     391             :                                                                 end(obj));
     392             :         j.assert_invariant();
     393             :     }
     394             : };
     395             : 
     396             : ////////////////////////
     397             : // has_/is_ functions //
     398             : ////////////////////////
     399             : 
     400             : /*!
     401             : @brief Helper to determine whether there's a key_type for T.
     402             : 
     403             : This helper is used to tell associative containers apart from other containers
     404             : such as sequence containers. For instance, `std::map` passes the test as it
     405             : contains a `mapped_type`, whereas `std::vector` fails the test.
     406             : 
     407             : @sa http://stackoverflow.com/a/7728728/266378
     408             : @since version 1.0.0, overworked in version 2.0.6
     409             : */
     410             : #define NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(type)                                    \
     411             :     template <typename T>                                                 \
     412             :     struct has_##type                                                     \
     413             :     {                                                                     \
     414             :     private:                                                              \
     415             :         template <typename U, typename = typename U::type>                \
     416             :         static int detect(U&&);                                           \
     417             :         static void detect(...);                                          \
     418             :                                                                           \
     419             :     public:                                                               \
     420             :         static constexpr bool value =                                     \
     421             :             std::is_integral<decltype(detect(std::declval<T>()))>::value; \
     422             :     }
     423             : 
     424             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(mapped_type);
     425             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(key_type);
     426             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(value_type);
     427             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(iterator);
     428             : 
     429             : #undef NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER
     430             : 
     431             : template <bool B, class RealType, class CompatibleObjectType>
     432             : struct is_compatible_object_type_impl : std::false_type
     433             : {
     434             : };
     435             : 
     436             : template <class RealType, class CompatibleObjectType>
     437             : struct is_compatible_object_type_impl<true, RealType, CompatibleObjectType>
     438             : {
     439             :     static constexpr auto value =
     440             :         std::is_constructible<
     441             :             typename RealType::key_type,
     442             :             typename CompatibleObjectType::key_type>::value and
     443             :         std::is_constructible<
     444             :             typename RealType::mapped_type,
     445             :             typename CompatibleObjectType::mapped_type>::value;
     446             : };
     447             : 
     448             : template <class BasicJsonType, class CompatibleObjectType>
     449             : struct is_compatible_object_type
     450             : {
     451             :     static auto constexpr value = is_compatible_object_type_impl<
     452             :         conjunction<negation<std::is_same<void, CompatibleObjectType>>,
     453             :                     has_mapped_type<CompatibleObjectType>,
     454             :                     has_key_type<CompatibleObjectType>>::value,
     455             :         typename BasicJsonType::object_t, CompatibleObjectType>::value;
     456             : };
     457             : 
     458             : template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     459             : struct is_basic_json_nested_type
     460             : {
     461             :     static auto constexpr value =
     462             :         std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::iterator>::value or
     463             :         std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::const_iterator>::value or
     464             :         std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::reverse_iterator>::value or
     465             :         std::is_same<T,
     466             :                      typename BasicJsonType::const_reverse_iterator>::value or
     467             :         std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::json_pointer>::value;
     468             : };
     469             : 
     470             : template <class BasicJsonType, class CompatibleArrayType>
     471             : struct is_compatible_array_type
     472             : {
     473             :     static auto constexpr value = conjunction<
     474             :         negation<std::is_same<void, CompatibleArrayType>>,
     475             :         negation<is_compatible_object_type<BasicJsonType, CompatibleArrayType>>,
     476             :         negation<std::is_constructible<typename BasicJsonType::string_t,
     477             :                                        CompatibleArrayType>>,
     478             :         negation<is_basic_json_nested_type<BasicJsonType, CompatibleArrayType>>,
     479             :         has_value_type<CompatibleArrayType>,
     480             :         has_iterator<CompatibleArrayType>>::value;
     481             : };
     482             : 
     483             : template <bool, typename, typename>
     484             : struct is_compatible_integer_type_impl : std::false_type
     485             : {
     486             : };
     487             : 
     488             : template <typename RealIntegerType, typename CompatibleNumberIntegerType>
     489             : struct is_compatible_integer_type_impl<true, RealIntegerType,
     490             :                                        CompatibleNumberIntegerType>
     491             : {
     492             :     // is there an assert somewhere on overflows?
     493             :     using RealLimits = std::numeric_limits<RealIntegerType>;
     494             :     using CompatibleLimits = std::numeric_limits<CompatibleNumberIntegerType>;
     495             : 
     496             :     static constexpr auto value =
     497             :         std::is_constructible<RealIntegerType,
     498             :                               CompatibleNumberIntegerType>::value and
     499             :         CompatibleLimits::is_integer and
     500             :         RealLimits::is_signed == CompatibleLimits::is_signed;
     501             : };
     502             : 
     503             : template <typename RealIntegerType, typename CompatibleNumberIntegerType>
     504             : struct is_compatible_integer_type
     505             : {
     506             :     static constexpr auto
     507             :         value = is_compatible_integer_type_impl <
     508             :                     std::is_integral<CompatibleNumberIntegerType>::value and
     509             :                 not std::is_same<bool, CompatibleNumberIntegerType>::value,
     510             :         RealIntegerType, CompatibleNumberIntegerType > ::value;
     511             : };
     512             : 
     513             : // trait checking if JSONSerializer<T>::from_json(json const&, udt&) exists
     514             : template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     515             : struct has_from_json
     516             : {
     517             : private:
     518             :     // also check the return type of from_json
     519             :     template <typename U, typename = enable_if_t<std::is_same<
     520             :                               void, decltype(uncvref_t<U>::from_json(
     521             :                                         std::declval<BasicJsonType>(),
     522             :                                         std::declval<T&>()))>::value>>
     523             :     static int detect(U&&);
     524             :     static void detect(...);
     525             : 
     526             : public:
     527             :     static constexpr bool value = std::is_integral<decltype(
     528             :         detect(std::declval<typename BasicJsonType::template json_serializer<
     529             :                    T, void>>()))>::value;
     530             : };
     531             : 
     532             : // This trait checks if JSONSerializer<T>::from_json(json const&) exists
     533             : // this overload is used for non-default-constructible user-defined-types
     534             : template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     535             : struct has_non_default_from_json
     536             : {
     537             : private:
     538             :     template <typename U, typename = enable_if_t<std::is_same<
     539             :                               T, decltype(uncvref_t<U>::from_json(
     540             :                                      std::declval<BasicJsonType>()))>::value>>
     541             :     static int detect(U&&);
     542             :     static void detect(...);
     543             : 
     544             : public:
     545             :     static constexpr bool value = std::is_integral<decltype(
     546             :         detect(std::declval<typename BasicJsonType::template json_serializer<
     547             :                    T, void>>()))>::value;
     548             : };
     549             : 
     550             : // This trait checks if BasicJsonType::json_serializer<T>::to_json exists
     551             : template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>

     553             : {
     554             : private:
     555             :     template <typename U,
     556             :               typename = decltype(uncvref_t<U>::to_json(
     557             :                   std::declval<BasicJsonType&>(), std::declval<T>()))>

     562             :     static constexpr bool value = std::is_integral<decltype(
     563             :         detect(std::declval<typename BasicJsonType::template json_serializer<
     564             :                    T, void>>()))>::value;
     565             : };

     917             : 
     918             : struct to_json_fn
     919             : {
     920             : private:
     921             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     922           0 :     auto call(BasicJsonType& j, T&& val, priority_tag<1>) const
     923             :         noexcept(noexcept(to_json(j, std::forward<T>(val))))
     924             :             -> decltype(to_json(j, std::forward<T>(val)), void())
     925             :     {
     926           0 :         return to_json(j, std::forward<T>(val));
     927             :     }
     928             : 
     929             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     930             :     void call(BasicJsonType&, T&&, priority_tag<0>) const noexcept
     931             :     {
     932             :         static_assert(sizeof(BasicJsonType) == 0,
     933             :                       "could not find to_json() method in T's namespace");
     934             :     }
     935             : 
     936             : public:
     937             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     938           0 :     void operator()(BasicJsonType& j, T&& val) const
     939             :         noexcept(noexcept(std::declval<to_json_fn>().call(j,
     940             :                                                           std::forward<T>(val),
     941             :                                                           priority_tag<1>{})))
     942             :     {
     943           0 :         return call(j, std::forward<T>(val), priority_tag<1>{});
     944             :     }
     945             : };
     946             : 
     947             : struct from_json_fn
     948             : {
     949             : private:
     950             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     951           0 :     auto call(const BasicJsonType& j, T& val, priority_tag<1>) const
     952             :         noexcept(noexcept(from_json(j, val)))
     953             :             -> decltype(from_json(j, val), void())
     954             :     {
     955           0 :         return from_json(j, val);
     956             :     }
     957             : 
     958             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     959             :     void call(const BasicJsonType&, T&, priority_tag<0>) const noexcept
     960             :     {
     961             :         static_assert(sizeof(BasicJsonType) == 0,
     962             :                       "could not find from_json() method in T's namespace");
     963             :     }
     964             : 
     965             : public:
     966             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     967           0 :     void operator()(const BasicJsonType& j, T& val) const
     968             :         noexcept(noexcept(std::declval<from_json_fn>().call(j, val,
     969             :                                                             priority_tag<1>{})))
     970             :     {
     971           0 :         return call(j, val, priority_tag<1>{});
     972             :     }
     973             : };
     974             : 
     975             : // taken from ranges-v3
     976             : template <typename T>
     977             : struct static_const
     978             : {
     979             :     static constexpr T value{};
     980             : };
     981             : 
     982             : template <typename T>
     983             : constexpr T static_const<T>::value;
     984             : } // namespace detail
     985             : 
     986             : /// namespace to hold default `to_json` / `from_json` functions
     987             : namespace
     988             : {
     989             : constexpr const auto& to_json = detail::static_const<detail::to_json_fn>::value;
     990             : constexpr const auto& from_json =
     991             :     detail::static_const<detail::from_json_fn>::value;
     992             : }
     993             : 
     994             : /*!
     995             : @brief default JSONSerializer template argument
     996             : 
     997             : This serializer ignores the template arguments and uses ADL
     998             : ([argument-dependent lookup](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/adl))
     999             : for serialization.
    1000             : */
    1001             : template <typename = void, typename = void>
    1002             : struct adl_serializer
    1003             : {
    1004             :     /*!
    1005             :     @brief convert a JSON value to any value type
    1006             : 
    1007             :     This function is usually called by the `get()` function of the
    1008             :     @ref basic_json class (either explicit or via conversion operators).
    1009             : 
    1010             :     @param[in] j         JSON value to read from
    1011             :     @param[in,out] val  value to write to
    1012             :     */
    1013             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename ValueType>
    1014           0 :     static void from_json(BasicJsonType&& j, ValueType& val) noexcept(
    1015             :         noexcept(::nlohmann::from_json(std::forward<BasicJsonType>(j), val)))
    1016             :     {
    1017           0 :         ::nlohmann::from_json(std::forward<BasicJsonType>(j), val);
    1018           0 :     }
    1019             : 
    1020             :     /*!
    1021             :     @brief convert any value type to a JSON value
    1022             : 
    1023             :     This function is usually called by the constructors of the @ref basic_json
    1024             :     class.
    1025             : 
    1026             :     @param[in,out] j  JSON value to write to
    1027             :     @param[in] val     value to read from
    1028             :     */
    1029             :     template <typename BasicJsonType, typename ValueType>
    1030           0 :     static void to_json(BasicJsonType& j, ValueType&& val) noexcept(
    1031             :         noexcept(::nlohmann::to_json(j, std::forward<ValueType>(val))))
    1032             :     {
    1033           0 :         ::nlohmann::to_json(j, std::forward<ValueType>(val));
    1034           0 :     }
    1035             : };
    1036             : 
    1037             : /*!
    1038             : @brief a class to store JSON values
    1039             : 
    1040             : @tparam ObjectType type for JSON objects (`std::map` by default; will be used
    1041             : in @ref object_t)
    1042             : @tparam ArrayType type for JSON arrays (`std::vector` by default; will be used
    1043             : in @ref array_t)
    1044             : @tparam StringType type for JSON strings and object keys (`std::string` by
    1045             : default; will be used in @ref string_t)
    1046             : @tparam BooleanType type for JSON booleans (`bool` by default; will be used
    1047             : in @ref boolean_t)
    1048             : @tparam NumberIntegerType type for JSON integer numbers (`int64_t` by
    1049             : default; will be used in @ref number_integer_t)
    1050             : @tparam NumberUnsignedType type for JSON unsigned integer numbers (@c
    1051             : `uint64_t` by default; will be used in @ref number_unsigned_t)
    1052             : @tparam NumberFloatType type for JSON floating-point numbers (`double` by
    1053             : default; will be used in @ref number_float_t)
    1054             : @tparam AllocatorType type of the allocator to use (`std::allocator` by
    1055             : default)
    1056             : @tparam JSONSerializer the serializer to resolve internal calls to `to_json()`
    1057             : and `from_json()` (@ref adl_serializer by default)
    1058             : 
    1059             : @requirement The class satisfies the following concept requirements:
    1060             : - Basic
    1061             :  -
    1062             : [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible):
    1063             :    JSON values can be default constructed. The result will be a JSON null
    1064             :    value.
    1065             :  -
    1066             : [MoveConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveConstructible):
    1067             :    A JSON value can be constructed from an rvalue argument.
    1068             :  -
    1069             : [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible):
    1070             :    A JSON value can be copy-constructed from an lvalue expression.
    1071             :  - [MoveAssignable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveAssignable):
    1072             :    A JSON value van be assigned from an rvalue argument.
    1073             :  - [CopyAssignable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyAssignable):
    1074             :    A JSON value can be copy-assigned from an lvalue expression.
    1075             :  - [Destructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Destructible):
    1076             :    JSON values can be destructed.
    1077             : - Layout
    1078             :  -
    1079             : [StandardLayoutType](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/StandardLayoutType):
    1080             :    JSON values have
    1081             :    [standard
    1082             : layout](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/data_members#Standard_layout):
    1083             :    All non-static data members are private and standard layout types, the
    1084             :    class has no virtual functions or (virtual) base classes.
    1085             : - Library-wide
    1086             :  -
    1087             : [EqualityComparable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/EqualityComparable):
    1088             :    JSON values can be compared with `==`, see @ref
    1089             :    operator==(const_reference,const_reference).
    1090             :  -
    1091             : [LessThanComparable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/LessThanComparable):
    1092             :    JSON values can be compared with `<`, see @ref
    1093             :    operator<(const_reference,const_reference).
    1094             :  - [Swappable](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Swappable):
    1095             :    Any JSON lvalue or rvalue of can be swapped with any lvalue or rvalue of
    1096             :    other compatible types, using unqualified function call @ref swap().
    1097             :  - [NullablePointer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/NullablePointer):
    1098             :    JSON values can be compared against `std::nullptr_t` objects which are used
    1099             :    to model the `null` value.
    1100             : - Container
    1101             :  - [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container):
    1102             :    JSON values can be used like STL containers and provide iterator access.
    1103             :  -
    1104             : [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer);
    1105             :    JSON values can be used like STL containers and provide reverse iterator
    1106             :    access.
    1107             : 
    1108             : @invariant The member variables @a m_value and @a m_type have the following
    1109             : relationship:
    1110             : - If `m_type == value_t::object`, then `m_value.object != nullptr`.
    1111             : - If `m_type == value_t::array`, then `m_value.array != nullptr`.
    1112             : - If `m_type == value_t::string`, then `m_value.string != nullptr`.
    1113             : The invariants are checked by member function assert_invariant().
    1114             : 
    1115             : @internal
    1116             : @note ObjectType trick from http://stackoverflow.com/a/9860911
    1117             : @endinternal
    1118             : 
    1119             : @see [RFC 7159: The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Data Interchange
    1120             : Format](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159)
    1121             : 
    1122             : @since version 1.0.0
    1123             : 
    1124             : @nosubgrouping
    1125             : */
    1126             : template <template <typename U, typename V, typename... Args> class ObjectType =
    1127             :               std::map,
    1128             :           template <typename U, typename... Args> class ArrayType = std::vector,
    1129             :           class StringType = std::string, class BooleanType = bool,
    1130             :           class NumberIntegerType = std::int64_t,
    1131             :           class NumberUnsignedType = std::uint64_t,
    1132             :           class NumberFloatType = double,
    1133             :           template <typename U> class AllocatorType = std::allocator,
    1134             :           template <typename T, typename SFINAE = void> class JSONSerializer =
    1135             :               adl_serializer>
    1136             : class basic_json
    1137             : {
    1138             : private:
    1139             :     template <detail::value_t>
    1140             :     friend struct detail::external_constructor;
    1141             :     /// workaround type for MSVC
    1142             :     using basic_json_t =
    1143             :         basic_json<ObjectType, ArrayType, StringType, BooleanType,
    1144             :                    NumberIntegerType, NumberUnsignedType, NumberFloatType,
    1145             :                    AllocatorType, JSONSerializer>;
    1146             : 
    1147             : public:
    1148             :     using value_t = detail::value_t;
    1149             :     // forward declarations
    1150             :     template <typename U>
    1151             :     class iter_impl;
    1152             :     template <typename Base>
    1153             :     class json_reverse_iterator;
    1154             :     class json_pointer;
    1155             :     template <typename T, typename SFINAE>
    1156             :     using json_serializer = JSONSerializer<T, SFINAE>;
    1157             : 
    1158             :     /////////////////////
    1159             :     // container types //
    1160             :     /////////////////////
    1161             : 
    1162             :     /// @name container types
    1163             :     /// The canonic container types to use @ref basic_json like any other STL
    1164             :     /// container.
    1165             :     /// @{
    1166             : 
    1167             :     /// the type of elements in a basic_json container
    1168             :     using value_type = basic_json;
    1169             : 
    1170             :     /// the type of an element reference
    1171             :     using reference = value_type&;
    1172             :     /// the type of an element const reference
    1173             :     using const_reference = const value_type&;
    1174             : 
    1175             :     /// a type to represent differences between iterators
    1176             :     using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
    1177             :     /// a type to represent container sizes
    1178             :     using size_type = std::size_t;
    1179             : 
    1180             :     /// the allocator type
    1181             :     using allocator_type = AllocatorType<basic_json>;
    1182             : 
    1183             :     /// the type of an element pointer
    1184             :     using pointer = typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::pointer;
    1185             :     /// the type of an element const pointer
    1186             :     using const_pointer =
    1187             :         typename std::allocator_traits<allocator_type>::const_pointer;
    1188             : 
    1189             :     /// an iterator for a basic_json container
    1190             :     using iterator = iter_impl<basic_json>;
    1191             :     /// a const iterator for a basic_json container
    1192             :     using const_iterator = iter_impl<const basic_json>;
    1193             :     /// a reverse iterator for a basic_json container
    1194             :     using reverse_iterator =
    1195             :         json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::iterator>;
    1196             :     /// a const reverse iterator for a basic_json container
    1197             :     using const_reverse_iterator =
    1198             :         json_reverse_iterator<typename basic_json::const_iterator>;
    1199             : 
    1200             :     /// @}
    1201             : 
    1202             :     /*!
    1203             :     @brief returns the allocator associated with the container
    1204             :     */
    1205             :     static allocator_type get_allocator() { return allocator_type(); }
    1206             :     /*!
    1207             :     @brief returns version information on the library
    1208             : 
    1209             :     This function returns a JSON object with information about the library,
    1210             :     including the version number and information on the platform and compiler.
    1211             : 
    1212             :     @return JSON object holding version information
    1213             :     key         | description
    1214             :     ----------- | ---------------
    1215             :     `compiler`  | Information on the used compiler. It is an object with the
    1216             :     following keys: `c++` (the used C++ standard), `family` (the compiler
    1217             :     family; possible values are `clang`, `icc`, `gcc`, `ilecpp`, `msvc`,
    1218             :     `pgcpp`, `sunpro`, and `unknown`), and `version` (the compiler version).
    1219             :     `copyright` | The copyright line for the library as string.
    1220             :     `name`      | The name of the library as string.
    1221             :     `platform`  | The used platform as string. Possible values are `win32`,
    1222             :     `linux`, `apple`, `unix`, and `unknown`.
    1223             :     `url`       | The URL of the project as string.
    1224             :     `version`   | The version of the library. It is an object with the following
    1225             :     keys: `major`, `minor`, and `patch` as defined by [Semantic
    1226             :     Versioning](http://semver.org), and `string` (the version string).
    1227             : 
    1228             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example output of the `meta()`
    1229             :     function.,meta}
    1230             : 
    1231             :     @complexity Constant.
    1232             : 
    1233             :     @since 2.1.0
    1234             :     */
    1235             :     static basic_json meta()
    1236             :     {
    1237             :         basic_json result;
    1238             : 
    1239             :         result["copyright"] = "(C) 2013-2017 Niels Lohmann";
    1240             :         result["name"] = "JSON for Modern C++";
    1241             :         result["url"] = "https://github.com/nlohmann/json";
    1242             :         result["version"] = {{"string", "2.1.1"},
    1243             :                              {"major", 2},
    1244             :                              {"minor", 1},
    1245             :                              {"patch", 1}};
    1246             : 
    1247             : #ifdef _WIN32
    1248             :         result["platform"] = "win32";
    1249             : #elif defined __linux__
    1250             :         result["platform"] = "linux";
    1251             : #elif defined __APPLE__
    1252             :         result["platform"] = "apple";
    1253             : #elif defined __unix__
    1254             :         result["platform"] = "unix";
    1255             : #else
    1256             :         result["platform"] = "unknown";
    1257             : #endif
    1258             : 
    1259             : #if defined(__clang__)
    1260             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "clang"},
    1261             :                               {"version", __clang_version__}};
    1262             : #elif defined(__ICC) || defined(__INTEL_COMPILER)
    1263             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "icc"}, {"version", __INTEL_COMPILER}};
    1264             : #elif defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
    1265             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "gcc"},
    1266             :                               {"version",
    1267             :                                std::to_string(__GNUC__) + "." +
    1268             :                                    std::to_string(__GNUC_MINOR__) + "." +
    1269             :                                    std::to_string(__GNUC_PATCHLEVEL__)}};
    1270             : #elif defined(__HP_cc) || defined(__HP_aCC)
    1271             :         result["compiler"] = "hp"
    1272             : #elif defined(__IBMCPP__)
    1273             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "ilecpp"}, {"version", __IBMCPP__}};
    1274             : #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
    1275             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "msvc"}, {"version", _MSC_VER}};
    1276             : #elif defined(__PGI)
    1277             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "pgcpp"}, {"version", __PGI}};
    1278             : #elif defined(__SUNPRO_CC)
    1279             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "sunpro"}, {"version", __SUNPRO_CC}};
    1280             : #else
    1281             :         result["compiler"] = {{"family", "unknown"}, {"version", "unknown"}};
    1282             : #endif
    1283             : 
    1284             : #ifdef __cplusplus
    1285             :         result["compiler"]["c++"] = std::to_string(__cplusplus);
    1286             : #else
    1287             :         result["compiler"]["c++"] = "unknown";
    1288             : #endif
    1289             :         return result;
    1290             :     }
    1291             : 
    1292             :     ///////////////////////////
    1293             :     // JSON value data types //
    1294             :     ///////////////////////////
    1295             : 
    1296             :     /// @name JSON value data types
    1297             :     /// The data types to store a JSON value. These types are derived from
    1298             :     /// the template arguments passed to class @ref basic_json.
    1299             :     /// @{
    1300             : 
    1301             :     /*!
    1302             :     @brief a type for an object
    1303             : 
    1304             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON objects as follows:
    1305             :     > An object is an unordered collection of zero or more name/value pairs,
    1306             :     > where a name is a string and a value is a string, number, boolean, null,
    1307             :     > object, or array.
    1308             : 
    1309             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters
    1310             :     described below.
    1311             : 
    1312             :     @tparam ObjectType  the container to store objects (e.g., `std::map` or
    1313             :     `std::unordered_map`)
    1314             :     @tparam StringType the type of the keys or names (e.g., `std::string`).
    1315             :     The comparison function `std::less<StringType>` is used to order elements
    1316             :     inside the container.
    1317             :     @tparam AllocatorType the allocator to use for objects (e.g.,
    1318             :     `std::allocator`)
    1319             : 
    1320             :     #### Default type
    1321             : 
    1322             :     With the default values for @a ObjectType (`std::map`), @a StringType
    1323             :     (`std::string`), and @a AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default
    1324             :     value for @a object_t is:
    1325             : 
    1326             :     @code {.cpp}
    1327             :     std::map<
    1328             :       std::string, // key_type
    1329             :       basic_json, // value_type
    1330             :       std::less<std::string>, // key_compare
    1331             :       std::allocator<std::pair<const std::string, basic_json>> // allocator_type
    1332             :     >
    1333             :     @endcode
    1334             : 
    1335             :     #### Behavior
    1336             : 
    1337             :     The choice of @a object_t influences the behavior of the JSON class. With
    1338             :     the default type, objects have the following behavior:
    1339             : 
    1340             :     - When all names are unique, objects will be interoperable in the sense
    1341             :       that all software implementations receiving that object will agree on
    1342             :       the name-value mappings.
    1343             :     - When the names within an object are not unique, later stored name/value
    1344             :       pairs overwrite previously stored name/value pairs, leaving the used
    1345             :       names unique. For instance, `{"key": 1}` and `{"key": 2, "key": 1}` will
    1346             :       be treated as equal and both stored as `{"key": 1}`.
    1347             :     - Internally, name/value pairs are stored in lexicographical order of the
    1348             :       names. Objects will also be serialized (see @ref dump) in this order.
    1349             :       For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be stored
    1350             :       and serialized as `{"a": 2, "b": 1}`.
    1351             :     - When comparing objects, the order of the name/value pairs is irrelevant.
    1352             :       This makes objects interoperable in the sense that they will not be
    1353             :       affected by these differences. For instance, `{"b": 1, "a": 2}` and
    1354             :       `{"a": 2, "b": 1}` will be treated as equal.
    1355             : 
    1356             :     #### Limits
    1357             : 
    1358             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
    1359             :     > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
    1360             : 
    1361             :     In this class, the object's limit of nesting is not constraint explicitly.
    1362             :     However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
    1363             :     runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the
    1364             :     @ref max_size function of a JSON object.
    1365             : 
    1366             :     #### Storage
    1367             : 
    1368             :     Objects are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is, for any
    1369             :     access to object values, a pointer of type `object_t*` must be
    1370             :     dereferenced.
    1371             : 
    1372             :     @sa @ref array_t -- type for an array value
    1373             : 
    1374             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1375             : 
    1376             :     @note The order name/value pairs are added to the object is *not*
    1377             :     preserved by the library. Therefore, iterating an object may return
    1378             :     name/value pairs in a different order than they were originally stored. In
    1379             :     fact, keys will be traversed in alphabetical order as `std::map` with
    1380             :     `std::less` is used by default. Please note this behavior conforms to [RFC
    1381             :     7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159), because any order implements the
    1382             :     specified "unordered" nature of JSON objects.
    1383             :     */
    1384             :     using object_t =
    1385             :         ObjectType<StringType, basic_json, std::less<StringType>,
    1386             :                    AllocatorType<std::pair<const StringType, basic_json>>>;
    1387             : 
    1388             :     /*!
    1389             :     @brief a type for an array
    1390             : 
    1391             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON arrays as follows:
    1392             :     > An array is an ordered sequence of zero or more values.
    1393             : 
    1394             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameters
    1395             :     explained below.
    1396             : 
    1397             :     @tparam ArrayType  container type to store arrays (e.g., `std::vector` or
    1398             :     `std::list`)
    1399             :     @tparam AllocatorType allocator to use for arrays (e.g., `std::allocator`)
    1400             : 
    1401             :     #### Default type
    1402             : 
    1403             :     With the default values for @a ArrayType (`std::vector`) and @a
    1404             :     AllocatorType (`std::allocator`), the default value for @a array_t is:
    1405             : 
    1406             :     @code {.cpp}
    1407             :     std::vector<
    1408             :       basic_json, // value_type
    1409             :       std::allocator<basic_json> // allocator_type
    1410             :     >
    1411             :     @endcode
    1412             : 
    1413             :     #### Limits
    1414             : 
    1415             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
    1416             :     > An implementation may set limits on the maximum depth of nesting.
    1417             : 
    1418             :     In this class, the array's limit of nesting is not constraint explicitly.
    1419             :     However, a maximum depth of nesting may be introduced by the compiler or
    1420             :     runtime environment. A theoretical limit can be queried by calling the
    1421             :     @ref max_size function of a JSON array.
    1422             : 
    1423             :     #### Storage
    1424             : 
    1425             :     Arrays are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is, for any
    1426             :     access to array values, a pointer of type `array_t*` must be dereferenced.
    1427             : 
    1428             :     @sa @ref object_t -- type for an object value
    1429             : 
    1430             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1431             :     */
    1432             :     using array_t = ArrayType<basic_json, AllocatorType<basic_json>>;
    1433             : 
    1434             :     /*!
    1435             :     @brief a type for a string
    1436             : 
    1437             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes JSON strings as follows:
    1438             :     > A string is a sequence of zero or more Unicode characters.
    1439             : 
    1440             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter
    1441             :     described below. Unicode values are split by the JSON class into
    1442             :     byte-sized characters during deserialization.
    1443             : 
    1444             :     @tparam StringType  the container to store strings (e.g., `std::string`).
    1445             :     Note this container is used for keys/names in objects, see @ref object_t.
    1446             : 
    1447             :     #### Default type
    1448             : 
    1449             :     With the default values for @a StringType (`std::string`), the default
    1450             :     value for @a string_t is:
    1451             : 
    1452             :     @code {.cpp}
    1453             :     std::string
    1454             :     @endcode
    1455             : 
    1456             :     #### Encoding
    1457             : 
    1458             :     Strings are stored in UTF-8 encoding. Therefore, functions like
    1459             :     `std::string::size()` or `std::string::length()` return the number of
    1460             :     bytes in the string rather than the number of characters or glyphs.
    1461             : 
    1462             :     #### String comparison
    1463             : 
    1464             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
    1465             :     > Software implementations are typically required to test names of object
    1466             :     > members for equality. Implementations that transform the textual
    1467             :     > representation into sequences of Unicode code units and then perform the
    1468             :     > comparison numerically, code unit by code unit, are interoperable in the
    1469             :     > sense that implementations will agree in all cases on equality or
    1470             :     > inequality of two strings. For example, implementations that compare
    1471             :     > strings with escaped characters unconverted may incorrectly find that
    1472             :     > `"a\\b"` and `"a\u005Cb"` are not equal.
    1473             : 
    1474             :     This implementation is interoperable as it does compare strings code unit
    1475             :     by code unit.
    1476             : 
    1477             :     #### Storage
    1478             : 
    1479             :     String values are stored as pointers in a @ref basic_json type. That is,
    1480             :     for any access to string values, a pointer of type `string_t*` must be
    1481             :     dereferenced.
    1482             : 
    1483             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1484             :     */
    1485             :     using string_t = StringType;
    1486             : 
    1487             :     /*!
    1488             :     @brief a type for a boolean
    1489             : 
    1490             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) implicitly describes a boolean as a
    1491             :     type which differentiates the two literals `true` and `false`.
    1492             : 
    1493             :     To store objects in C++, a type is defined by the template parameter @a
    1494             :     BooleanType which chooses the type to use.
    1495             : 
    1496             :     #### Default type
    1497             : 
    1498             :     With the default values for @a BooleanType (`bool`), the default value for
    1499             :     @a boolean_t is:
    1500             : 
    1501             :     @code {.cpp}
    1502             :     bool
    1503             :     @endcode
    1504             : 
    1505             :     #### Storage
    1506             : 
    1507             :     Boolean values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
    1508             : 
    1509             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1510             :     */
    1511             :     using boolean_t = BooleanType;
    1512             : 
    1513             :     /*!
    1514             :     @brief a type for a number (integer)
    1515             : 
    1516             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
    1517             :     > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
    1518             :     > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
    1519             :     > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
    1520             :     > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
    1521             :     > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
    1522             :     > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
    1523             :     > are not permitted.
    1524             : 
    1525             :     This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
    1526             :     However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
    1527             :     is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
    1528             :     Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
    1529             :     number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
    1530             : 
    1531             :     To store integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
    1532             :     parameter @a NumberIntegerType which chooses the type to use.
    1533             : 
    1534             :     #### Default type
    1535             : 
    1536             :     With the default values for @a NumberIntegerType (`int64_t`), the default
    1537             :     value for @a number_integer_t is:
    1538             : 
    1539             :     @code {.cpp}
    1540             :     int64_t
    1541             :     @endcode
    1542             : 
    1543             :     #### Default behavior
    1544             : 
    1545             :     - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
    1546             :       leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
    1547             :       number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
    1548             :       instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`.
    1549             :       During deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
    1550             :     - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
    1551             : 
    1552             :     #### Limits
    1553             : 
    1554             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
    1555             :     > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
    1556             : 
    1557             :     When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
    1558             :     stored is `9223372036854775807` (INT64_MAX) and the minimal integer number
    1559             :     that can be stored is `-9223372036854775808` (INT64_MIN). Integer numbers
    1560             :     that are out of range will yield over/underflow when used in a
    1561             :     constructor. During deserialization, too large or small integer numbers
    1562             :     will be automatically be stored as @ref number_unsigned_t or @ref
    1563             :     number_float_t.
    1564             : 
    1565             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
    1566             :     > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
    1567             :     > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
    1568             :     > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
    1569             : 
    1570             :     As this range is a subrange of the exactly supported range [INT64_MIN,
    1571             :     INT64_MAX], this class's integer type is interoperable.
    1572             : 
    1573             :     #### Storage
    1574             : 
    1575             :     Integer number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
    1576             : 
    1577             :     @sa @ref number_float_t -- type for number values (floating-point)
    1578             : 
    1579             :     @sa @ref number_unsigned_t -- type for number values (unsigned integer)
    1580             : 
    1581             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1582             :     */
    1583             :     using number_integer_t = NumberIntegerType;
    1584             : 
    1585             :     /*!
    1586             :     @brief a type for a number (unsigned)
    1587             : 
    1588             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
    1589             :     > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
    1590             :     > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
    1591             :     > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
    1592             :     > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
    1593             :     > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
    1594             :     > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
    1595             :     > are not permitted.
    1596             : 
    1597             :     This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
    1598             :     However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
    1599             :     is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
    1600             :     Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
    1601             :     number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
    1602             : 
    1603             :     To store unsigned integer numbers in C++, a type is defined by the
    1604             :     template parameter @a NumberUnsignedType which chooses the type to use.
    1605             : 
    1606             :     #### Default type
    1607             : 
    1608             :     With the default values for @a NumberUnsignedType (`uint64_t`), the
    1609             :     default value for @a number_unsigned_t is:
    1610             : 
    1611             :     @code {.cpp}
    1612             :     uint64_t
    1613             :     @endcode
    1614             : 
    1615             :     #### Default behavior
    1616             : 
    1617             :     - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
    1618             :       leading zeros in integer literals lead to an interpretation as octal
    1619             :       number. Internally, the value will be stored as decimal number. For
    1620             :       instance, the C++ integer literal `010` will be serialized to `8`.
    1621             :       During deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
    1622             :     - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
    1623             : 
    1624             :     #### Limits
    1625             : 
    1626             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) specifies:
    1627             :     > An implementation may set limits on the range and precision of numbers.
    1628             : 
    1629             :     When the default type is used, the maximal integer number that can be
    1630             :     stored is `18446744073709551615` (UINT64_MAX) and the minimal integer
    1631             :     number that can be stored is `0`. Integer numbers that are out of range
    1632             :     will yield over/underflow when used in a constructor. During
    1633             :     deserialization, too large or small integer numbers will be automatically
    1634             :     be stored as @ref number_integer_t or @ref number_float_t.
    1635             : 
    1636             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) further states:
    1637             :     > Note that when such software is used, numbers that are integers and are
    1638             :     > in the range \f$[-2^{53}+1, 2^{53}-1]\f$ are interoperable in the sense
    1639             :     > that implementations will agree exactly on their numeric values.
    1640             : 
    1641             :     As this range is a subrange (when considered in conjunction with the
    1642             :     number_integer_t type) of the exactly supported range [0, UINT64_MAX],
    1643             :     this class's integer type is interoperable.
    1644             : 
    1645             :     #### Storage
    1646             : 
    1647             :     Integer number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json type.
    1648             : 
    1649             :     @sa @ref number_float_t -- type for number values (floating-point)
    1650             :     @sa @ref number_integer_t -- type for number values (integer)
    1651             : 
    1652             :     @since version 2.0.0
    1653             :     */
    1654             :     using number_unsigned_t = NumberUnsignedType;
    1655             : 
    1656             :     /*!
    1657             :     @brief a type for a number (floating-point)
    1658             : 
    1659             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) describes numbers as follows:
    1660             :     > The representation of numbers is similar to that used in most
    1661             :     > programming languages. A number is represented in base 10 using decimal
    1662             :     > digits. It contains an integer component that may be prefixed with an
    1663             :     > optional minus sign, which may be followed by a fraction part and/or an
    1664             :     > exponent part. Leading zeros are not allowed. (...) Numeric values that
    1665             :     > cannot be represented in the grammar below (such as Infinity and NaN)
    1666             :     > are not permitted.
    1667             : 
    1668             :     This description includes both integer and floating-point numbers.
    1669             :     However, C++ allows more precise storage if it is known whether the number
    1670             :     is a signed integer, an unsigned integer or a floating-point number.
    1671             :     Therefore, three different types, @ref number_integer_t, @ref
    1672             :     number_unsigned_t and @ref number_float_t are used.
    1673             : 
    1674             :     To store floating-point numbers in C++, a type is defined by the template
    1675             :     parameter @a NumberFloatType which chooses the type to use.
    1676             : 
    1677             :     #### Default type
    1678             : 
    1679             :     With the default values for @a NumberFloatType (`double`), the default
    1680             :     value for @a number_float_t is:
    1681             : 
    1682             :     @code {.cpp}
    1683             :     double
    1684             :     @endcode
    1685             : 
    1686             :     #### Default behavior
    1687             : 
    1688             :     - The restrictions about leading zeros is not enforced in C++. Instead,
    1689             :       leading zeros in floating-point literals will be ignored. Internally,
    1690             :       the value will be stored as decimal number. For instance, the C++
    1691             :       floating-point literal `01.2` will be serialized to `1.2`. During
    1692             :       deserialization, leading zeros yield an error.
    1693             :     - Not-a-number (NaN) values will be serialized to `null`.
    1694             : 
    1695             :     #### Limits
    1696             : 
    1697             :     [RFC 7159](http://rfc7159.net/rfc7159) states:
    1698             :     > This specification allows implementations to set limits on the range and
    1699             :     > precision of numbers accepted. Since software that implements IEEE
    1700             :     > 754-2008 binary64 (double precision) numbers is generally available and
    1701             :     > widely used, good interoperability can be achieved by implementations
    1702             :     > that expect no more precision or range than these provide, in the sense
    1703             :     > that implementations will approximate JSON numbers within the expected
    1704             :     > precision.
    1705             : 
    1706             :     This implementation does exactly follow this approach, as it uses double
    1707             :     precision floating-point numbers. Note values smaller than
    1708             :     `-1.79769313486232e+308` and values greater than `1.79769313486232e+308`
    1709             :     will be stored as NaN internally and be serialized to `null`.
    1710             : 
    1711             :     #### Storage
    1712             : 
    1713             :     Floating-point number values are stored directly inside a @ref basic_json
    1714             :     type.
    1715             : 
    1716             :     @sa @ref number_integer_t -- type for number values (integer)
    1717             : 
    1718             :     @sa @ref number_unsigned_t -- type for number values (unsigned integer)
    1719             : 
    1720             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1721             :     */
    1722             :     using number_float_t = NumberFloatType;
    1723             : 
    1724             :     /// @}
    1725             : 
    1726             : private:
    1727             :     /// helper for exception-safe object creation
    1728             :     template <typename T, typename... Args>
    1729           0 :     static T* create(Args&&... args)
    1730             :     {
    1731           0 :         AllocatorType<T> alloc;
    1732           0 :         auto deleter = [&](T* object) { alloc.deallocate(object, 1); };
    1733             :         std::unique_ptr<T, decltype(deleter)> object(alloc.allocate(1),
    1734           0 :                                                      deleter);
    1735           0 :         alloc.construct(object.get(), std::forward<Args>(args)...);
    1736           0 :         assert(object != nullptr);
    1737           0 :         return object.release();
    1738             :     }
    1739             : 
    1740             :     ////////////////////////
    1741             :     // JSON value storage //
    1742             :     ////////////////////////
    1743             : 
    1744             :     /*!
    1745             :     @brief a JSON value
    1746             : 
    1747             :     The actual storage for a JSON value of the @ref basic_json class. This
    1748             :     union combines the different storage types for the JSON value types
    1749             :     defined in @ref value_t.
    1750             : 
    1751             :     JSON type | value_t type    | used type
    1752             :     --------- | --------------- | ------------------------
    1753             :     object    | object          | pointer to @ref object_t
    1754             :     array     | array           | pointer to @ref array_t
    1755             :     string    | string          | pointer to @ref string_t
    1756             :     boolean   | boolean         | @ref boolean_t
    1757             :     number    | number_integer  | @ref number_integer_t
    1758             :     number    | number_unsigned | @ref number_unsigned_t
    1759             :     number    | number_float    | @ref number_float_t
    1760             :     null      | null            | *no value is stored*
    1761             : 
    1762             :     @note Variable-length types (objects, arrays, and strings) are stored as
    1763             :     pointers. The size of the union should not exceed 64 bits if the default
    1764             :     value types are used.
    1765             : 
    1766             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1767             :     */
    1768             :     union json_value {
    1769             :         /// object (stored with pointer to save storage)
    1770             :         object_t* object;
