    1771             :         /// array (stored with pointer to save storage)
    1772             :         array_t* array;
    1773             :         /// string (stored with pointer to save storage)
    1774             :         string_t* string;
    1775             :         /// boolean
    1776             :         boolean_t boolean;
    1777             :         /// number (integer)
    1778             :         number_integer_t number_integer;
    1779             :         /// number (unsigned integer)
    1780             :         number_unsigned_t number_unsigned;
    1781             :         /// number (floating-point)
    1782             :         number_float_t number_float;
    1783             : 
    1784             :         /// default constructor (for null values)
    1785             :         json_value() = default;
    1786             :         /// constructor for booleans
    1787           0 :         json_value(boolean_t v) noexcept : boolean(v) {}
    1788             :         /// constructor for numbers (integer)
    1789           0 :         json_value(number_integer_t v) noexcept : number_integer(v) {}
    1790             :         /// constructor for numbers (unsigned)
    1791           0 :         json_value(number_unsigned_t v) noexcept : number_unsigned(v) {}
    1792             :         /// constructor for numbers (floating-point)
    1793           0 :         json_value(number_float_t v) noexcept : number_float(v) {}
    1794             :         /// constructor for empty values of a given type
    1795           0 :         json_value(value_t t)
    1796             :         {
    1797           0 :             switch (t)
    1798             :             {
    1799             :             case value_t::object:
    1800             :             {
    1801           0 :                 object = create<object_t>();
    1802           0 :                 break;
    1803             :             }
    1804             : 
    1805             :             case value_t::array:
    1806             :             {
    1807           0 :                 array = create<array_t>();
    1808           0 :                 break;
    1809             :             }
    1810             : 
    1811             :             case value_t::string:
    1812             :             {
    1813           0 :                 string = create<string_t>("");
    1814           0 :                 break;
    1815             :             }
    1816             : 
    1817             :             case value_t::boolean:
    1818             :             {
    1819           0 :                 boolean = boolean_t(false);
    1820           0 :                 break;
    1821             :             }
    1822             : 
    1823             :             case value_t::number_integer:
    1824             :             {
    1825           0 :                 number_integer = number_integer_t(0);
    1826           0 :                 break;
    1827             :             }
    1828             : 
    1829             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
    1830             :             {
    1831           0 :                 number_unsigned = number_unsigned_t(0);
    1832           0 :                 break;
    1833             :             }
    1834             : 
    1835             :             case value_t::number_float:
    1836             :             {
    1837           0 :                 number_float = number_float_t(0.0);
    1838           0 :                 break;
    1839             :             }
    1840             : 
    1841             :             case value_t::null:
    1842             :             {
    1843           0 :                 break;
    1844             :             }
    1845             : 
    1846             :             default:
    1847             :             {
    1848           0 :                 if (t == value_t::null)
    1849             :                 {
    1850           0 :                     JSON_THROW(
    1851             :                         std::domain_error("961c151d2e87f2686a955a9be24d316f1362"
    1852             :                                           "bf21 2.1.1")); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
    1853             :                 }
    1854           0 :                 break;
    1855             :             }
    1856             :             }
    1857           0 :         }
    1858             : 
    1859             :         /// constructor for strings
    1860           0 :         json_value(const string_t& value) { string = create<string_t>(value); }
    1861             :         /// constructor for objects
    1862             :         json_value(const object_t& value) { object = create<object_t>(value); }
    1863             :         /// constructor for arrays
    1864             :         json_value(const array_t& value) { array = create<array_t>(value); }
    1865             :     };
    1866             : 
    1867             :     /*!
    1868             :     @brief checks the class invariants
    1869             : 
    1870             :     This function asserts the class invariants. It needs to be called at the
    1871             :     end of every constructor to make sure that created objects respect the
    1872             :     invariant. Furthermore, it has to be called each time the type of a JSON
    1873             :     value is changed, because the invariant expresses a relationship between
    1874             :     @a m_type and @a m_value.
    1875             :     */
    1876           0 :     void assert_invariant() const
    1877             :     {
    1878           0 :         assert(m_type != value_t::object or m_value.object != nullptr);
    1879           0 :         assert(m_type != value_t::array or m_value.array != nullptr);
    1880           0 :         assert(m_type != value_t::string or m_value.string != nullptr);
    1881           0 :     }
    1882             : 
    1883             : public:
    1884             :     //////////////////////////
    1885             :     // JSON parser callback //
    1886             :     //////////////////////////
    1887             : 
    1888             :     /*!
    1889             :     @brief JSON callback events
    1890             : 
    1891             :     This enumeration lists the parser events that can trigger calling a
    1892             :     callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t during parsing.
    1893             : 
    1894             :     @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are
    1895             :     triggered"
    1896             : 
    1897             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1898             :     */
    1899             :     enum class parse_event_t : uint8_t
    1900             :     {
    1901             :         /// the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object
    1902             :         object_start,
    1903             :         /// the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object
    1904             :         object_end,
    1905             :         /// the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array
    1906             :         array_start,
    1907             :         /// the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array
    1908             :         array_end,
    1909             :         /// the parser read a key of a value in an object
    1910             :         key,
    1911             :         /// the parser finished reading a JSON value
    1912             :         value
    1913             :     };
    1914             : 
    1915             :     /*!
    1916             :     @brief per-element parser callback type
    1917             : 
    1918             :     With a parser callback function, the result of parsing a JSON text can be
    1919             :     influenced. When passed to @ref parse(std::istream&, const
    1920             :     parser_callback_t) or @ref parse(const CharT, const parser_callback_t),
    1921             :     it is called on certain events (passed as @ref parse_event_t via parameter
    1922             :     @a event) with a set recursion depth @a depth and context JSON value
    1923             :     @a parsed. The return value of the callback function is a boolean
    1924             :     indicating whether the element that emitted the callback shall be kept or
    1925             :     not.
    1926             : 
    1927             :     We distinguish six scenarios (determined by the event type) in which the
    1928             :     callback function can be called. The following table describes the values
    1929             :     of the parameters @a depth, @a event, and @a parsed.
    1930             : 
    1931             :     parameter @a event | description | parameter @a depth | parameter @a parsed
    1932             :     ------------------ | ----------- | ------------------ | -------------------
    1933             :     parse_event_t::object_start | the parser read `{` and started to process a
    1934             :     JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | a JSON value with
    1935             :     type discarded
    1936             :     parse_event_t::key | the parser read a key of a value in an object | depth
    1937             :     of the currently parsed JSON object | a JSON string containing the key
    1938             :     parse_event_t::object_end | the parser read `}` and finished processing a
    1939             :     JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | the parsed JSON
    1940             :     object
    1941             :     parse_event_t::array_start | the parser read `[` and started to process a
    1942             :     JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | a JSON value with type
    1943             :     discarded
    1944             :     parse_event_t::array_end | the parser read `]` and finished processing a
    1945             :     JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | the parsed JSON array
    1946             :     parse_event_t::value | the parser finished reading a JSON value | depth of
    1947             :     the value | the parsed JSON value
    1948             : 
    1949             :     @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are
    1950             :     triggered"
    1951             : 
    1952             :     Discarding a value (i.e., returning `false`) has different effects
    1953             :     depending on the context in which function was called:
    1954             : 
    1955             :     - Discarded values in structured types are skipped. That is, the parser
    1956             :       will behave as if the discarded value was never read.
    1957             :     - In case a value outside a structured type is skipped, it is replaced
    1958             :       with `null`. This case happens if the top-level element is skipped.
    1959             : 
    1960             :     @param[in] depth  the depth of the recursion during parsing
    1961             : 
    1962             :     @param[in] event  an event of type parse_event_t indicating the context in
    1963             :     the callback function has been called
    1964             : 
    1965             :     @param[in,out] parsed  the current intermediate parse result; note that
    1966             :     writing to this value has no effect for parse_event_t::key events
    1967             : 
    1968             :     @return Whether the JSON value which called the function during parsing
    1969             :     should be kept (`true`) or not (`false`). In the latter case, it is either
    1970             :     skipped completely or replaced by an empty discarded object.
    1971             : 
    1972             :     @sa @ref parse(std::istream&, parser_callback_t) or
    1973             :     @ref parse(const CharT, const parser_callback_t) for examples
    1974             : 
    1975             :     @since version 1.0.0
    1976             :     */
    1977             :     using parser_callback_t =
    1978             :         std::function<bool(int depth, parse_event_t event, basic_json& parsed)>;
    1979             : 
    1980             :     //////////////////
    1981             :     // constructors //
    1982             :     //////////////////
    1983             : 
    1984             :     /// @name constructors and destructors
    1985             :     /// Constructors of class @ref basic_json, copy/move constructor, copy
    1986             :     /// assignment, static functions creating objects, and the destructor.
    1987             :     /// @{
    1988             : 
    1989             :     /*!
    1990             :     @brief create an empty value with a given type
    1991             : 
    1992             :     Create an empty JSON value with a given type. The value will be default
    1993             :     initialized with an empty value which depends on the type:
    1994             : 
    1995             :     Value type  | initial value
    1996             :     ----------- | -------------
    1997             :     null        | `null`
    1998             :     boolean     | `false`
    1999             :     string      | `""`
    2000             :     number      | `0`
    2001             :     object      | `{}`
    2002             :     array       | `[]`
    2003             : 
    2004             :     @param[in] value_type  the type of the value to create
    2005             : 
    2006             :     @complexity Constant.
    2007             : 
    2008             :     @throw std::bad_alloc if allocation for object, array, or string value
    2009             :     fails
    2010             : 
    2011             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor for different @ref
    2012             :     value_t values,basic_json__value_t}
    2013             : 
    2014             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2015             :     */
    2016           0 :     basic_json(const value_t value_type)
    2017             :         : m_type(value_type)
    2018           0 :         , m_value(value_type)
    2019             :     {
    2020           0 :         assert_invariant();
    2021           0 :     }
    2022             : 
    2023             :     /*!
    2024             :     @brief create a null object
    2025             : 
    2026             :     Create a `null` JSON value. It either takes a null pointer as parameter
    2027             :     (explicitly creating `null`) or no parameter (implicitly creating `null`).
    2028             :     The passed null pointer itself is not read -- it is only used to choose
    2029             :     the right constructor.
    2030             : 
    2031             :     @complexity Constant.
    2032             : 
    2033             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
    2034             :     exceptions.
    2035             : 
    2036             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with and without a
    2037             :     null pointer parameter.,basic_json__nullptr_t}
    2038             : 
    2039             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2040             :     */
    2041           0 :     basic_json(std::nullptr_t = nullptr) noexcept : basic_json(value_t::null)
    2042             :     {
    2043           0 :         assert_invariant();
    2044           0 :     }
    2045             : 
    2046             :     /*!
    2047             :     @brief create a JSON value
    2048             : 
    2049             :     This is a "catch all" constructor for all compatible JSON types; that is,
    2050             :     types for which a `to_json()` method exsits. The constructor forwards the
    2051             :     parameter @a val to that method (to `json_serializer<U>::to_json` method
    2052             :     with `U = uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`, to be exact).
    2053             : 
    2054             :     Template type @a CompatibleType includes, but is not limited to, the
    2055             :     following types:
    2056             :     - **arrays**: @ref array_t and all kinds of compatible containers such as
    2057             :       `std::vector`, `std::deque`, `std::list`, `std::forward_list`,
    2058             :       `std::array`, `std::set`, `std::unordered_set`, `std::multiset`, and
    2059             :       `unordered_multiset` with a `value_type` from which a @ref basic_json
    2060             :       value can be constructed.
    2061             :     - **objects**: @ref object_t and all kinds of compatible associative
    2062             :       containers such as `std::map`, `std::unordered_map`, `std::multimap`,
    2063             :       and `std::unordered_multimap` with a `key_type` compatible to
    2064             :       @ref string_t and a `value_type` from which a @ref basic_json value can
    2065             :       be constructed.
    2066             :     - **strings**: @ref string_t, string literals, and all compatible string
    2067             :       containers can be used.
    2068             :     - **numbers**: @ref number_integer_t, @ref number_unsigned_t,
    2069             :       @ref number_float_t, and all convertible number types such as `int`,
    2070             :       `size_t`, `int64_t`, `float` or `double` can be used.
    2071             :     - **boolean**: @ref boolean_t / `bool` can be used.
    2072             : 
    2073             :     See the examples below.
    2074             : 
    2075             :     @tparam CompatibleType a type such that:
    2076             :     - @a CompatibleType is not derived from `std::istream`,
    2077             :     - @a CompatibleType is not @ref basic_json (to avoid hijacking copy/move
    2078             :          constructors),
    2079             :     - @a CompatibleType is not a @ref basic_json nested type (e.g.,
    2080             :          @ref json_pointer, @ref iterator, etc ...)
    2081             :     - @ref @ref json_serializer<U> has a
    2082             :          `to_json(basic_json_t&, CompatibleType&&)` method
    2083             : 
    2084             :     @tparam U = `uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`
    2085             : 
    2086             :     @param[in] val the value to be forwarded
    2087             : 
    2088             :     @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
    2089             :                 depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
    2090             :                 method.
    2091             : 
    2092             :     @throw what `json_serializer<U>::to_json()` throws
    2093             : 
    2094             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with several
    2095             :     compatible types.,basic_json__CompatibleType}
    2096             : 
    2097             :     @since version 2.1.0
    2098             :     */
    2099             :     template <
    2100             :         typename CompatibleType, typename U = detail::uncvref_t<CompatibleType>,
    2101             :         detail::enable_if_t<not std::is_base_of<std::istream, U>::value and
    2102             :                                 not std::is_same<U, basic_json_t>::value and
    2103             :                                 not detail::is_basic_json_nested_type<
    2104             :                                     basic_json_t, U>::value and
    2105             :                                 detail::has_to_json<basic_json, U>::value,
    2106             :                             int> = 0>
    2107           0 :     basic_json(CompatibleType&& val) noexcept(
    2108             :         noexcept(JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(std::declval<basic_json_t&>(),
    2109             :                                             std::forward<CompatibleType>(val))))
    2110           0 :     {
    2111           0 :         JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(*this, std::forward<CompatibleType>(val));
    2112           0 :         assert_invariant();
    2113           0 :     }
    2114             : 
    2115             :     /*!
    2116             :     @brief create a container (array or object) from an initializer list
    2117             : 
    2118             :     Creates a JSON value of type array or object from the passed initializer
    2119             :     list @a init. In case @a type_deduction is `true` (default), the type of
    2120             :     the JSON value to be created is deducted from the initializer list @a init
    2121             :     according to the following rules:
    2122             : 
    2123             :     1. If the list is empty, an empty JSON object value `{}` is created.
    2124             :     2. If the list consists of pairs whose first element is a string, a JSON
    2125             :        object value is created where the first elements of the pairs are
    2126             :        treated as keys and the second elements are as values.
    2127             :     3. In all other cases, an array is created.
    2128             : 
    2129             :     The rules aim to create the best fit between a C++ initializer list and
    2130             :     JSON values. The rationale is as follows:
    2131             : 
    2132             :     1. The empty initializer list is written as `{}` which is exactly an empty
    2133             :        JSON object.
    2134             :     2. C++ has now way of describing mapped types other than to list a list of
    2135             :        pairs. As JSON requires that keys must be of type string, rule 2 is the
    2136             :        weakest constraint one can pose on initializer lists to interpret them
    2137             :        as an object.
    2138             :     3. In all other cases, the initializer list could not be interpreted as
    2139             :        JSON object type, so interpreting it as JSON array type is safe.
    2140             : 
    2141             :     With the rules described above, the following JSON values cannot be
    2142             :     expressed by an initializer list:
    2143             : 
    2144             :     - the empty array (`[]`): use @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>)
    2145             :       with an empty initializer list in this case
    2146             :     - arrays whose elements satisfy rule 2: use @ref
    2147             :       array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) with the same initializer list
    2148             :       in this case
    2149             : 
    2150             :     @note When used without parentheses around an empty initializer list, @ref
    2151             :     basic_json() is called instead of this function, yielding the JSON null
    2152             :     value.
    2153             : 
    2154             :     @param[in] init  initializer list with JSON values
    2155             : 
    2156             :     @param[in] type_deduction internal parameter; when set to `true`, the type
    2157             :     of the JSON value is deducted from the initializer list @a init; when set
    2158             :     to `false`, the type provided via @a manual_type is forced. This mode is
    2159             :     used by the functions @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) and
    2160             :     @ref object(std::initializer_list<basic_json>).
    2161             : 
    2162             :     @param[in] manual_type internal parameter; when @a type_deduction is set
    2163             :     to `false`, the created JSON value will use the provided type (only @ref
    2164             :     value_t::array and @ref value_t::object are valid); when @a type_deduction
    2165             :     is set to `true`, this parameter has no effect
    2166             : 
    2167             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a type_deduction is `false`, @a manual_type
    2168             :     is `value_t::object`, but @a init contains an element which is not a pair
    2169             :     whose first element is a string; example: `"cannot create object from
    2170             :     initializer list"`
    2171             : 
    2172             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
    2173             : 
    2174             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values are created from
    2175             :     initializer lists.,basic_json__list_init_t}
    2176             : 
    2177             :     @sa @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) -- create a JSON array
    2178             :     value from an initializer list
    2179             :     @sa @ref object(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) -- create a JSON object
    2180             :     value from an initializer list
    2181             : 
    2182             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2183             :     */
    2184             :     basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init,
    2185             :                bool type_deduction = true, value_t manual_type = value_t::array)
    2186             :     {
    2187             :         // check if each element is an array with two elements whose first
    2188             :         // element is a string
    2189             :         bool is_an_object = std::all_of(init.begin(), init.end(),
    2190             :                                         [](const basic_json& element) {
    2191             :                                             return element.is_array() and
    2192             :                                                    element.size() == 2 and
    2193             :                                                    element[0].is_string();
    2194             :                                         });
    2195             : 
    2196             :         // adjust type if type deduction is not wanted
    2197             :         if (not type_deduction)
    2198             :         {
    2199             :             // if array is wanted, do not create an object though possible
    2200             :             if (manual_type == value_t::array)
    2201             :             {
    2202             :                 is_an_object = false;
    2203             :             }
    2204             : 
    2205             :             // if object is wanted but impossible, throw an exception
    2206             :             if (manual_type == value_t::object and not is_an_object)
    2207             :             {
    2208             :                 JSON_THROW(std::domain_error(
    2209             :                     "cannot create object from initializer list"));
    2210             :             }
    2211             :         }
    2212             : 
    2213             :         if (is_an_object)
    2214             :         {
    2215             :             // the initializer list is a list of pairs -> create object
    2216             :             m_type = value_t::object;
    2217             :             m_value = value_t::object;
    2218             : 
    2219             :             std::for_each(init.begin(), init.end(),
    2220             :                           [this](const basic_json& element) {
    2221             :                               m_value.object->emplace(
    2222             :                                   *(element[0].m_value.string), element[1]);
    2223             :                           });
    2224             :         }
    2225             :         else
    2226             :         {
    2227             :             // the initializer list describes an array -> create array
    2228             :             m_type = value_t::array;
    2229             :             m_value.array = create<array_t>(init);
    2230             :         }
    2231             : 
    2232             :         assert_invariant();
    2233             :     }
    2234             : 
    2235             :     /*!
    2236             :     @brief explicitly create an array from an initializer list
    2237             : 
    2238             :     Creates a JSON array value from a given initializer list. That is, given a
    2239             :     list of values `a, b, c`, creates the JSON value `[a, b, c]`. If the
    2240             :     initializer list is empty, the empty array `[]` is created.
    2241             : 
    2242             :     @note This function is only needed to express two edge cases that cannot
    2243             :     be realized with the initializer list constructor (@ref
    2244             :     basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t)). These cases
    2245             :     are:
    2246             :     1. creating an array whose elements are all pairs whose first element is a
    2247             :     string -- in this case, the initializer list constructor would create an
    2248             :     object, taking the first elements as keys
    2249             :     2. creating an empty array -- passing the empty initializer list to the
    2250             :     initializer list constructor yields an empty object
    2251             : 
    2252             :     @param[in] init  initializer list with JSON values to create an array from
    2253             :     (optional)
    2254             : 
    2255             :     @return JSON array value
    2256             : 
    2257             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
    2258             : 
    2259             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `array`
    2260             :     function.,array}
    2261             : 
    2262             :     @sa @ref basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t) --
    2263             :     create a JSON value from an initializer list
    2264             :     @sa @ref object(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) -- create a JSON object
    2265             :     value from an initializer list
    2266             : 
    2267             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2268             :     */
    2269             :     static basic_json array(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init =
    2270             :                                 std::initializer_list<basic_json>())
    2271             :     {
    2272             :         return basic_json(init, false, value_t::array);
    2273             :     }
    2274             : 
    2275             :     /*!
    2276             :     @brief explicitly create an object from an initializer list
    2277             : 
    2278             :     Creates a JSON object value from a given initializer list. The initializer
    2279             :     lists elements must be pairs, and their first elements must be strings. If
    2280             :     the initializer list is empty, the empty object `{}` is created.
    2281             : 
    2282             :     @note This function is only added for symmetry reasons. In contrast to the
    2283             :     related function @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>), there are
    2284             :     no cases which can only be expressed by this function. That is, any
    2285             :     initializer list @a init can also be passed to the initializer list
    2286             :     constructor @ref basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool,
    2287             :     value_t).
    2288             : 
    2289             :     @param[in] init  initializer list to create an object from (optional)
    2290             : 
    2291             :     @return JSON object value
    2292             : 
    2293             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a init is not a pair whose first elements are
    2294             :     strings; thrown by
    2295             :     @ref basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t)
    2296             : 
    2297             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
    2298             : 
    2299             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `object`
    2300             :     function.,object}
    2301             : 
    2302             :     @sa @ref basic_json(std::initializer_list<basic_json>, bool, value_t) --
    2303             :     create a JSON value from an initializer list
    2304             :     @sa @ref array(std::initializer_list<basic_json>) -- create a JSON array
    2305             :     value from an initializer list
    2306             : 
    2307             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2308             :     */
    2309             :     static basic_json object(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init =
    2310             :                                  std::initializer_list<basic_json>())
    2311             :     {
    2312             :         return basic_json(init, false, value_t::object);
    2313             :     }
    2314             : 
    2315             :     /*!
    2316             :     @brief construct an array with count copies of given value
    2317             : 
    2318             :     Constructs a JSON array value by creating @a cnt copies of a passed value.
    2319             :     In case @a cnt is `0`, an empty array is created. As postcondition,
    2320             :     `std::distance(begin(),end()) == cnt` holds.
    2321             : 
    2322             :     @param[in] cnt  the number of JSON copies of @a val to create
    2323             :     @param[in] val  the JSON value to copy
    2324             : 
    2325             :     @complexity Linear in @a cnt.
    2326             : 
    2327             :     @liveexample{The following code shows examples for the @ref
    2328             :     basic_json(size_type\, const basic_json&)
    2329             :     constructor.,basic_json__size_type_basic_json}
    2330             : 
    2331             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2332             :     */
    2333             :     basic_json(size_type cnt, const basic_json& val)
    2334             :         : m_type(value_t::array)
    2335             :     {
    2336             :         m_value.array = create<array_t>(cnt, val);
    2337             :         assert_invariant();
    2338             :     }
    2339             : 
    2340             :     /*!
    2341             :     @brief construct a JSON container given an iterator range
    2342             : 
    2343             :     Constructs the JSON value with the contents of the range `[first, last)`.
    2344             :     The semantics depends on the different types a JSON value can have:
    2345             :     - In case of primitive types (number, boolean, or string), @a first must
    2346             :       be `begin()` and @a last must be `end()`. In this case, the value is
    2347             :       copied. Otherwise, std::out_of_range is thrown.
    2348             :     - In case of structured types (array, object), the constructor behaves as
    2349             :       similar versions for `std::vector`.
    2350             :     - In case of a null type, std::domain_error is thrown.
    2351             : 
    2352             :     @tparam InputIT an input iterator type (@ref iterator or @ref
    2353             :     const_iterator)
    2354             : 
    2355             :     @param[in] first begin of the range to copy from (included)
    2356             :     @param[in] last end of the range to copy from (excluded)
    2357             : 
    2358             :     @pre Iterators @a first and @a last must be initialized. **This
    2359             :          precondition is enforced with an assertion.**
    2360             : 
    2361             :     @throw std::domain_error if iterators are not compatible; that is, do not
    2362             :     belong to the same JSON value; example: `"iterators are not compatible"`
    2363             :     @throw std::out_of_range if iterators are for a primitive type (number,
    2364             :     boolean, or string) where an out of range error can be detected easily;
    2365             :     example: `"iterators out of range"`
    2366             :     @throw std::bad_alloc if allocation for object, array, or string fails
    2367             :     @throw std::domain_error if called with a null value; example: `"cannot
    2368             :     use construct with iterators from null"`
    2369             : 
    2370             :     @complexity Linear in distance between @a first and @a last.
    2371             : 
    2372             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several ways to create JSON values by
    2373             :     specifying a subrange with iterators.,basic_json__InputIt_InputIt}
    2374             : 
    2375             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2376             :     */
    2377             :     template <
    2378             :         class InputIT,
    2379             :         typename std::enable_if<
    2380             :             std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
    2381             :                 std::is_same<InputIT,
    2382             :                              typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value,
    2383             :             int>::type = 0>
    2384             :     basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last)
    2385             :     {
    2386             :         assert(first.m_object != nullptr);
    2387             :         assert(last.m_object != nullptr);
    2388             : 
    2389             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
    2390             :         if (first.m_object != last.m_object)
    2391             :         {
    2392             :             JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("iterators are not compatible"));
    2393             :         }
    2394             : 
    2395             :         // copy type from first iterator
    2396             :         m_type = first.m_object->m_type;
    2397             : 
    2398             :         // check if iterator range is complete for primitive values
    2399             :         switch (m_type)
    2400             :         {
    2401             :         case value_t::boolean:
    2402             :         case value_t::number_float:
    2403             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    2404             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    2405             :         case value_t::string:
    2406             :         {
    2407             :             if (not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin() or
    2408             :                 not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end())
    2409             :             {
    2410             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range("iterators out of range"));
    2411             :             }
    2412             :             break;
    2413             :         }
    2414             : 
    2415             :         default:
    2416             :         {
    2417             :             break;
    2418             :         }
    2419             :         }
    2420             : 
    2421             :         switch (m_type)
    2422             :         {
    2423             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    2424             :         {
    2425             :             m_value.number_integer = first.m_object->m_value.number_integer;
    2426             :             break;
    2427             :         }
    2428             : 
    2429             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    2430             :         {
    2431             :             m_value.number_unsigned = first.m_object->m_value.number_unsigned;
    2432             :             break;
    2433             :         }
    2434             : 
    2435             :         case value_t::number_float:
    2436             :         {
    2437             :             m_value.number_float = first.m_object->m_value.number_float;
    2438             :             break;
    2439             :         }
    2440             : 
    2441             :         case value_t::boolean:
    2442             :         {
    2443             :             m_value.boolean = first.m_object->m_value.boolean;
    2444             :             break;
    2445             :         }
    2446             : 
    2447             :         case value_t::string:
    2448             :         {
    2449             :             m_value = *first.m_object->m_value.string;
    2450             :             break;
    2451             :         }
    2452             : 
    2453             :         case value_t::object:
    2454             :         {
    2455             :             m_value.object = create<object_t>(first.m_it.object_iterator,
    2456             :                                               last.m_it.object_iterator);
    2457             :             break;
    2458             :         }
    2459             : 
    2460             :         case value_t::array:
    2461             :         {
    2462             :             m_value.array = create<array_t>(first.m_it.array_iterator,
    2463             :                                             last.m_it.array_iterator);
    2464             :             break;
    2465             :         }
    2466             : 
    2467             :         default:
    2468             :         {
    2469             :             JSON_THROW(
    2470             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use construct with iterators from " +
    2471             :                                   first.m_object->type_name()));
    2472             :         }
    2473             :         }
    2474             : 
    2475             :         assert_invariant();
    2476             :     }
    2477             : 
    2478             :     /*!
    2479             :     @brief construct a JSON value given an input stream
    2480             : 
    2481             :     @param[in,out] i  stream to read a serialized JSON value from
    2482             :     @param[in] cb a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
    2483             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
    2484             :     (optional)
    2485             : 
    2486             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    2487             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
    2488             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
    2489             : 
    2490             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    2491             : 
    2492             :     @deprecated This constructor is deprecated and will be removed in version
    2493             :       3.0.0 to unify the interface of the library. Deserialization will be
    2494             :       done by stream operators or by calling one of the `parse` functions,
    2495             :       e.g. @ref parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t). That is, calls
    2496             :       like `json j(i);` for an input stream @a i need to be replaced by
    2497             :       `json j = json::parse(i);`. See the example below.
    2498             : 
    2499             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates constructing a JSON value from
    2500             :     a `std::stringstream` with and without callback
    2501             :     function.,basic_json__istream}
    2502             : 
    2503             :     @since version 2.0.0, deprecated in version 2.0.3, to be removed in
    2504             :            version 3.0.0
    2505             :     */
    2506             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
    2507             :     explicit basic_json(std::istream& i, const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    2508             :     {
    2509             :         *this = parser(i, cb).parse();
    2510             :         assert_invariant();
    2511             :     }
    2512             : 
    2513             :     ///////////////////////////////////////
    2514             :     // other constructors and destructor //
    2515             :     ///////////////////////////////////////
    2516             : 
    2517             :     /*!
    2518             :     @brief copy constructor
    2519             : 
    2520             :     Creates a copy of a given JSON value.
    2521             : 
    2522             :     @param[in] other  the JSON value to copy
    2523             : 
    2524             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a other.
    2525             : 
    2526             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    2527             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    2528             :     requirements:
    2529             :     - The complexity is linear.
    2530             :     - As postcondition, it holds: `other == basic_json(other)`.
    2531             : 
    2532             :     @throw std::bad_alloc if allocation for object, array, or string fails.
    2533             : 
    2534             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the copy
    2535             :     constructor.,basic_json__basic_json}
    2536             : 
    2537             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2538             :     */
    2539             :     basic_json(const basic_json& other)
    2540             :         : m_type(other.m_type)
    2541             :     {
    2542             :         // check of passed value is valid
    2543             :         other.assert_invariant();
    2544             : 
    2545             :         switch (m_type)
    2546             :         {
    2547             :         case value_t::object:
    2548             :         {
    2549             :             m_value = *other.m_value.object;
    2550             :             break;
    2551             :         }
    2552             : 
    2553             :         case value_t::array:
    2554             :         {
    2555             :             m_value = *other.m_value.array;
    2556             :             break;
    2557             :         }
    2558             : 
    2559             :         case value_t::string:
    2560             :         {
    2561             :             m_value = *other.m_value.string;
    2562             :             break;
    2563             :         }
    2564             : 
    2565             :         case value_t::boolean:
    2566             :         {
    2567             :             m_value = other.m_value.boolean;
    2568             :             break;
    2569             :         }
    2570             : 
    2571             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    2572             :         {
    2573             :             m_value = other.m_value.number_integer;
    2574             :             break;
    2575             :         }
    2576             : 
    2577             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    2578             :         {
    2579             :             m_value = other.m_value.number_unsigned;
    2580             :             break;
    2581             :         }
    2582             : 
    2583             :         case value_t::number_float:
    2584             :         {
    2585             :             m_value = other.m_value.number_float;
    2586             :             break;
    2587             :         }
    2588             : 
    2589             :         default:
    2590             :         {
    2591             :             break;
    2592             :         }
    2593             :         }
    2594             : 
    2595             :         assert_invariant();
    2596             :     }
    2597             : 
    2598             :     /*!
    2599             :     @brief move constructor
    2600             : 
    2601             :     Move constructor. Constructs a JSON value with the contents of the given
    2602             :     value @a other using move semantics. It "steals" the resources from @a
    2603             :     other and leaves it as JSON null value.
    2604             : 
    2605             :     @param[in,out] other  value to move to this object
    2606             : 
    2607             :     @post @a other is a JSON null value
    2608             : 
    2609             :     @complexity Constant.
    2610             : 
    2611             :     @liveexample{The code below shows the move constructor explicitly called
    2612             :     via std::move.,basic_json__moveconstructor}
    2613             : 
    2614             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2615             :     */
    2616           0 :     basic_json(basic_json&& other) noexcept : m_type(std::move(other.m_type)),
    2617           0 :                                               m_value(std::move(other.m_value))
    2618             :     {
    2619             :         // check that passed value is valid
    2620           0 :         other.assert_invariant();
    2621             : 
    2622             :         // invalidate payload
    2623           0 :         other.m_type = value_t::null;
    2624           0 :         other.m_value = {};
    2625             : 
    2626           0 :         assert_invariant();
    2627           0 :     }
    2628             : 
    2629             :     /*!
    2630             :     @brief copy assignment
    2631             : 
    2632             :     Copy assignment operator. Copies a JSON value via the "copy and swap"
    2633             :     strategy: It is expressed in terms of the copy constructor, destructor,
    2634             :     and the swap() member function.
    2635             : 
    2636             :     @param[in] other  value to copy from
    2637             : 
    2638             :     @complexity Linear.
    2639             : 
    2640             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    2641             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    2642             :     requirements:
    2643             :     - The complexity is linear.
    2644             : 
    2645             :     @liveexample{The code below shows and example for the copy assignment. It
    2646             :     creates a copy of value `a` which is then swapped with `b`. Finally\, the
    2647             :     copy of `a` (which is the null value after the swap) is
    2648             :     destroyed.,basic_json__copyassignment}
    2649             : 
    2650             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2651             :     */
    2652           0 :     reference& operator=(basic_json other) noexcept(
    2653             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
    2654             :             std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
    2655             :                 std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
    2656             :                     std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value)
    2657             :     {
    2658             :         // check that passed value is valid
    2659           0 :         other.assert_invariant();
    2660             : 
    2661             :         using std::swap;
    2662           0 :         swap(m_type, other.m_type);
    2663           0 :         swap(m_value, other.m_value);
    2664             : 
    2665           0 :         assert_invariant();
    2666           0 :         return *this;
    2667             :     }
    2668             : 
    2669             :     /*!
    2670             :     @brief destructor
    2671             : 
    2672             :     Destroys the JSON value and frees all allocated memory.
    2673             : 
    2674             :     @complexity Linear.
    2675             : 
    2676             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    2677             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    2678             :     requirements:
    2679             :     - The complexity is linear.
    2680             :     - All stored elements are destroyed and all memory is freed.
    2681             : 
    2682             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2683             :     */
    2684           0 :     ~basic_json()
    2685             :     {
    2686           0 :         assert_invariant();
    2687             : 
    2688           0 :         switch (m_type)
    2689             :         {
    2690             :         case value_t::object:
    2691             :         {
    2692           0 :             AllocatorType<object_t> alloc;
    2693           0 :             alloc.destroy(m_value.object);
    2694           0 :             alloc.deallocate(m_value.object, 1);
    2695           0 :             break;
    2696             :         }
    2697             : 
    2698             :         case value_t::array:
    2699             :         {
    2700           0 :             AllocatorType<array_t> alloc;
    2701           0 :             alloc.destroy(m_value.array);
    2702           0 :             alloc.deallocate(m_value.array, 1);
    2703           0 :             break;
    2704             :         }
    2705             : 
    2706             :         case value_t::string:
    2707             :         {
    2708           0 :             AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
    2709           0 :             alloc.destroy(m_value.string);
    2710           0 :             alloc.deallocate(m_value.string, 1);
    2711           0 :             break;
    2712             :         }
    2713             : 
    2714             :         default:
    2715             :         {
    2716             :             // all other types need no specific destructor
    2717           0 :             break;
    2718             :         }
    2719             :         }
    2720           0 :     }
    2721             : 
    2722             :     /// @}
    2723             : 
    2724             : public:
    2725             :     ///////////////////////
    2726             :     // object inspection //
    2727             :     ///////////////////////
    2728             : 
    2729             :     /// @name object inspection
    2730             :     /// Functions to inspect the type of a JSON value.
    2731             :     /// @{
    2732             : 
    2733             :     /*!
    2734             :     @brief serialization
    2735             : 
    2736             :     Serialization function for JSON values. The function tries to mimic
    2737             :     Python's `json.dumps()` function, and currently supports its @a indent
    2738             :     parameter.
    2739             : 
    2740             :     @param[in] indent If indent is nonnegative, then array elements and object
    2741             :     members will be pretty-printed with that indent level. An indent level of
    2742             :     `0` will only insert newlines. `-1` (the default) selects the most compact
    2743             :     representation.
    2744             : 
    2745             :     @return string containing the serialization of the JSON value
    2746             : 
    2747             :     @complexity Linear.
    2748             : 
    2749             :     @liveexample{The following example shows the effect of different @a indent
    2750             :     parameters to the result of the serialization.,dump}
    2751             : 
    2752             :     @see https://docs.python.org/2/library/json.html#json.dump
    2753             : 
    2754             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2755             :     */
    2756           0 :     string_t dump(const int indent = -1) const
    2757             :     {
    2758           0 :         std::stringstream ss;
    2759             : 
    2760           0 :         if (indent >= 0)
    2761             :         {
    2762           0 :             dump(ss, true, static_cast<unsigned int>(indent));
    2763             :         }
    2764             :         else
    2765             :         {
    2766           0 :             dump(ss, false, 0);
    2767             :         }
    2768             : 
    2769           0 :         return ss.str();
    2770             :     }
    2771             : 
    2772             :     /*!
    2773             :     @brief return the type of the JSON value (explicit)
    2774             : 
    2775             :     Return the type of the JSON value as a value from the @ref value_t
    2776             :     enumeration.
    2777             : 
    2778             :     @return the type of the JSON value

    2780             :     @complexity Constant.
    2781             : 
    2782             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
    2783             :     exceptions.

    2786             :     types.,type}
    2787             : 
    2788             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2789             :     */
    2790             :     constexpr value_t type() const noexcept { return m_type; }
    2791             :     /*!
    2792             :     @brief return whether type is primitive
    2793             : 
    2794             :     This function returns true iff the JSON type is primitive (string, number,
    2795             :     boolean, or null).
    2796             : 
    2797             :     @return `true` if type is primitive (string, number, boolean, or null),
    2798             :     `false` otherwise.
    2799             : 
    2800             :     @complexity Constant.
    2801             : 
    2802             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
    2803             :     exceptions.
    2804             : 
    2805             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_primitive()` for all JSON
    2806             :     types.,is_primitive}
    2807             : 
    2808             :     @sa @ref is_structured() -- returns whether JSON value is structured
    2809             :     @sa @ref is_null() -- returns whether JSON value is `null`
    2810             :     @sa @ref is_string() -- returns whether JSON value is a string
    2811             :     @sa @ref is_boolean() -- returns whether JSON value is a boolean
    2812             :     @sa @ref is_number() -- returns whether JSON value is a number
    2813             : 
    2814             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2815             :     */
    2816             :     constexpr bool is_primitive() const noexcept
    2817             :     {
    2818             :         return is_null() or is_string() or is_boolean() or is_number();
    2819             :     }
    2820             : 
    2821             :     /*!
    2822             :     @brief return whether type is structured
    2823             : 
    2824             :     This function returns true iff the JSON type is structured (array or
    2825             :     object).
    2826             : 
    2827             :     @return `true` if type is structured (array or object), `false` otherwise.
    2828             : 
    2829             :     @complexity Constant.

    2832             :     exceptions.
    2833             :

    2835             :     types.,is_structured}

    2837             :     @sa @ref is_primitive() -- returns whether value is primitive
    2838             :     @sa @ref is_array() -- returns whether value is an array
    2839             :     @sa @ref is_object() -- returns whether value is an object
    2840             : 
    2841             :     @since version 1.0.0
    2842             :     */
    2843             :     constexpr bool is_structured() const noexcept
    2844             :     {
    2845             :         return is_array() or is_object();
    2846             :     }
    2847             : 
    2848             :     /*!
    2849             :     @brief return whether value is null

    2865           0 :     constexpr bool is_null() const noexcept { return m_type == value_t::null; }

    2887             : 
    2888             :     /*!
    2889             :     @brief return whether value is a number
    2890             : 
    2891             :     This function returns true iff the JSON value is a number. This includes
    2892             :     both integer and floating-point values.
    2893             : 
    2894             :     @return `true` if type is number (regardless whether integer, unsigned
    2895             :     integer or floating-type), `false` otherwise.

    2900             :     exceptions.

    3070             :     /*!
    3071             :     @brief return whether value is discarded
    3072             : 
    3073             :     This function returns true iff the JSON value was discarded during parsing
    3074             :     with a callback function (see @ref parser_callback_t).
    3075             : 
    3076             :     @note This function will always be `false` for JSON values after parsing.
    3077             :     That is, discarded values can only occur during parsing, but will be
    3078             :     removed when inside a structured value or replaced by null in other cases.
    3079             : 
    3080             :     @return `true` if type is discarded, `false` otherwise.
    3081             : 
    3082             :     @complexity Constant.

    3085             :     exceptions.

    3088             :     types.,is_discarded}
    3089             : 
    3090             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3091             :     */

    3093             :     {
    3094           0 :         return m_type == value_t::discarded;

    3118             : private:

    3120             :     // value access //
