    3122             : 
    3123             :     /// get a boolean (explicit)
    3124             :     boolean_t get_impl(boolean_t* /*unused*/) const
    3125             :     {
    3126             :         if (is_boolean())
    3127             :         {
    3128             :             return m_value.boolean;
    3129             :         }
    3130             : 
    3131             :         JSON_THROW(
    3132             :             std::domain_error("type must be boolean, but is " + type_name()));
    3133             :     }
    3134             : 
    3135             :     /// get a pointer to the value (object)
    3136             :     object_t* get_impl_ptr(object_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3137             :     {
    3138             :         return is_object() ? m_value.object : nullptr;
    3139             :     }
    3140             : 
    3141             :     /// get a pointer to the value (object)
    3142             :     constexpr const object_t* get_impl_ptr(const object_t* /*unused*/) const
    3143             :         noexcept
    3144             :     {
    3145             :         return is_object() ? m_value.object : nullptr;
    3146             :     }
    3147             : 
    3148             :     /// get a pointer to the value (array)
    3149             :     array_t* get_impl_ptr(array_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3150             :     {
    3151             :         return is_array() ? m_value.array : nullptr;
    3152             :     }
    3153             : 
    3154             :     /// get a pointer to the value (array)
    3155             :     constexpr const array_t* get_impl_ptr(const array_t* /*unused*/) const
    3156             :         noexcept
    3157             :     {
    3158             :         return is_array() ? m_value.array : nullptr;
    3159             :     }
    3160             : 
    3161             :     /// get a pointer to the value (string)
    3162             :     string_t* get_impl_ptr(string_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3163             :     {
    3164             :         return is_string() ? m_value.string : nullptr;
    3165             :     }
    3166             : 
    3167             :     /// get a pointer to the value (string)
    3168           0 :     constexpr const string_t* get_impl_ptr(const string_t* /*unused*/) const
    3169             :         noexcept
    3170             :     {
    3171           0 :         return is_string() ? m_value.string : nullptr;
    3172             :     }
    3173             : 
    3174             :     /// get a pointer to the value (boolean)
    3175             :     boolean_t* get_impl_ptr(boolean_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3176             :     {
    3177             :         return is_boolean() ? &m_value.boolean : nullptr;
    3178             :     }
    3179             : 
    3180             :     /// get a pointer to the value (boolean)
    3181             :     constexpr const boolean_t* get_impl_ptr(const boolean_t* /*unused*/) const
    3182             :         noexcept
    3183             :     {
    3184             :         return is_boolean() ? &m_value.boolean : nullptr;
    3185             :     }
    3186             : 
    3187             :     /// get a pointer to the value (integer number)
    3188             :     number_integer_t* get_impl_ptr(number_integer_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3189             :     {
    3190             :         return is_number_integer() ? &m_value.number_integer : nullptr;
    3191             :     }
    3192             : 
    3193             :     /// get a pointer to the value (integer number)
    3194             :     constexpr const number_integer_t* get_impl_ptr(
    3195             :         const number_integer_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
    3196             :     {
    3197             :         return is_number_integer() ? &m_value.number_integer : nullptr;
    3198             :     }
    3199             : 
    3200             :     /// get a pointer to the value (unsigned number)
    3201             :     number_unsigned_t* get_impl_ptr(number_unsigned_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3202             :     {
    3203             :         return is_number_unsigned() ? &m_value.number_unsigned : nullptr;
    3204             :     }
    3205             : 
    3206             :     /// get a pointer to the value (unsigned number)
    3207             :     constexpr const number_unsigned_t* get_impl_ptr(
    3208             :         const number_unsigned_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
    3209             :     {
    3210             :         return is_number_unsigned() ? &m_value.number_unsigned : nullptr;
    3211             :     }
    3212             : 
    3213             :     /// get a pointer to the value (floating-point number)
    3214             :     number_float_t* get_impl_ptr(number_float_t* /*unused*/) noexcept
    3215             :     {
    3216             :         return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
    3217             :     }
    3218             : 
    3219             :     /// get a pointer to the value (floating-point number)
    3220             :     constexpr const number_float_t* get_impl_ptr(
    3221             :         const number_float_t* /*unused*/) const noexcept
    3222             :     {
    3223             :         return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
    3224             :     }
    3225             : 
    3226             :     /*!
    3227             :     @brief helper function to implement get_ref()
    3228             : 
    3229             :     This funcion helps to implement get_ref() without code duplication for
    3230             :     const and non-const overloads
    3231             : 
    3232             :     @tparam ThisType will be deduced as `basic_json` or `const basic_json`
    3233             : 
    3234             :     @throw std::domain_error if ReferenceType does not match underlying value
    3235             :     type of the current JSON
    3236             :     */
    3237             :     template <typename ReferenceType, typename ThisType>
    3238             :     static ReferenceType get_ref_impl(ThisType& obj)
    3239             :     {
    3240             :         // helper type
    3241             :         using PointerType = typename std::add_pointer<ReferenceType>::type;
    3242             : 
    3243             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr<>()
    3244             :         auto ptr = obj.template get_ptr<PointerType>();
    3245             : 
    3246             :         if (ptr != nullptr)
    3247             :         {
    3248             :             return *ptr;
    3249             :         }
    3250             : 
    3251             :         JSON_THROW(std::domain_error(
    3252             :             "incompatible ReferenceType for get_ref, actual type is " +
    3253             :             obj.type_name()));
    3254             :     }
    3255             : 
    3256             : public:
    3257             :     /// @name value access
    3258             :     /// Direct access to the stored value of a JSON value.
    3259             :     /// @{
    3260             : 
    3261             :     /*!
    3262             :     @brief get special-case overload
    3263             : 
    3264             :     This overloads avoids a lot of template boilerplate, it can be seen as the
    3265             :     identity method
    3266             : 
    3267             :     @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
    3268             : 
    3269             :     @return a copy of *this
    3270             : 
    3271             :     @complexity Constant.
    3272             : 
    3273             :     @since version 2.1.0
    3274             :     */
    3275             :     template <typename BasicJsonType,
    3276             :               detail::enable_if_t<
    3277             :                   std::is_same<typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type,
    3278             :                                basic_json_t>::value,
    3279             :                   int> = 0>
    3280             :     basic_json get() const
    3281             :     {
    3282             :         return *this;
    3283             :     }
    3284             : 
    3285             :     /*!
    3286             :     @brief get a value (explicit)
    3287             : 
    3288             :     Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
    3289             :     which is
    3290             :     [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible)
    3291             :     and
    3292             :     [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible).
    3293             :     The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
    3294             :     `from_json()` method.
    3295             : 
    3296             :     The function is equivalent to executing
    3297             :     @code {.cpp}
    3298             :     ValueType ret;
    3299             :     JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
    3300             :     return ret;
    3301             :     @endcode
    3302             : 
    3303             :     This overloads is chosen if:
    3304             :     - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json,
    3305             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
    3306             :       `void from_json(const @ref basic_json&, ValueType&)`, and
    3307             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> does not have a `from_json()` method of
    3308             :       the form `ValueType from_json(const @ref basic_json&)`
    3309             : 
    3310             :     @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
    3311             :     @tparam ValueType the returned value type
    3312             : 
    3313             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
    3314             : 
    3315             :     @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
    3316             : 
    3317             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
    3318             :     to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
    3319             :     be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
    3320             :     `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
    3321             :     associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
    3322             :     json>`.,get__ValueType_const}
    3323             : 
    3324             :     @since version 2.1.0
    3325             :     */
    3326             :     template <typename ValueTypeCV,
    3327             :               typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
    3328             :               detail::enable_if_t<
    3329             :                   not std::is_same<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
    3330             :                       detail::has_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
    3331             :                       not detail::has_non_default_from_json<basic_json_t,
    3332             :                                                             ValueType>::value,
    3333             :                   int> = 0>
    3334           0 :     ValueType get() const
    3335             :         noexcept(noexcept(JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(
    3336             :             std::declval<const basic_json_t&>(), std::declval<ValueType&>())))
    3337             :     {
    3338             :         // we cannot static_assert on ValueTypeCV being non-const, because
    3339             :         // there is support for get<const basic_json_t>(), which is why we
    3340             :         // still need the uncvref
    3341             :         static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
    3342             :                       "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might "
    3343             :                       "want to use get_ref()");
    3344             :         static_assert(
    3345             :             std::is_default_constructible<ValueType>::value,
    3346             :             "types must be DefaultConstructible when used with get()");
    3347             : 
    3348           0 :         ValueType ret;
    3349           0 :         JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
    3350           0 :         return ret;
    3351             :     }
    3352             : 
    3353             :     /*!
    3354             :     @brief get a value (explicit); special case
    3355             : 
    3356             :     Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
    3357             :     which is **not**
    3358             :     [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible)
    3359             :     and **not**
    3360             :     [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible).
    3361             :     The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
    3362             :     `from_json()` method.
    3363             : 
    3364             :     The function is equivalent to executing
    3365             :     @code {.cpp}
    3366             :     return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
    3367             :     @endcode
    3368             : 
    3369             :     This overloads is chosen if:
    3370             :     - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json and
    3371             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
    3372             :       `ValueType from_json(const @ref basic_json&)`
    3373             : 
    3374             :     @note If @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has both overloads of
    3375             :     `from_json()`, this one is chosen.
    3376             : 
    3377             :     @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
    3378             :     @tparam ValueType the returned value type
    3379             : 
    3380             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
    3381             : 
    3382             :     @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
    3383             : 
    3384             :     @since version 2.1.0
    3385             :     */
    3386             :     template <
    3387             :         typename ValueTypeCV,
    3388             :         typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
    3389             :         detail::enable_if_t<not std::is_same<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
    3390             :                                 detail::has_non_default_from_json<
    3391             :                                     basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
    3392             :                             int> = 0>
    3393             :     ValueType get() const
    3394             :         noexcept(noexcept(JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(
    3395             :             std::declval<const basic_json_t&>())))
    3396             :     {
    3397             :         static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
    3398             :                       "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might "
    3399             :                       "want to use get_ref()");
    3400             :         return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
    3401             :     }
    3402             : 
    3403             :     /*!
    3404             :     @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
    3405             : 
    3406             :     Explicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
    3407             :     made.
    3408             : 
    3409             :     @warning The pointer becomes invalid if the underlying JSON object
    3410             :     changes.
    3411             : 
    3412             :     @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
    3413             :     object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
    3414             :     @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t.
    3415             : 
    3416             :     @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
    3417             :     pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
    3418             : 
    3419             :     @complexity Constant.
    3420             : 
    3421             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
    3422             :     JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
    3423             :     `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
    3424             :     match.,get__PointerType}
    3425             : 
    3426             :     @sa @ref get_ptr() for explicit pointer-member access
    3427             : 
    3428             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3429             :     */
    3430             :     template <typename PointerType,
    3431             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value,
    3432             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    3433             :     PointerType get() noexcept
    3434             :     {
    3435             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr
    3436             :         return get_ptr<PointerType>();
    3437             :     }
    3438             : 
    3439             :     /*!
    3440             :     @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
    3441             :     @copydoc get()
    3442             :     */
    3443             :     template <typename PointerType,
    3444             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value,
    3445             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    3446             :     constexpr const PointerType get() const noexcept
    3447             :     {
    3448             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr
    3449             :         return get_ptr<PointerType>();
    3450             :     }
    3451             : 
    3452             :     /*!
    3453             :     @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
    3454             : 
    3455             :     Implicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
    3456             :     made.
    3457             : 
    3458             :     @warning Writing data to the pointee of the result yields an undefined
    3459             :     state.
    3460             : 
    3461             :     @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
    3462             :     object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
    3463             :     @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t. Enforced by a static
    3464             :     assertion.
    3465             : 
    3466             :     @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
    3467             :     pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
    3468             : 
    3469             :     @complexity Constant.
    3470             : 
    3471             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
    3472             :     JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
    3473             :     `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
    3474             :     match.,get_ptr}
    3475             : 
    3476             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3477             :     */
    3478             :     template <typename PointerType,
    3479             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value,
    3480             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    3481             :     PointerType get_ptr() noexcept
    3482             :     {
    3483             :         // get the type of the PointerType (remove pointer and const)
    3484             :         using pointee_t =
    3485             :             typename std::remove_const<typename std::remove_pointer<
    3486             :                 typename std::remove_const<PointerType>::type>::type>::type;
    3487             :         // make sure the type matches the allowed types
    3488             :         static_assert(std::is_same<object_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3489             :                           std::is_same<array_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3490             :                           std::is_same<string_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3491             :                           std::is_same<boolean_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3492             :                           std::is_same<number_integer_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3493             :                           std::is_same<number_unsigned_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3494             :                           std::is_same<number_float_t, pointee_t>::value,
    3495             :                       "incompatible pointer type");
    3496             : 
    3497             :         // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>()
    3498             :         return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<PointerType>(nullptr));
    3499             :     }
    3500             : 
    3501             :     /*!
    3502             :     @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
    3503             :     @copydoc get_ptr()
    3504             :     */
    3505             :     template <
    3506             :         typename PointerType,
    3507             :         typename std::enable_if<std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value and
    3508             :                                     std::is_const<typename std::remove_pointer<
    3509             :                                         PointerType>::type>::value,
    3510             :                                 int>::type = 0>
    3511           0 :     constexpr const PointerType get_ptr() const noexcept
    3512             :     {
    3513             :         // get the type of the PointerType (remove pointer and const)
    3514             :         using pointee_t =
    3515             :             typename std::remove_const<typename std::remove_pointer<
    3516             :                 typename std::remove_const<PointerType>::type>::type>::type;
    3517             :         // make sure the type matches the allowed types
    3518             :         static_assert(std::is_same<object_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3519             :                           std::is_same<array_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3520             :                           std::is_same<string_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3521             :                           std::is_same<boolean_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3522             :                           std::is_same<number_integer_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3523             :                           std::is_same<number_unsigned_t, pointee_t>::value or
    3524             :                           std::is_same<number_float_t, pointee_t>::value,
    3525             :                       "incompatible pointer type");
    3526             : 
    3527             :         // delegate the call to get_impl_ptr<>() const
    3528           0 :         return get_impl_ptr(static_cast<const PointerType>(nullptr));
    3529             :     }
    3530             : 
    3531             :     /*!
    3532             :     @brief get a reference value (implicit)
    3533             : 
    3534             :     Implicit reference access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies
    3535             :     are made.
    3536             : 
    3537             :     @warning Writing data to the referee of the result yields an undefined
    3538             :     state.
    3539             : 
    3540             :     @tparam ReferenceType reference type; must be a reference to @ref array_t,
    3541             :     @ref object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t, or
    3542             :     @ref number_float_t. Enforced by static assertion.
    3543             : 
    3544             :     @return reference to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
    3545             :     reference type @a ReferenceType fits to the JSON value; throws
    3546             :     std::domain_error otherwise
    3547             : 
    3548             :     @throw std::domain_error in case passed type @a ReferenceType is
    3549             :     incompatible with the stored JSON value
    3550             : 
    3551             :     @complexity Constant.
    3552             : 
    3553             :     @liveexample{The example shows several calls to `get_ref()`.,get_ref}
    3554             : 
    3555             :     @since version 1.1.0
    3556             :     */
    3557             :     template <typename ReferenceType,
    3558             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value,
    3559             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    3560             :     ReferenceType get_ref()
    3561             :     {
    3562             :         // delegate call to get_ref_impl
    3563             :         return get_ref_impl<ReferenceType>(*this);
    3564             :     }
    3565             : 
    3566             :     /*!
    3567             :     @brief get a reference value (implicit)
    3568             :     @copydoc get_ref()
    3569             :     */
    3570             :     template <typename ReferenceType,
    3571             :               typename std::enable_if<
    3572             :                   std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value and
    3573             :                       std::is_const<typename std::remove_reference<
    3574             :                           ReferenceType>::type>::value,
    3575             :                   int>::type = 0>
    3576             :     ReferenceType get_ref() const
    3577             :     {
    3578             :         // delegate call to get_ref_impl
    3579             :         return get_ref_impl<ReferenceType>(*this);
    3580             :     }
    3581             : 
    3582             :     /*!
    3583             :     @brief get a value (implicit)
    3584             : 
    3585             :     Implicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value.
    3586             :     The call is realized by calling @ref get() const.
    3587             : 
    3588             :     @tparam ValueType non-pointer type compatible to the JSON value, for
    3589             :     instance `int` for JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or
    3590             :     `std::vector` types for JSON arrays. The character type of @ref string_t
    3591             :     as well as an initializer list of this type is excluded to avoid
    3592             :     ambiguities as these types implicitly convert to `std::string`.
    3593             : 
    3594             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to type @a ValueType
    3595             : 
    3596             :     @throw std::domain_error in case passed type @a ValueType is incompatible
    3597             :     to JSON, thrown by @ref get() const
    3598             : 
    3599             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
    3600             : 
    3601             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
    3602             :     to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
    3603             :     be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
    3604             :     `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
    3605             :     associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
    3606             :     json>`.,operator__ValueType}
    3607             : 
    3608             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3609             :     */
    3610             :     template <typename ValueType,
    3611             :               typename std::enable_if<
    3612             :                   not std::is_pointer<ValueType>::value and
    3613             :                       not std::is_same<ValueType,
    3614             :                                        typename string_t::value_type>::value
    3615             : #ifndef _MSC_VER // fix for issue #167 operator<< ambiguity under VS2015
    3616             :                       and
    3617             :                       not std::is_same<
    3618             :                           ValueType, std::initializer_list<
    3619             :                                          typename string_t::value_type>>::value
    3620             : #endif
    3621             :                   ,
    3622             :                   int>::type = 0>
    3623           0 :     operator ValueType() const
    3624             :     {
    3625             :         // delegate the call to get<>() const
    3626           0 :         return get<ValueType>();
    3627             :     }
    3628             : 
    3629             :     /// @}
    3630             : 
    3631             :     ////////////////////
    3632             :     // element access //
    3633             :     ////////////////////
    3634             : 
    3635             :     /// @name element access
    3636             :     /// Access to the JSON value.
    3637             :     /// @{
    3638             : 
    3639             :     /*!
    3640             :     @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
    3641             : 
    3642             :     Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx, with
    3643             :     bounds checking.
    3644             : 
    3645             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
    3646             : 
    3647             :     @return reference to the element at index @a idx
    3648             : 
    3649             :     @throw std::domain_error if the JSON value is not an array; example:
    3650             :     `"cannot use at() with string"`
    3651             :     @throw std::out_of_range if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
    3652             :     that is, `idx >= size()`; example: `"array index 7 is out of range"`
    3653             : 
    3654             :     @complexity Constant.
    3655             : 
    3656             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
    3657             :     written using `at()`.,at__size_type}
    3658             : 
    3659             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3660             :     */
    3661             :     reference at(size_type idx)
    3662             :     {
    3663             :         // at only works for arrays
    3664             :         if (is_array())
    3665             :         {
    3666             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.array->at(idx); }
    3667             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
    3668             :             {
    3669             :                 // create better exception explanation
    3670             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range(
    3671             :                     "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
    3672             :             }
    3673             :         }
    3674             :         else
    3675             :         {
    3676             :             JSON_THROW(
    3677             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use at() with " + type_name()));
    3678             :         }
    3679             :     }
    3680             : 
    3681             :     /*!
    3682             :     @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
    3683             : 
    3684             :     Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx,
    3685             :     with bounds checking.
    3686             : 
    3687             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
    3688             : 
    3689             :     @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
    3690             : 
    3691             :     @throw std::domain_error if the JSON value is not an array; example:
    3692             :     `"cannot use at() with string"`
    3693             :     @throw std::out_of_range if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
    3694             :     that is, `idx >= size()`; example: `"array index 7 is out of range"`
    3695             : 
    3696             :     @complexity Constant.
    3697             : 
    3698             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
    3699             :     `at()`.,at__size_type_const}
    3700             : 
    3701             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3702             :     */
    3703             :     const_reference at(size_type idx) const
    3704             :     {
    3705             :         // at only works for arrays
    3706             :         if (is_array())
    3707             :         {
    3708             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.array->at(idx); }
    3709             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
    3710             :             {
    3711             :                 // create better exception explanation
    3712             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range(
    3713             :                     "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
    3714             :             }
    3715             :         }
    3716             :         else
    3717             :         {
    3718             :             JSON_THROW(
    3719             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use at() with " + type_name()));
    3720             :         }
    3721             :     }
    3722             : 
    3723             :     /*!
    3724             :     @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
    3725             : 
    3726             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key, with
    3727             :     bounds checking.
    3728             : 
    3729             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    3730             : 
    3731             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
    3732             : 
    3733             :     @throw std::domain_error if the JSON value is not an object; example:
    3734             :     `"cannot use at() with boolean"`
    3735             :     @throw std::out_of_range if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
    3736             :     that is, `find(key) == end()`; example: `"key "the fast" not found"`
    3737             : 
    3738             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    3739             : 
    3740             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
    3741             :     written using `at()`.,at__object_t_key_type}
    3742             : 
    3743             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
    3744             :     access by reference
    3745             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    3746             : 
    3747             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3748             :     */
    3749             :     reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
    3750             :     {
    3751             :         // at only works for objects
    3752             :         if (is_object())
    3753             :         {
    3754             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.object->at(key); }
    3755             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
    3756             :             {
    3757             :                 // create better exception explanation
    3758             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range("key '" + key + "' not found"));
    3759             :             }
    3760             :         }
    3761             :         else
    3762             :         {
    3763             :             JSON_THROW(
    3764             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use at() with " + type_name()));
    3765             :         }
    3766             :     }
    3767             : 
    3768             :     /*!
    3769             :     @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
    3770             : 
    3771             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key,
    3772             :     with bounds checking.
    3773             : 
    3774             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    3775             : 
    3776             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key
    3777             : 
    3778             :     @throw std::domain_error if the JSON value is not an object; example:
    3779             :     `"cannot use at() with boolean"`
    3780             :     @throw std::out_of_range if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
    3781             :     that is, `find(key) == end()`; example: `"key "the fast" not found"`
    3782             : 
    3783             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    3784             : 
    3785             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
    3786             :     `at()`.,at__object_t_key_type_const}
    3787             : 
    3788             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
    3789             :     access by reference
    3790             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    3791             : 
    3792             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3793             :     */
    3794             :     const_reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key) const
    3795             :     {
    3796             :         // at only works for objects
    3797             :         if (is_object())
    3798             :         {
    3799             :             JSON_TRY { return m_value.object->at(key); }
    3800             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&)
    3801             :             {
    3802             :                 // create better exception explanation
    3803             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range("key '" + key + "' not found"));
    3804             :             }
    3805             :         }
    3806             :         else
    3807             :         {
    3808             :             JSON_THROW(
    3809             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use at() with " + type_name()));
    3810             :         }
    3811             :     }
    3812             : 
    3813             :     /*!
    3814             :     @brief access specified array element
    3815             : 
    3816             :     Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
    3817             : 
    3818             :     @note If @a idx is beyond the range of the array (i.e., `idx >= size()`),
    3819             :     then the array is silently filled up with `null` values to make `idx` a
    3820             :     valid reference to the last stored element.
    3821             : 
    3822             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
    3823             : 
    3824             :     @return reference to the element at index @a idx
    3825             : 
    3826             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an array or null; example:
    3827             :     `"cannot use operator[] with string"`
    3828             : 
    3829             :     @complexity Constant if @a idx is in the range of the array. Otherwise
    3830             :     linear in `idx - size()`.
    3831             : 
    3832             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
    3833             :     written using `[]` operator. Note the addition of `null`
    3834             :     values.,operatorarray__size_type}
    3835             : 
    3836             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3837             :     */
    3838             :     reference operator[](size_type idx)
    3839             :     {
    3840             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty array
    3841             :         if (is_null())
    3842             :         {
    3843             :             m_type = value_t::array;
    3844             :             m_value.array = create<array_t>();
    3845             :             assert_invariant();
    3846             :         }
    3847             : 
    3848             :         // operator[] only works for arrays
    3849             :         if (is_array())
    3850             :         {
    3851             :             // fill up array with null values if given idx is outside range
    3852             :             if (idx >= m_value.array->size())
    3853             :             {
    3854             :                 m_value.array->insert(m_value.array->end(),
    3855             :                                       idx - m_value.array->size() + 1,
    3856             :                                       basic_json());
    3857             :             }
    3858             : 
    3859             :             return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
    3860             :         }
    3861             : 
    3862             :         JSON_THROW(
    3863             :             std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name()));
    3864             :     }
    3865             : 
    3866             :     /*!
    3867             :     @brief access specified array element
    3868             : 
    3869             :     Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
    3870             : 
    3871             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
    3872             : 
    3873             :     @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
    3874             : 
    3875             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an array; example: `"cannot use
    3876             :     operator[] with null"`
    3877             : 
    3878             :     @complexity Constant.
    3879             : 
    3880             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
    3881             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__size_type_const}
    3882             : 
    3883             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3884             :     */
    3885             :     const_reference operator[](size_type idx) const
    3886             :     {
    3887             :         // const operator[] only works for arrays
    3888             :         if (is_array())
    3889             :         {
    3890             :             return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
    3891             :         }
    3892             : 
    3893             :         JSON_THROW(
    3894             :             std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name()));
    3895             :     }
    3896             : 
    3897             :     /*!
    3898             :     @brief access specified object element
    3899             : 
    3900             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
    3901             : 
    3902             :     @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
    3903             :     the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
    3904             :     In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
    3905             : 
    3906             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    3907             : 
    3908             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
    3909             : 
    3910             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object or null; example:
    3911             :     `"cannot use operator[] with string"`
    3912             : 
    3913             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    3914             : 
    3915             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
    3916             :     written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
    3917             : 
    3918             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    3919             :     with range checking
    3920             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    3921             : 
    3922             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3923             :     */
    3924           0 :     reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key)
    3925             :     {
    3926             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
    3927           0 :         if (is_null())
    3928             :         {
    3929           0 :             m_type = value_t::object;
    3930           0 :             m_value.object = create<object_t>();
    3931           0 :             assert_invariant();
    3932             :         }
    3933             : 
    3934             :         // operator[] only works for objects
    3935           0 :         if (is_object())
    3936             :         {
    3937           0 :             return m_value.object->operator[](key);
    3938             :         }
    3939             : 
    3940           0 :         JSON_THROW(
    3941             :             std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name()));
    3942             :     }
    3943             : 
    3944             :     /*!
    3945             :     @brief read-only access specified object element
    3946             : 
    3947             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key. No
    3948             :     bounds checking is performed.
    3949             : 
    3950             :     @warning If the element with key @a key does not exist, the behavior is
    3951             :     undefined.
    3952             : 
    3953             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    3954             : 
    3955             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key
    3956             : 
    3957             :     @pre The element with key @a key must exist. **This precondition is
    3958             :          enforced with an assertion.**
    3959             : 
    3960             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object; example: `"cannot use
    3961             :     operator[] with null"`
    3962             : 
    3963             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    3964             : 
    3965             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
    3966             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}
    3967             : 
    3968             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    3969             :     with range checking
    3970             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    3971             : 
    3972             :     @since version 1.0.0
    3973             :     */
    3974             :     const_reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key) const
    3975             :     {
    3976             :         // const operator[] only works for objects
    3977             :         if (is_object())
    3978             :         {
    3979             :             assert(m_value.object->find(key) != m_value.object->end());
    3980             :             return m_value.object->find(key)->second;
    3981             :         }
    3982             : 
    3983             :         JSON_THROW(
    3984             :             std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name()));
    3985             :     }
    3986             : 
    3987             :     /*!
    3988             :     @brief access specified object element
    3989             : 
    3990             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
    3991             : 
    3992             :     @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
    3993             :     the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
    3994             :     In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
    3995             : 
    3996             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    3997             : 
    3998             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
    3999             : 
    4000             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object or null; example:
    4001             :     `"cannot use operator[] with string"`
    4002             : 
    4003             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    4004             : 
    4005             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
    4006             :     written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
    4007             : 
    4008             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    4009             :     with range checking
    4010             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    4011             : 
    4012             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4013             :     */
    4014             :     template <typename T, std::size_t n>
    4015             :     reference operator[](T* (&key)[n])
    4016             :     {
    4017             :         return operator[](static_cast<const T>(key));
    4018             :     }
    4019             : 
    4020             :     /*!
    4021             :     @brief read-only access specified object element
    4022             : 
    4023             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key. No
    4024             :     bounds checking is performed.
    4025             : 
    4026             :     @warning If the element with key @a key does not exist, the behavior is
    4027             :     undefined.
    4028             : 
    4029             :     @note This function is required for compatibility reasons with Clang.
    4030             : 
    4031             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    4032             : 
    4033             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key
    4034             :

    4036             :     operator[] with null"`

    4038             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    4039             : 
    4040             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
    4041             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}
    4042             : 
    4043             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    4044             :     with range checking
    4045             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    4046             : 
    4047             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4048             :     */
