    4053             :     }
    4054             : 
    4055             :     /*!
    4056             :     @brief access specified object element
    4057             : 
    4058             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
    4059             : 
    4060             :     @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
    4061             :     the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
    4062             :     In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
    4063             : 
    4064             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    4065             : 
    4066             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
    4067             : 
    4068             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object or null; example:
    4069             :     `"cannot use operator[] with string"`
    4070             : 
    4071             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    4072             : 
    4073             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
    4074             :     written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
    4075             : 
    4076             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    4077             :     with range checking
    4078             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    4079             : 
    4080             :     @since version 1.1.0
    4081             :     */
    4082             :     template <typename T>
    4083           0 :     reference operator[](T* key)
    4084             :     {
    4085             :         // implicitly convert null to object
    4086           0 :         if (is_null())
    4087             :         {
    4088           0 :             m_type = value_t::object;
    4089           0 :             m_value = value_t::object;
    4090           0 :             assert_invariant();
    4091             :         }
    4092             : 
    4093             :         // at only works for objects
    4094           0 :         if (is_object())
    4095             :         {
    4096           0 :             return m_value.object->operator[](key);
    4097             :         }
    4098             : 
    4099           0 :         JSON_THROW(
    4100             :             std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name()));
    4101             :     }
    4102             : 
    4103             :     /*!
    4104             :     @brief read-only access specified object element
    4105             : 
    4106             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key. No
    4107             :     bounds checking is performed.
    4108             : 
    4109             :     @warning If the element with key @a key does not exist, the behavior is
    4110             :     undefined.
    4111             : 
    4112             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    4113             : 
    4114             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key
    4115             : 
    4116             :     @pre The element with key @a key must exist. **This precondition is
    4117             :          enforced with an assertion.**
    4118             : 
    4119             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object; example: `"cannot use
    4120             :     operator[] with null"`
    4121             : 
    4122             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    4123             : 
    4124             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read using
    4125             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type_const}
    4126             : 
    4127             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    4128             :     with range checking
    4129             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
    4130             : 
    4131             :     @since version 1.1.0
    4132             :     */
    4133             :     template <typename T>
    4134             :     const_reference operator[](T* key) const
    4135             :     {
    4136             :         // at only works for objects
    4137             :         if (is_object())
    4138             :         {
    4139             :             assert(m_value.object->find(key) != m_value.object->end());
    4140             :             return m_value.object->find(key)->second;
    4141             :         }
    4142             : 
    4143             :         JSON_THROW(
    4144             :             std::domain_error("cannot use operator[] with " + type_name()));
    4145             :     }
    4146             : 
    4147             :     /*!
    4148             :     @brief access specified object element with default value
    4149             : 
    4150             :     Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
    4151             :     or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
    4152             : 
    4153             :     The function is basically equivalent to executing
    4154             :     @code {.cpp}
    4155             :     try {
    4156             :         return at(key);
    4157             :     } catch(std::out_of_range) {
    4158             :         return default_value;
    4159             :     }
    4160             :     @endcode
    4161             : 
    4162             :     @note Unlike @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&), this function
    4163             :     does not throw if the given key @a key was not found.
    4164             : 
    4165             :     @note Unlike @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key), this
    4166             :     function does not implicitly add an element to the position defined by @a
    4167             :     key. This function is furthermore also applicable to const objects.
    4168             : 
    4169             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
    4170             :     @param[in] default_value  the value to return if @a key is not found
    4171             : 
    4172             :     @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
    4173             :     JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
    4174             :     JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
    4175             :     value @a default_value must be compatible.
    4176             : 
    4177             :     @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
    4178             :     is not found
    4179             : 
    4180             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object; example: `"cannot use
    4181             :     value() with null"`
    4182             : 
    4183             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    4184             : 
    4185             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
    4186             :     with a default value.,basic_json__value}
    4187             : 
    4188             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
    4189             :     with range checking
    4190             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
    4191             :     access by reference
    4192             : 
    4193             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4194             :     */
    4195             :     template <
    4196             :         class ValueType,
    4197             :         typename std::enable_if<
    4198             :             std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
    4199             :     ValueType value(const typename object_t::key_type& key,
    4200             :                     ValueType default_value) const
    4201             :     {
    4202             :         // at only works for objects
    4203             :         if (is_object())
    4204             :         {
    4205             :             // if key is found, return value and given default value otherwise
    4206             :             const auto it = find(key);
    4207             :             if (it != end())
    4208             :             {
    4209             :                 return *it;
    4210             :             }
    4211             : 
    4212             :             return default_value;
    4213             :         }
    4214             :         else
    4215             :         {
    4216             :             JSON_THROW(
    4217             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use value() with " + type_name()));
    4218             :         }
    4219             :     }
    4220             : 
    4221             :     /*!
    4222             :     @brief overload for a default value of type const char*
    4223             :     @copydoc basic_json::value(const typename object_t::key_type&, ValueType)
    4224             :     const
    4225             :     */
    4226             :     string_t value(const typename object_t::key_type& key,
    4227             :                    const char* default_value) const
    4228             :     {
    4229             :         return value(key, string_t(default_value));
    4230             :     }
    4231             : 
    4232             :     /*!
    4233             :     @brief access specified object element via JSON Pointer with default value
    4234             : 
    4235             :     Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
    4236             :     or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
    4237             : 
    4238             :     The function is basically equivalent to executing
    4239             :     @code {.cpp}
    4240             :     try {
    4241             :         return at(ptr);
    4242             :     } catch(std::out_of_range) {
    4243             :         return default_value;
    4244             :     }
    4245             :     @endcode
    4246             : 
    4247             :     @note Unlike @ref at(const json_pointer&), this function does not throw
    4248             :     if the given key @a key was not found.
    4249             : 
    4250             :     @param[in] ptr  a JSON pointer to the element to access
    4251             :     @param[in] default_value  the value to return if @a ptr found no value
    4252             : 
    4253             :     @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
    4254             :     JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
    4255             :     JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
    4256             :     value @a default_value must be compatible.
    4257             : 
    4258             :     @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
    4259             :     is not found
    4260             : 
    4261             :     @throw std::domain_error if JSON is not an object; example: `"cannot use
    4262             :     value() with null"`
    4263             : 
    4264             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
    4265             : 
    4266             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
    4267             :     with a default value.,basic_json__value_ptr}
    4268             : 
    4269             :     @sa @ref operator[](const json_pointer&) for unchecked access by reference
    4270             : 
    4271             :     @since version 2.0.2
    4272             :     */
    4273             :     template <
    4274             :         class ValueType,
    4275             :         typename std::enable_if<
    4276             :             std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
    4277             :     ValueType value(const json_pointer& ptr, ValueType default_value) const
    4278             :     {
    4279             :         // at only works for objects
    4280             :         if (is_object())
    4281             :         {
    4282             :             // if pointer resolves a value, return it or use default value
    4283             :             JSON_TRY { return ptr.get_checked(this); }
    4284             :             JSON_CATCH(std::out_of_range&) { return default_value; }
    4285             :         }
    4286             : 
    4287             :         JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("cannot use value() with " + type_name()));
    4288             :     }
    4289             : 
    4290             :     /*!
    4291             :     @brief overload for a default value of type const char*
    4292             :     @copydoc basic_json::value(const json_pointer&, ValueType) const
    4293             :     */
    4294             :     string_t value(const json_pointer& ptr, const char* default_value) const
    4295             :     {
    4296             :         return value(ptr, string_t(default_value));
    4297             :     }
    4298             : 
    4299             :     /*!
    4300             :     @brief access the first element
    4301             : 
    4302             :     Returns a reference to the first element in the container. For a JSON
    4303             :     container `c`, the expression `c.front()` is equivalent to `*c.begin()`.
    4304             : 
    4305             :     @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
    4306             :     first element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
    4307             :     reference to the value is returned.
    4308             : 
    4309             :     @complexity Constant.
    4310             : 
    4311             :     @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
    4312             :     or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
    4313             :     assertions**).
    4314             :     @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
    4315             : 
    4316             :     @throw std::out_of_range when called on `null` value
    4317             : 
    4318             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `front()`.,front}
    4319             : 
    4320             :     @sa @ref back() -- access the last element
    4321             : 
    4322             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4323             :     */
    4324             :     reference front() { return *begin(); }
    4325             :     /*!
    4326             :     @copydoc basic_json::front()
    4327             :     */
    4328             :     const_reference front() const { return *cbegin(); }
    4329             :     /*!
    4330             :     @brief access the last element
    4331             : 
    4332             :     Returns a reference to the last element in the container. For a JSON
    4333             :     container `c`, the expression `c.back()` is equivalent to
    4334             :     @code {.cpp}
    4335             :     auto tmp = c.end();
    4336             :     --tmp;
    4337             :     return *tmp;
    4338             :     @endcode
    4339             : 
    4340             :     @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
    4341             :     last element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
    4342             :     reference to the value is returned.
    4343             : 
    4344             :     @complexity Constant.
    4345             : 
    4346             :     @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
    4347             :     or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
    4348             :     assertions**).
    4349             :     @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
    4350             : 
    4351             :     @throw std::out_of_range when called on `null` value.
    4352             : 
    4353             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `back()`.,back}
    4354             : 
    4355             :     @sa @ref front() -- access the first element
    4356             : 
    4357             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4358             :     */
    4359             :     reference back()
    4360             :     {
    4361             :         auto tmp = end();
    4362             :         --tmp;
    4363             :         return *tmp;
    4364             :     }
    4365             : 
    4366             :     /*!
    4367             :     @copydoc basic_json::back()
    4368             :     */
    4369             :     const_reference back() const
    4370             :     {
    4371             :         auto tmp = cend();
    4372             :         --tmp;
    4373             :         return *tmp;
    4374             :     }
    4375             : 
    4376             :     /*!
    4377             :     @brief remove element given an iterator
    4378             : 
    4379             :     Removes the element specified by iterator @a pos. The iterator @a pos must
    4380             :     be valid and dereferenceable. Thus the `end()` iterator (which is valid,
    4381             :     but is not dereferenceable) cannot be used as a value for @a pos.
    4382             : 
    4383             :     If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
    4384             :     will be `null`.
    4385             : 
    4386             :     @param[in] pos iterator to the element to remove
    4387             :     @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
    4388             :     pos refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
    4389             : 
    4390             :     @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
    4391             : 
    4392             :     @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
    4393             :     erase, including the `end()` iterator.
    4394             : 
    4395             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot
    4396             :     use erase() with null"`
    4397             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on an iterator which does not belong to
    4398             :     the current JSON value; example: `"iterator does not fit current value"`
    4399             :     @throw std::out_of_range if called on a primitive type with invalid
    4400             :     iterator (i.e., any iterator which is not `begin()`); example: `"iterator
    4401             :     out of range"`
    4402             : 
    4403             :     @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
    4404             :     - objects: amortized constant
    4405             :     - arrays: linear in distance between @a pos and the end of the container
    4406             :     - strings: linear in the length of the string
    4407             :     - other types: constant
    4408             : 
    4409             :     @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
    4410             :     types.,erase__IteratorType}
    4411             : 
    4412             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
    4413             :     the given range
    4414             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
    4415             :     from an object at the given key
    4416             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
    4417             :     the given index
    4418             : 
    4419             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4420             :     */
    4421             :     template <
    4422             :         class IteratorType,
    4423             :         typename std::enable_if<
    4424             :             std::is_same<IteratorType,
    4425             :                          typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
    4426             :                 std::is_same<IteratorType,
    4427             :                              typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value,
    4428             :             int>::type = 0>
    4429             :     IteratorType erase(IteratorType pos)
    4430             :     {
    4431             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
    4432             :         if (this != pos.m_object)
    4433             :         {
    4434             :             JSON_THROW(
    4435             :                 std::domain_error("iterator does not fit current value"));
    4436             :         }
    4437             : 
    4438             :         IteratorType result = end();
    4439             : 
    4440             :         switch (m_type)
    4441             :         {
    4442             :         case value_t::boolean:
    4443             :         case value_t::number_float:
    4444             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    4445             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    4446             :         case value_t::string:
    4447             :         {
    4448             :             if (not pos.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin())
    4449             :             {
    4450             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range("iterator out of range"));
    4451             :             }
    4452             : 
    4453             :             if (is_string())
    4454             :             {
    4455             :                 AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
    4456             :                 alloc.destroy(m_value.string);
    4457             :                 alloc.deallocate(m_value.string, 1);
    4458             :                 m_value.string = nullptr;
    4459             :             }
    4460             : 
    4461             :             m_type = value_t::null;
    4462             :             assert_invariant();
    4463             :             break;
    4464             :         }
    4465             : 
    4466             :         case value_t::object:
    4467             :         {
    4468             :             result.m_it.object_iterator =
    4469             :                 m_value.object->erase(pos.m_it.object_iterator);
    4470             :             break;
    4471             :         }
    4472             : 
    4473             :         case value_t::array:
    4474             :         {
    4475             :             result.m_it.array_iterator =
    4476             :                 m_value.array->erase(pos.m_it.array_iterator);
    4477             :             break;
    4478             :         }
    4479             : 
    4480             :         default:
    4481             :         {
    4482             :             JSON_THROW(
    4483             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use erase() with " + type_name()));
    4484             :         }
    4485             :         }
    4486             : 
    4487             :         return result;
    4488             :     }
    4489             : 
    4490             :     /*!
    4491             :     @brief remove elements given an iterator range
    4492             : 
    4493             :     Removes the element specified by the range `[first; last)`. The iterator
    4494             :     @a first does not need to be dereferenceable if `first == last`: erasing
    4495             :     an empty range is a no-op.
    4496             : 
    4497             :     If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
    4498             :     will be `null`.
    4499             : 
    4500             :     @param[in] first iterator to the beginning of the range to remove
    4501             :     @param[in] last iterator past the end of the range to remove
    4502             :     @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
    4503             :     second refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
    4504             : 
    4505             :     @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
    4506             : 
    4507             :     @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
    4508             :     erase, including the `end()` iterator.
    4509             : 
    4510             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot
    4511             :     use erase() with null"`
    4512             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on iterators which does not belong to
    4513             :     the current JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit current value"`
    4514             :     @throw std::out_of_range if called on a primitive type with invalid
    4515             :     iterators (i.e., if `first != begin()` and `last != end()`); example:
    4516             :     `"iterators out of range"`
    4517             : 
    4518             :     @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
    4519             :     - objects: `log(size()) + std::distance(first, last)`
    4520             :     - arrays: linear in the distance between @a first and @a last, plus linear
    4521             :       in the distance between @a last and end of the container
    4522             :     - strings: linear in the length of the string
    4523             :     - other types: constant
    4524             : 
    4525             :     @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
    4526             :     types.,erase__IteratorType_IteratorType}
    4527             : 
    4528             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
    4529             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
    4530             :     from an object at the given key
    4531             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
    4532             :     the given index
    4533             : 
    4534             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4535             :     */
    4536             :     template <
    4537             :         class IteratorType,
    4538             :         typename std::enable_if<
    4539             :             std::is_same<IteratorType,
    4540             :                          typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
    4541             :                 std::is_same<IteratorType,
    4542             :                              typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value,
    4543             :             int>::type = 0>
    4544             :     IteratorType erase(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
    4545             :     {
    4546             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
    4547             :         if (this != first.m_object or this != last.m_object)
    4548             :         {
    4549             :             JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("iterators do not fit current value"));
    4550             :         }
    4551             : 
    4552             :         IteratorType result = end();
    4553             : 
    4554             :         switch (m_type)
    4555             :         {
    4556             :         case value_t::boolean:
    4557             :         case value_t::number_float:
    4558             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    4559             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    4560             :         case value_t::string:
    4561             :         {
    4562             :             if (not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin() or
    4563             :                 not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end())
    4564             :             {
    4565             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range("iterators out of range"));
    4566             :             }
    4567             : 
    4568             :             if (is_string())
    4569             :             {
    4570             :                 AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
    4571             :                 alloc.destroy(m_value.string);
    4572             :                 alloc.deallocate(m_value.string, 1);
    4573             :                 m_value.string = nullptr;
    4574             :             }
    4575             : 
    4576             :             m_type = value_t::null;
    4577             :             assert_invariant();
    4578             :             break;
    4579             :         }
    4580             : 
    4581             :         case value_t::object:
    4582             :         {
    4583             :             result.m_it.object_iterator =
    4584             :                 m_value.object->erase(first.m_it.object_iterator,
    4585             :                                       last.m_it.object_iterator);
    4586             :             break;
    4587             :         }
    4588             : 
    4589             :         case value_t::array:
    4590             :         {
    4591             :             result.m_it.array_iterator =
    4592             :                 m_value.array->erase(first.m_it.array_iterator,
    4593             :                                      last.m_it.array_iterator);
    4594             :             break;
    4595             :         }
    4596             : 
    4597             :         default:
    4598             :         {
    4599             :             JSON_THROW(
    4600             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use erase() with " + type_name()));
    4601             :         }
    4602             :         }
    4603             : 
    4604             :         return result;
    4605             :     }
    4606             : 
    4607             :     /*!
    4608             :     @brief remove element from a JSON object given a key
    4609             : 
    4610             :     Removes elements from a JSON object with the key value @a key.
    4611             : 
    4612             :     @param[in] key value of the elements to remove
    4613             : 
    4614             :     @return Number of elements removed. If @a ObjectType is the default
    4615             :     `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was not
    4616             :     found) or `1` (@a key was found).
    4617             : 
    4618             :     @post References and iterators to the erased elements are invalidated.
    4619             :     Other references and iterators are not affected.
    4620             : 
    4621             :     @throw std::domain_error when called on a type other than JSON object;
    4622             :     example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
    4623             : 
    4624             :     @complexity `log(size()) + count(key)`
    4625             : 
    4626             :     @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__key_type}
    4627             : 
    4628             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
    4629             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
    4630             :     the given range
    4631             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
    4632             :     the given index
    4633             : 
    4634             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4635             :     */
    4636             :     size_type erase(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
    4637             :     {
    4638             :         // this erase only works for objects
    4639             :         if (is_object())
    4640             :         {
    4641             :             return m_value.object->erase(key);
    4642             :         }
    4643             : 
    4644             :         JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("cannot use erase() with " + type_name()));
    4645             :     }
    4646             : 
    4647             :     /*!
    4648             :     @brief remove element from a JSON array given an index
    4649             : 
    4650             :     Removes element from a JSON array at the index @a idx.
    4651             : 
    4652             :     @param[in] idx index of the element to remove
    4653             : 
    4654             :     @throw std::domain_error when called on a type other than JSON array;
    4655             :     example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
    4656             :     @throw std::out_of_range when `idx >= size()`; example: `"array index 17
    4657             :     is out of range"`
    4658             : 
    4659             :     @complexity Linear in distance between @a idx and the end of the container.
    4660             : 
    4661             :     @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__size_type}
    4662             : 
    4663             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
    4664             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
    4665             :     the given range
    4666             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
    4667             :     from an object at the given key
    4668             : 
    4669             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4670             :     */
    4671             :     void erase(const size_type idx)
    4672             :     {
    4673             :         // this erase only works for arrays
    4674             :         if (is_array())
    4675             :         {
    4676             :             if (idx >= size())
    4677             :             {
    4678             :                 JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range(
    4679             :                     "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
    4680             :             }
    4681             : 
    4682             :             m_value.array->erase(m_value.array->begin() +
    4683             :                                  static_cast<difference_type>(idx));
    4684             :         }
    4685             :         else
    4686             :         {
    4687             :             JSON_THROW(
    4688             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use erase() with " + type_name()));
    4689             :         }
    4690             :     }
    4691             : 
    4692             :     /// @}
    4693             : 
    4694             :     ////////////
    4695             :     // lookup //
    4696             :     ////////////
    4697             : 
    4698             :     /// @name lookup
    4699             :     /// @{
    4700             : 
    4701             :     /*!
    4702             :     @brief find an element in a JSON object
    4703             : 
    4704             :     Finds an element in a JSON object with key equivalent to @a key. If the
    4705             :     element is not found or the JSON value is not an object, end() is
    4706             :     returned.
    4707             : 
    4708             :     @note This method always returns @ref end() when executed on a JSON type
    4709             :           that is not an object.
    4710             : 
    4711             :     @param[in] key key value of the element to search for
    4712             : 
    4713             :     @return Iterator to an element with key equivalent to @a key. If no such
    4714             :     element is found or the JSON value is not an object, past-the-end (see
    4715             :     @ref end()) iterator is returned.
    4716             : 
    4717             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
    4718             : 
    4719             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `find()` is used.,find__key_type}
    4720             : 
    4721             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4722             :     */
    4723             :     iterator find(typename object_t::key_type key)
    4724             :     {
    4725             :         auto result = end();
    4726             : 
    4727             :         if (is_object())
    4728             :         {
    4729             :             result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->find(key);
    4730             :         }
    4731             : 
    4732             :         return result;
    4733             :     }
    4734             : 
    4735             :     /*!
    4736             :     @brief find an element in a JSON object
    4737             :     @copydoc find(typename object_t::key_type)
    4738             :     */
    4739             :     const_iterator find(typename object_t::key_type key) const
    4740             :     {
    4741             :         auto result = cend();
    4742             : 
    4743             :         if (is_object())
    4744             :         {
    4745             :             result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->find(key);
    4746             :         }
    4747             : 
    4748             :         return result;
    4749             :     }
    4750             : 
    4751             :     /*!
    4752             :     @brief returns the number of occurrences of a key in a JSON object
    4753             : 
    4754             :     Returns the number of elements with key @a key. If ObjectType is the
    4755             :     default `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was
    4756             :     not found) or `1` (@a key was found).
    4757             : 
    4758             :     @note This method always returns `0` when executed on a JSON type that is
    4759             :           not an object.
    4760             : 
    4761             :     @param[in] key key value of the element to count
    4762             : 
    4763             :     @return Number of elements with key @a key. If the JSON value is not an
    4764             :     object, the return value will be `0`.
    4765             : 
    4766             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
    4767             : 
    4768             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `count()` is used.,count}
    4769             : 
    4770             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4771             :     */
    4772             :     size_type count(typename object_t::key_type key) const
    4773             :     {
    4774             :         // return 0 for all nonobject types
    4775             :         return is_object() ? m_value.object->count(key) : 0;
    4776             :     }
    4777             : 
    4778             :     /// @}
    4779             : 
    4780             :     ///////////////
    4781             :     // iterators //
    4782             :     ///////////////
    4783             : 
    4784             :     /// @name iterators
    4785             :     /// @{
    4786             : 
    4787             :     /*!
    4788             :     @brief returns an iterator to the first element
    4789             : 
    4790             :     Returns an iterator to the first element.
    4791             : 
    4792             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4793             : 
    4794             :     @return iterator to the first element
    4795             : 
    4796             :     @complexity Constant.
    4797             : 
    4798             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4799             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    4800             :     requirements:
    4801             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4802             : 
    4803             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `begin()`.,begin}
    4804             : 
    4805             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
    4806             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
    4807             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
    4808             : 
    4809             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4810             :     */
    4811             :     iterator begin() noexcept
    4812             :     {
    4813             :         iterator result(this);
    4814             :         result.set_begin();
    4815             :         return result;
    4816             :     }
    4817             : 
    4818             :     /*!
    4819             :     @copydoc basic_json::cbegin()
    4820             :     */
    4821             :     const_iterator begin() const noexcept { return cbegin(); }
    4822             :     /*!
    4823             :     @brief returns a const iterator to the first element
    4824             : 
    4825             :     Returns a const iterator to the first element.
    4826             : 
    4827             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4828             : 
    4829             :     @return const iterator to the first element
    4830             : 
    4831             :     @complexity Constant.
    4832             : 
    4833             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4834             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    4835             :     requirements:
    4836             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4837             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).begin()`.
    4838             : 
    4839             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `cbegin()`.,cbegin}
    4840             : 
    4841             :     @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
    4842             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
    4843             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
    4844             : 
    4845             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4846             :     */
    4847             :     const_iterator cbegin() const noexcept
    4848             :     {
    4849             :         const_iterator result(this);
    4850             :         result.set_begin();
    4851             :         return result;
    4852             :     }
    4853             : 
    4854             :     /*!
    4855             :     @brief returns an iterator to one past the last element
    4856             : 
    4857             :     Returns an iterator to one past the last element.
    4858             : 
    4859             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4860             : 
    4861             :     @return iterator one past the last element
    4862             : 
    4863             :     @complexity Constant.
    4864             : 
    4865             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4866             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    4867             :     requirements:
    4868             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4869             : 
    4870             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `end()`.,end}
    4871             : 
    4872             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
    4873             :     @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
    4874             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
    4875             : 
    4876             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4877             :     */
    4878             :     iterator end() noexcept
    4879             :     {
    4880             :         iterator result(this);
    4881             :         result.set_end();
    4882             :         return result;
    4883             :     }
    4884             : 
    4885             :     /*!
    4886             :     @copydoc basic_json::cend()
    4887             :     */
    4888             :     const_iterator end() const noexcept { return cend(); }
    4889             :     /*!
    4890             :     @brief returns a const iterator to one past the last element
    4891             : 
    4892             :     Returns a const iterator to one past the last element.
    4893             : 
    4894             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4895             : 
    4896             :     @return const iterator one past the last element
    4897             : 
    4898             :     @complexity Constant.
    4899             : 
    4900             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4901             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    4902             :     requirements:
    4903             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4904             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).end()`.
    4905             : 
    4906             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `cend()`.,cend}
    4907             : 
    4908             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
    4909             :     @sa @ref begin() -- returns an iterator to the beginning
    4910             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
    4911             : 
    4912             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4913             :     */
    4914             :     const_iterator cend() const noexcept
    4915             :     {
    4916             :         const_iterator result(this);
    4917             :         result.set_end();
    4918             :         return result;
    4919             :     }
    4920             : 
    4921             :     /*!
    4922             :     @brief returns an iterator to the reverse-beginning
    4923             : 
    4924             :     Returns an iterator to the reverse-beginning; that is, the last element.
    4925             : 
    4926             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4927             : 
    4928             :     @complexity Constant.
    4929             : 
    4930             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4931             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
    4932             :     requirements:
    4933             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4934             :     - Has the semantics of `reverse_iterator(end())`.
    4935             : 
    4936             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `rbegin()`.,rbegin}
    4937             : 
    4938             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
    4939             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
    4940             :     @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
    4941             : 
    4942             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4943             :     */
    4944             :     reverse_iterator rbegin() noexcept { return reverse_iterator(end()); }
    4945             :     /*!
    4946             :     @copydoc basic_json::crbegin()
    4947             :     */
    4948             :     const_reverse_iterator rbegin() const noexcept { return crbegin(); }
    4949             :     /*!
    4950             :     @brief returns an iterator to the reverse-end
    4951             : 
    4952             :     Returns an iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before the first
    4953             :     element.
    4954             : 
    4955             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4956             : 
    4957             :     @complexity Constant.
    4958             : 
    4959             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4960             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
    4961             :     requirements:
    4962             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4963             :     - Has the semantics of `reverse_iterator(begin())`.
    4964             : 
    4965             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `rend()`.,rend}
    4966             : 
    4967             :     @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
    4968             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
    4969             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
    4970             : 
    4971             :     @since version 1.0.0
    4972             :     */
    4973             :     reverse_iterator rend() noexcept { return reverse_iterator(begin()); }
    4974             :     /*!
    4975             :     @copydoc basic_json::crend()
    4976             :     */
    4977             :     const_reverse_iterator rend() const noexcept { return crend(); }
    4978             :     /*!
    4979             :     @brief returns a const reverse iterator to the last element
    4980             : 
    4981             :     Returns a const iterator to the reverse-beginning; that is, the last
    4982             :     element.
    4983             : 
    4984             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    4985             : 
    4986             :     @complexity Constant.
    4987             : 
    4988             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    4989             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
    4990             :     requirements:
    4991             :     - The complexity is constant.
    4992             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rbegin()`.
    4993             : 
    4994             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crbegin()`.,crbegin}
    4995             : 
    4996             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
    4997             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
    4998             :     @sa @ref crend() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the end
    4999             : 
    5000             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5001             :     */
    5002             :     const_reverse_iterator crbegin() const noexcept
    5003             :     {
    5004             :         return const_reverse_iterator(cend());
    5005             :     }
    5006             : 
    5007             :     /*!
    5008             :     @brief returns a const reverse iterator to one before the first
    5009             : 
    5010             :     Returns a const reverse iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before
    5011             :     the first element.
    5012             : 
    5013             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
    5014             : 
    5015             :     @complexity Constant.
    5016             : 
    5017             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    5018             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
    5019             :     requirements:
    5020             :     - The complexity is constant.
    5021             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rend()`.
    5022             : 
    5023             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crend()`.,crend}
    5024             : 
    5025             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
    5026             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
    5027             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
    5028             : 
    5029             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5030             :     */
    5031             :     const_reverse_iterator crend() const noexcept
    5032             :     {
    5033             :         return const_reverse_iterator(cbegin());
    5034             :     }
    5035             : 
    5036             : private:
    5037             :     // forward declaration
    5038             :     template <typename IteratorType>
    5039             :     class iteration_proxy;
    5040             : 
    5041             : public:
    5042             :     /*!
    5043             :     @brief wrapper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
    5044             : 
    5045             :     This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
    5046             :     iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
    5047             :     reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
    5048             :     underlying iterator.
    5049             : 
    5050             :     @note The name of this function is not yet final and may change in the
    5051             :     future.
    5052             :     */
    5053             :     static iteration_proxy<iterator> iterator_wrapper(reference cont)
    5054             :     {
    5055             :         return iteration_proxy<iterator>(cont);
    5056             :     }
    5057             : 
    5058             :     /*!
    5059             :     @copydoc iterator_wrapper(reference)
    5060             :     */
    5061             :     static iteration_proxy<const_iterator> iterator_wrapper(
    5062             :         const_reference cont)
    5063             :     {
    5064             :         return iteration_proxy<const_iterator>(cont);
    5065             :     }
    5066             : 
    5067             :     /// @}
    5068             : 
    5069             :     //////////////
    5070             :     // capacity //
    5071             :     //////////////
    5072             : 
    5073             :     /// @name capacity
    5074             :     /// @{
    5075             : 
    5076             :     /*!
    5077             :     @brief checks whether the container is empty
    5078             : 
    5079             :     Checks if a JSON value has no elements.
    5080             : 
    5081             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
    5082             :             defined as follows:
    5083             :             Value type  | return value
    5084             :             ----------- | -------------
    5085             :             null        | `true`
    5086             :             boolean     | `false`
    5087             :             string      | `false`
    5088             :             number      | `false`
    5089             :             object      | result of function `object_t::empty()`
    5090             :             array       | result of function `array_t::empty()`
    5091             : 
    5092             :     @note This function does not return whether a string stored as JSON value
    5093             :     is empty - it returns whether the JSON container itself is empty which is
    5094             :     false in the case of a string.
    5095             : 
    5096             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
    5097             :     the Container concept; that is, their `empty()` functions have constant
    5098             :     complexity.
    5099             : 
    5100             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    5101             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    5102             :     requirements:
    5103             :     - The complexity is constant.
    5104             :     - Has the semantics of `begin() == end()`.
    5105             : 
    5106             :     @liveexample{The following code uses `empty()` to check if a JSON
    5107             :     object contains any elements.,empty}
    5108             : 
    5109             :     @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
    5110             : 
    5111             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5112             :     */
    5113             :     bool empty() const noexcept
    5114             :     {
    5115             :         switch (m_type)
    5116             :         {
    5117             :         case value_t::null:
    5118             :         {
    5119             :             // null values are empty
    5120             :             return true;
    5121             :         }
    5122             : 
    5123             :         case value_t::array:
    5124             :         {
    5125             :             // delegate call to array_t::empty()
    5126             :             return m_value.array->empty();
    5127             :         }
    5128             : 
    5129             :         case value_t::object:
    5130             :         {
    5131             :             // delegate call to object_t::empty()
    5132             :             return m_value.object->empty();
    5133             :         }
    5134             : 
    5135             :         default:
    5136             :         {
    5137             :             // all other types are nonempty
    5138             :             return false;
    5139             :         }
    5140             :         }
    5141             :     }
    5142             : 
    5143             :     /*!
    5144             :     @brief returns the number of elements
    5145             : 
    5146             :     Returns the number of elements in a JSON value.
    5147             : 
    5148             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
    5149             :             defined as follows:
    5150             :             Value type  | return value
    5151             :             ----------- | -------------
    5152             :             null        | `0`
    5153             :             boolean     | `1`
    5154             :             string      | `1`
    5155             :             number      | `1`
    5156             :             object      | result of function object_t::size()
    5157             :             array       | result of function array_t::size()
    5158             : 
    5159             :     @note This function does not return the length of a string stored as JSON
    5160             :     value - it returns the number of elements in the JSON value which is 1 in
    5161             :     the case of a string.
    5162             : 
    5163             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
    5164             :     the Container concept; that is, their size() functions have constant
    5165             :     complexity.
    5166             : 
    5167             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    5168             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    5169             :     requirements:
    5170             :     - The complexity is constant.
    5171             :     - Has the semantics of `std::distance(begin(), end())`.
    5172             : 
    5173             :     @liveexample{The following code calls `size()` on the different value
    5174             :     types.,size}
    5175             : 
    5176             :     @sa @ref empty() -- checks whether the container is empty
    5177             :     @sa @ref max_size() -- returns the maximal number of elements
    5178             : 
    5179             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5180             :     */
    5181             :     size_type size() const noexcept
    5182             :     {
    5183             :         switch (m_type)
    5184             :         {
    5185             :         case value_t::null:
    5186             :         {
    5187             :             // null values are empty
    5188             :             return 0;
    5189             :         }
    5190             : 
    5191             :         case value_t::array:
    5192             :         {
    5193             :             // delegate call to array_t::size()
    5194             :             return m_value.array->size();
    5195             :         }
    5196             : 
    5197             :         case value_t::object:
    5198             :         {
    5199             :             // delegate call to object_t::size()
    5200             :             return m_value.object->size();
    5201             :         }
    5202             : 
    5203             :         default:
    5204             :         {
    5205             :             // all other types have size 1
    5206             :             return 1;
    5207             :         }
    5208             :         }
    5209             :     }
    5210             : 
    5211             :     /*!
    5212             :     @brief returns the maximum possible number of elements
    5213             : 
    5214             :     Returns the maximum number of elements a JSON value is able to hold due to
    5215             :     system or library implementation limitations, i.e. `std::distance(begin(),
    5216             :     end())` for the JSON value.
    5217             : 
    5218             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
    5219             :             defined as follows:
    5220             :             Value type  | return value
    5221             :             ----------- | -------------
    5222             :             null        | `0` (same as `size()`)
    5223             :             boolean     | `1` (same as `size()`)
    5224             :             string      | `1` (same as `size()`)
    5225             :             number      | `1` (same as `size()`)
    5226             :             object      | result of function `object_t::max_size()`
    5227             :             array       | result of function `array_t::max_size()`
    5228             : 
    5229             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
    5230             :     the Container concept; that is, their `max_size()` functions have constant
    5231             :     complexity.
    5232             : 
    5233             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
    5234             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
    5235             :     requirements:
    5236             :     - The complexity is constant.
    5237             :     - Has the semantics of returning `b.size()` where `b` is the largest
    5238             :       possible JSON value.
    5239             : 
    5240             :     @liveexample{The following code calls `max_size()` on the different value
    5241             :     types. Note the output is implementation specific.,max_size}
    5242             : 
    5243             :     @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
    5244             : 
    5245             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5246             :     */
    5247             :     size_type max_size() const noexcept
    5248             :     {
    5249             :         switch (m_type)
    5250             :         {
    5251             :         case value_t::array:
    5252             :         {
    5253             :             // delegate call to array_t::max_size()
    5254             :             return m_value.array->max_size();
    5255             :         }
    5256             : 
    5257             :         case value_t::object:
    5258             :         {
    5259             :             // delegate call to object_t::max_size()
    5260             :             return m_value.object->max_size();
    5261             :         }
    5262             : 
    5263             :         default:
    5264             :         {
    5265             :             // all other types have max_size() == size()
    5266             :             return size();
    5267             :         }
    5268             :         }
    5269             :     }
    5270             : 
    5271             :     /// @}
    5272             : 
    5273             :     ///////////////
    5274             :     // modifiers //
    5275             :     ///////////////
    5276             : 
    5277             :     /// @name modifiers
    5278             :     /// @{
    5279             : 
    5280             :     /*!
    5281             :     @brief clears the contents
    5282             : 
    5283             :     Clears the content of a JSON value and resets it to the default value as
    5284             :     if @ref basic_json(value_t) would have been called:
    5285             : 
    5286             :     Value type  | initial value
    5287             :     ----------- | -------------
    5288             :     null        | `null`
    5289             :     boolean     | `false`
    5290             :     string      | `""`
    5291             :     number      | `0`
    5292             :     object      | `{}`
    5293             :     array       | `[]`
    5294             : 
    5295             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
    5296             : 
    5297             :     @liveexample{The example below shows the effect of `clear()` to different
    5298             :     JSON types.,clear}
    5299             : 
    5300             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5301             :     */
    5302             :     void clear() noexcept
    5303             :     {
    5304             :         switch (m_type)
    5305             :         {
    5306             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    5307             :         {
    5308             :             m_value.number_integer = 0;
    5309             :             break;
    5310             :         }
    5311             : 
    5312             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    5313             :         {
    5314             :             m_value.number_unsigned = 0;
    5315             :             break;
    5316             :         }
    5317             : 
    5318             :         case value_t::number_float:
    5319             :         {
    5320             :             m_value.number_float = 0.0;
    5321             :             break;
    5322             :         }
    5323             : 
    5324             :         case value_t::boolean:
    5325             :         {
    5326             :             m_value.boolean = false;
    5327             :             break;
    5328             :         }
    5329             : 
    5330             :         case value_t::string:
    5331             :         {
    5332             :             m_value.string->clear();
    5333             :             break;
    5334             :         }
    5335             : 
    5336             :         case value_t::array:
    5337             :         {
    5338             :             m_value.array->clear();
    5339             :             break;
    5340             :         }
    5341             : 
    5342             :         case value_t::object:
    5343             :         {
    5344             :             m_value.object->clear();
    5345             :             break;
    5346             :         }
    5347             : 
    5348             :         default:
    5349             :         {
    5350             :             break;
    5351             :         }
    5352             :         }
    5353             :     }
    5354             : 
    5355             :     /*!
    5356             :     @brief add an object to an array
    5357             : 
    5358             :     Appends the given element @a val to the end of the JSON value. If the
    5359             :     function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array is created before
    5360             :     appending @a val.
    5361             : 
    5362             :     @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON array
    5363             : 
    5364             :     @throw std::domain_error when called on a type other than JSON array or
    5365             :     null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
    5366             : 
    5367             :     @complexity Amortized constant.
    5368             : 
    5369             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
    5370             :     add elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently
    5371             :     converted to a JSON array.,push_back}
    5372             : 
    5373             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5374             :     */
    5375           0 :     void push_back(basic_json&& val)
    5376             :     {
    5377             :         // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
    5378           0 :         if (not(is_null() or is_array()))
    5379             :         {

    5381             :                                          type_name()));

    5442             : 
    5443             :     /*!
    5444             :     @brief add an object to an object
    5445             : 
    5446             :     Inserts the given element @a val to the JSON object. If the function is
    5447             :     called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before inserting
    5448             :     @a val.
    5449             : 
    5450             :     @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON object
    5451             : 
    5452             :     @throw std::domain_error when called on a type other than JSON object or
    5453             :     null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
    5454             : 
    5455             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
    5456             : 
    5457             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
    5458             :     add elements to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently
    5459             :     converted to a JSON object.,push_back__object_t__value}
    5460             : 
    5461             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5462             :     */
    5463             :     void push_back(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
    5464             :     {
    5465             :         // push_back only works for null objects or objects
    5466             :         if (not(is_null() or is_object()))
    5467             :         {
    5468             :             JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("cannot use push_back() with " +
    5469             :                                          type_name()));
    5470             :         }
    5471             : 
    5472             :         // transform null object into an object
    5473             :         if (is_null())
    5474             :         {
    5475             :             m_type = value_t::object;
    5476             :             m_value = value_t::object;
    5477             :             assert_invariant();
    5478             :         }
