    5484             :     /*!
    5485             :     @brief add an object to an object
    5486             :     @copydoc push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&)
    5487             :     */
    5488             :     reference operator+=(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
    5489             :     {
    5490             :         push_back(val);
    5491             :         return *this;
    5492             :     }
    5493             : 
    5494             :     /*!
    5495             :     @brief add an object to an object
    5496             : 
    5497             :     This function allows to use `push_back` with an initializer list. In case
    5498             : 
    5499             :     1. the current value is an object,
    5500             :     2. the initializer list @a init contains only two elements, and
    5501             :     3. the first element of @a init is a string,
    5502             : 
    5503             :     @a init is converted into an object element and added using
    5504             :     @ref push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&). Otherwise, @a init
    5505             :     is converted to a JSON value and added using @ref push_back(basic_json&&).
    5506             : 
    5507             :     @param init  an initializer list
    5508             : 
    5509             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
    5510             : 
    5511             :     @note This function is required to resolve an ambiguous overload error,
    5512             :           because pairs like `{"key", "value"}` can be both interpreted as
    5513             :           `object_t::value_type` or `std::initializer_list<basic_json>`, see
    5514             :           https://github.com/nlohmann/json/issues/235 for more information.
    5515             : 
    5516             :     @liveexample{The example shows how initializer lists are treated as
    5517             :     objects when possible.,push_back__initializer_list}
    5518             :     */
    5519             :     void push_back(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init)
    5520             :     {
    5521             :         if (is_object() and init.size() == 2 and init.begin()->is_string())
    5522             :         {
    5523             :             const string_t key = *init.begin();
    5524             :             push_back(typename object_t::value_type(key, *(init.begin() + 1)));
    5525             :         }
    5526             :         else
    5527             :         {
    5528             :             push_back(basic_json(init));
    5529             :         }
    5530             :     }
    5531             : 
    5532             :     /*!
    5533             :     @brief add an object to an object
    5534             :     @copydoc push_back(std::initializer_list<basic_json>)
    5535             :     */
    5536             :     reference operator+=(std::initializer_list<basic_json> init)
    5537             :     {
    5538             :         push_back(init);
    5539             :         return *this;
    5540             :     }
    5541             : 
    5542             :     /*!
    5543             :     @brief add an object to an array
    5544             : 
    5545             :     Creates a JSON value from the passed parameters @a args to the end of the
    5546             :     JSON value. If the function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array
    5547             :     is created before appending the value created from @a args.
    5548             : 
    5549             :     @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
    5550             :     @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
    5551             : 
    5552             :     @throw std::domain_error when called on a type other than JSON array or
    5553             :     null; example: `"cannot use emplace_back() with number"`
    5554             : 
    5555             :     @complexity Amortized constant.
    5556             : 
    5557             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` can be used to add
    5558             :     elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently converted
    5559             :     to a JSON array.,emplace_back}
    5560             : 
    5561             :     @since version 2.0.8
    5562             :     */
    5563             :     template <class... Args>
    5564             :     void emplace_back(Args&&... args)
    5565             :     {
    5566             :         // emplace_back only works for null objects or arrays
    5567             :         if (not(is_null() or is_array()))
    5568             :         {
    5569             :             JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("cannot use emplace_back() with " +
    5570             :                                          type_name()));
    5571             :         }
    5572             : 
    5573             :         // transform null object into an array
    5574             :         if (is_null())
    5575             :         {
    5576             :             m_type = value_t::array;
    5577             :             m_value = value_t::array;
    5578             :             assert_invariant();
    5579             :         }
    5580             : 
    5581             :         // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
    5582             :         m_value.array->emplace_back(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
    5583             :     }
    5584             : 
    5585             :     /*!
    5586             :     @brief add an object to an object if key does not exist
    5587             : 
    5588             :     Inserts a new element into a JSON object constructed in-place with the
    5589             :     given @a args if there is no element with the key in the container. If the
    5590             :     function is called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before
    5591             :     appending the value created from @a args.
    5592             : 
    5593             :     @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
    5594             :     @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
    5595             : 
    5596             :     @return a pair consisting of an iterator to the inserted element, or the
    5597             :             already-existing element if no insertion happened, and a bool
    5598             :             denoting whether the insertion took place.
    5599             : 
    5600             :     @throw std::domain_error when called on a type other than JSON object or
    5601             :     null; example: `"cannot use emplace() with number"`
    5602             : 
    5603             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
    5604             : 
    5605             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `emplace()` can be used to add elements
    5606             :     to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently converted to a
    5607             :     JSON object. Further note how no value is added if there was already one
    5608             :     value stored with the same key.,emplace}
    5609             : 
    5610             :     @since version 2.0.8
    5611             :     */
    5612             :     template <class... Args>
    5613             :     std::pair<iterator, bool> emplace(Args&&... args)
    5614             :     {
    5615             :         // emplace only works for null objects or arrays
    5616             :         if (not(is_null() or is_object()))
    5617             :         {
    5618             :             JSON_THROW(
    5619             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use emplace() with " + type_name()));
    5620             :         }
    5621             : 
    5622             :         // transform null object into an object
    5623             :         if (is_null())
    5624             :         {
    5625             :             m_type = value_t::object;
    5626             :             m_value = value_t::object;
    5627             :             assert_invariant();
    5628             :         }
    5629             : 
    5630             :         // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
    5631             :         auto res = m_value.object->emplace(std::forward<Args>(args)...);
    5632             :         // create result iterator and set iterator to the result of emplace
    5633             :         auto it = begin();
    5634             :         it.m_it.object_iterator = res.first;
    5635             : 
    5636             :         // return pair of iterator and boolean
    5637             :         return {it, res.second};
    5638             :     }
    5639             : 
    5640             :     /*!
    5641             :     @brief inserts element
    5642             : 
    5643             :     Inserts element @a val before iterator @a pos.
    5644             : 
    5645             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
    5646             :     the end() iterator
    5647             :     @param[in] val element to insert
    5648             :     @return iterator pointing to the inserted @a val.
    5649             : 
    5650             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on JSON values other than arrays;
    5651             :     example: `"cannot use insert() with string"`
    5652             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a pos is not an iterator of *this; example:
    5653             :     `"iterator does not fit current value"`
    5654             : 
    5655             :     @complexity Constant plus linear in the distance between @a pos and end of
    5656             :     the container.

    5659             : 
    5660             :     @since version 1.0.0

    5686             :     @brief inserts element

    5693             : 
    5694             :     /*!
    5695             :     @brief inserts elements
    5696             : 
    5697             :     Inserts @a cnt copies of @a val before iterator @a pos.
    5698             : 
    5699             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
    5700             :     the end() iterator
    5701             :     @param[in] cnt number of copies of @a val to insert
    5702             :     @param[in] val element to insert
    5703             :     @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
    5704             :     `cnt==0`
    5705             : 
    5706             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on JSON values other than arrays;
    5707             :     example: `"cannot use insert() with string"`
    5708             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a pos is not an iterator of *this; example:
    5709             :     `"iterator does not fit current value"`

    5711             :     @complexity Linear in @a cnt plus linear in the distance between @a pos
    5712             :     and end of the container.
    5713             : 
    5714             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__count}
    5715             : 
    5716             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5717             :     */

    5719             :     {
    5720             :         // insert only works for arrays
    5721             :         if (is_array())

    5723             :             // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
    5724             :             if (pos.m_object != this)
    5725             :             {
    5726             :                 JSON_THROW(
    5727             :                     std::domain_error("iterator does not fit current value"));
    5728             :             }
    5729             : 
    5730             :             // insert to array and return iterator
    5731             :             iterator result(this);

    5733             :                 m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator, cnt, val);
    5734             :             return result;
    5735             :         }

    5737             :         JSON_THROW(
    5738             :             std::domain_error("cannot use insert() with " + type_name()));

    5740             : 
    5741             :     /*!
    5742             :     @brief inserts elements
    5743             : 
    5744             :     Inserts elements from range `[first, last)` before iterator @a pos.
    5745             : 
    5746             :     @param[in] pos iterator before which the content will be inserted; may be
    5747             :     the end() iterator
    5748             :     @param[in] first begin of the range of elements to insert
    5749             :     @param[in] last end of the range of elements to insert
    5750             : 
    5751             :     @throw std::domain_error if called on JSON values other than arrays;
    5752             :     example: `"cannot use insert() with string"`
    5753             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a pos is not an iterator of *this; example:
    5754             :     `"iterator does not fit current value"`
    5755             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a first and @a last do not belong to the same
    5756             :     JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit"`
    5757             :     @throw std::domain_error if @a first or @a last are iterators into
    5758             :     container for which insert is called; example: `"passed iterators may not
    5759             :     belong to container"`
    5760             : 
    5761             :     @return iterator pointing to the first element inserted, or @a pos if
    5762             :     `first==last`
    5763             : 
    5764             :     @complexity Linear in `std::distance(first, last)` plus linear in the
    5765             :     distance between @a pos and end of the container.
    5766             : 
    5767             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__range}
    5768             : 
    5769             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5770             :     */
    5771             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, const_iterator first,
    5772             :                     const_iterator last)
    5773             :     {
    5774             :         // insert only works for arrays
    5775             :         if (not is_array())
    5776             :         {
    5777             :             JSON_THROW(
    5778             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use insert() with " + type_name()));
    5779             :         }
    5780             : 
    5781             :         // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
    5782             :         if (pos.m_object != this)
    5783             :         {
    5784             :             JSON_THROW(
    5785             :                 std::domain_error("iterator does not fit current value"));
    5786             :         }
    5787             : 
    5788             :         // check if range iterators belong to the same JSON object
    5789             :         if (first.m_object != last.m_object)
    5790             :         {
    5791             :             JSON_THROW(std::domain_error("iterators do not fit"));
    5792             :         }
    5793             : 
    5794             :         if (first.m_object == this or last.m_object == this)
    5795             :         {
    5796             :             JSON_THROW(std::domain_error(
    5797             :                 "passed iterators may not belong to container"));
    5798             :         }
    5799             : 
    5800             :         // insert to array and return iterator
    5801             :         iterator result(this);
    5802             :         result.m_it.array_iterator =
    5803             :             m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator,
    5804             :                                   first.m_it.array_iterator,
    5805             :                                   last.m_it.array_iterator);

    5807             :     }
    5808             : 
    5809             :     /*!
    5810             :     @brief inserts elements
    5811             :

    5816             :     @param[in] ilist initializer list to insert the values from

    5821             :     `"iterator does not fit current value"`

    5824             :     `ilist` is empty

    5827             :     @a pos and end of the container.

    5829             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `insert()` is used.,insert__ilist}
    5830             : 
    5831             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5832             :     */
    5833             :     iterator insert(const_iterator pos, std::initializer_list<basic_json> ilist)
    5834             :     {
    5835             :         // insert only works for arrays
    5836             :         if (not is_array())
    5837             :         {
    5838             :             JSON_THROW(
    5839             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use insert() with " + type_name()));
    5840             :         }
    5841             : 
    5842             :         // check if iterator pos fits to this JSON value
    5843             :         if (pos.m_object != this)
    5844             :         {
    5845             :             JSON_THROW(
    5846             :                 std::domain_error("iterator does not fit current value"));
    5847             :         }
    5848             : 
    5849             :         // insert to array and return iterator
    5850             :         iterator result(this);
    5851             :         result.m_it.array_iterator =
    5852             :             m_value.array->insert(pos.m_it.array_iterator, ilist);
    5853             :         return result;
    5854             :     }
    5855             : 
    5856             :     /*!
    5857             :     @brief exchanges the values
    5858             : 
    5859             :     Exchanges the contents of the JSON value with those of @a other. Does not
    5860             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
    5861             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
    5862             :     invalidated.
    5863             : 
    5864             :     @param[in,out] other JSON value to exchange the contents with
    5865             : 
    5866             :     @complexity Constant.
    5867             : 
    5868             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values can be swapped with
    5869             :     `swap()`.,swap__reference}
    5870             : 
    5871             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5872             :     */
    5873             :     void swap(reference other) noexcept(
    5874             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
    5875             :             std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
    5876             :                 std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
    5877             :                     std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value)
    5878             :     {
    5879             :         std::swap(m_type, other.m_type);
    5880             :         std::swap(m_value, other.m_value);
    5881             :         assert_invariant();
    5882             :     }
    5883             : 
    5884             :     /*!
    5885             :     @brief exchanges the values
    5886             : 
    5887             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON array with those of @a other. Does not
    5888             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
    5889             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
    5890             :     invalidated.
    5891             : 
    5892             :     @param[in,out] other array to exchange the contents with
    5893             : 
    5894             :     @throw std::domain_error when JSON value is not an array; example:
    5895             :     `"cannot use swap() with string"`
    5896             : 
    5897             :     @complexity Constant.
    5898             : 
    5899             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how arrays can be swapped with
    5900             :     `swap()`.,swap__array_t}
    5901             : 
    5902             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5903             :     */
    5904             :     void swap(array_t& other)
    5905             :     {
    5906             :         // swap only works for arrays
    5907             :         if (is_array())
    5908             :         {
    5909             :             std::swap(*(m_value.array), other);
    5910             :         }
    5911             :         else
    5912             :         {
    5913             :             JSON_THROW(
    5914             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use swap() with " + type_name()));
    5915             :         }
    5916             :     }
    5917             : 
    5918             :     /*!
    5919             :     @brief exchanges the values
    5920             : 
    5921             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON object with those of @a other. Does not
    5922             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
    5923             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
    5924             :     invalidated.
    5925             : 
    5926             :     @param[in,out] other object to exchange the contents with
    5927             : 
    5928             :     @throw std::domain_error when JSON value is not an object; example:
    5929             :     `"cannot use swap() with string"`
    5930             : 
    5931             :     @complexity Constant.
    5932             : 
    5933             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how objects can be swapped with
    5934             :     `swap()`.,swap__object_t}
    5935             : 
    5936             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5937             :     */
    5938             :     void swap(object_t& other)
    5939             :     {
    5940             :         // swap only works for objects
    5941             :         if (is_object())
    5942             :         {
    5943             :             std::swap(*(m_value.object), other);
    5944             :         }
    5945             :         else
    5946             :         {
    5947             :             JSON_THROW(
    5948             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use swap() with " + type_name()));
    5949             :         }
    5950             :     }
    5951             : 
    5952             :     /*!
    5953             :     @brief exchanges the values
    5954             : 
    5955             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON string with those of @a other. Does not
    5956             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
    5957             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
    5958             :     invalidated.
    5959             : 
    5960             :     @param[in,out] other string to exchange the contents with
    5961             : 
    5962             :     @throw std::domain_error when JSON value is not a string; example: `"cannot
    5963             :     use swap() with boolean"`
    5964             : 
    5965             :     @complexity Constant.
    5966             : 
    5967             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how strings can be swapped with
    5968             :     `swap()`.,swap__string_t}
    5969             : 
    5970             :     @since version 1.0.0
    5971             :     */
    5972             :     void swap(string_t& other)
    5973             :     {
    5974             :         // swap only works for strings
    5975             :         if (is_string())
    5976             :         {
    5977             :             std::swap(*(m_value.string), other);
    5978             :         }
    5979             :         else
    5980             :         {
    5981             :             JSON_THROW(
    5982             :                 std::domain_error("cannot use swap() with " + type_name()));
    5983             :         }
    5984             :     }
    5985             : 
    5986             :     /// @}
    5987             : 
    5988             : public:
    5989             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
    5990             :     // lexicographical comparison operators //
    5991             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
    5992             : 
    5993             :     /// @name lexicographical comparison operators
    5994             :     /// @{
    5995             : 
    5996             :     /*!
    5997             :     @brief comparison: equal
    5998             : 
    5999             :     Compares two JSON values for equality according to the following rules:
    6000             :     - Two JSON values are equal if (1) they are from the same type and (2)
    6001             :       their stored values are the same.
    6002             :     - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
    6003             :       comparison. Floating-point numbers are compared indirectly: two
    6004             :       floating-point numbers `f1` and `f2` are considered equal if neither
    6005             :       `f1 > f2` nor `f2 > f1` holds.
    6006             :     - Two JSON null values are equal.
    6007             : 
    6008             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
    6009             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
    6010             :     @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are equal
    6011             : 
    6012             :     @complexity Linear.
    6013             : 
    6014             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
    6015             :     types.,operator__equal}
    6016             : 
    6017             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6018             :     */
    6019             :     friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6020             :     {
    6021             :         const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
    6022             :         const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
    6023             : 
    6024             :         if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
    6025             :         {
    6026             :             switch (lhs_type)
    6027             :             {
    6028             :             case value_t::array:
    6029             :             {
    6030             :                 return *lhs.m_value.array == *rhs.m_value.array;
    6031             :             }
    6032             :             case value_t::object:
    6033             :             {
    6034             :                 return *lhs.m_value.object == *rhs.m_value.object;
    6035             :             }
    6036             :             case value_t::null:
    6037             :             {
    6038             :                 return true;
    6039             :             }
    6040             :             case value_t::string:
    6041             :             {
    6042             :                 return *lhs.m_value.string == *rhs.m_value.string;
    6043             :             }
    6044             :             case value_t::boolean:
    6045             :             {
    6046             :                 return lhs.m_value.boolean == rhs.m_value.boolean;
    6047             :             }
    6048             :             case value_t::number_integer:
    6049             :             {
    6050             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_integer == rhs.m_value.number_integer;
    6051             :             }
    6052             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
    6053             :             {
    6054             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_unsigned ==
    6055             :                        rhs.m_value.number_unsigned;
    6056             :             }
    6057             :             case value_t::number_float:
    6058             :             {
    6059             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_float == rhs.m_value.number_float;
    6060             :             }
    6061             :             default:
    6062             :             {
    6063             :                 return false;
    6064             :             }
    6065             :             }
    6066             :         }
    6067             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
    6068             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
    6069             :         {
    6070             :             return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) ==
    6071             :                    rhs.m_value.number_float;
    6072             :         }
    6073             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
    6074             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
    6075             :         {
    6076             :             return lhs.m_value.number_float ==
    6077             :                    static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_integer);
    6078             :         }
    6079             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and
    6080             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
    6081             :         {
    6082             :             return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) ==
    6083             :                    rhs.m_value.number_float;
    6084             :         }
    6085             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
    6086             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
    6087             :         {
    6088             :             return lhs.m_value.number_float ==
    6089             :                    static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6090             :         }
    6091             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned and
    6092             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
    6093             :         {
    6094             :             return static_cast<number_integer_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) ==
    6095             :                    rhs.m_value.number_integer;
    6096             :         }
    6097             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
    6098             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
    6099             :         {
    6100             :             return lhs.m_value.number_integer ==
    6101             :                    static_cast<number_integer_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6102             :         }
    6103             : 
    6104             :         return false;
    6105             :     }
    6106             : 
    6107             :     /*!
    6108             :     @brief comparison: equal
    6109             :     @copydoc operator==(const_reference, const_reference)
    6110             :     */
    6111             :     template <typename ScalarType,
    6112             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
    6113             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    6114             :     friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
    6115             :     {
    6116             :         return (lhs == basic_json(rhs));
    6117             :     }
    6118             : 
    6119             :     /*!
    6120             :     @brief comparison: equal
    6121             :     @copydoc operator==(const_reference, const_reference)
    6122             :     */
    6123             :     template <typename ScalarType,
    6124             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
    6125             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    6126             :     friend bool operator==(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6127             :     {
    6128             :         return (basic_json(lhs) == rhs);
    6129             :     }
    6130             : 
    6131             :     /*!
    6132             :     @brief comparison: not equal
    6133             : 
    6134             :     Compares two JSON values for inequality by calculating `not (lhs == rhs)`.
    6135             : 
    6136             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
    6137             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
    6138             :     @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are not equal
    6139             : 
    6140             :     @complexity Linear.
    6141             : 
    6142             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
    6143             :     types.,operator__notequal}
    6144             : 
    6145             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6146             :     */

    6148             :     {
    6149             :         return not(lhs == rhs);
    6150             :     }
    6151             : 
    6152             :     /*!
    6153             :     @brief comparison: not equal
    6154             :     @copydoc operator!=(const_reference, const_reference)
    6155             :     */
    6156             :     template <typename ScalarType,
    6157             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
    6158             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    6159             :     friend bool operator!=(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept
    6160             :     {
    6161             :         return (lhs != basic_json(rhs));
    6162             :     }
    6163             : 
    6164             :     /*!
    6165             :     @brief comparison: not equal
    6166             :     @copydoc operator!=(const_reference, const_reference)
    6167             :     */
    6168             :     template <typename ScalarType,
    6169             :               typename std::enable_if<std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value,
    6170             :                                       int>::type = 0>
    6171             :     friend bool operator!=(const ScalarType lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6172             :     {
    6173             :         return (basic_json(lhs) != rhs);
    6174             :     }
    6175             : 
    6176             :     /*!
    6177             :     @brief comparison: less than
    6178             : 
    6179             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than another JSON value @a
    6180             :     rhs according to the following rules:
    6181             :     - If @a lhs and @a rhs have the same type, the values are compared using
    6182             :       the default `<` operator.
    6183             :     - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
    6184             :       comparison
    6185             :     - In case @a lhs and @a rhs have different types, the values are ignored
    6186             :       and the order of the types is considered, see
    6187             :       @ref operator<(const value_t, const value_t).
    6188             : 
    6189             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
    6190             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
    6191             :     @return whether @a lhs is less than @a rhs
    6192             : 
    6193             :     @complexity Linear.
    6194             : 
    6195             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
    6196             :     types.,operator__less}
    6197             : 
    6198             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6199             :     */
    6200             :     friend bool operator<(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6201             :     {
    6202             :         const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
    6203             :         const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
    6204             : 
    6205             :         if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
    6206             :         {
    6207             :             switch (lhs_type)
    6208             :             {
    6209             :             case value_t::array:
    6210             :             {
    6211             :                 return *lhs.m_value.array < *rhs.m_value.array;
    6212             :             }
    6213             :             case value_t::object:
    6214             :             {
    6215             :                 return *lhs.m_value.object < *rhs.m_value.object;
    6216             :             }
    6217             :             case value_t::null:
    6218             :             {
    6219             :                 return false;
    6220             :             }
    6221             :             case value_t::string:
    6222             :             {
    6223             :                 return *lhs.m_value.string < *rhs.m_value.string;
    6224             :             }
    6225             :             case value_t::boolean:
    6226             :             {
    6227             :                 return lhs.m_value.boolean < rhs.m_value.boolean;
    6228             :             }
    6229             :             case value_t::number_integer:
    6230             :             {
    6231             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_integer < rhs.m_value.number_integer;
    6232             :             }
    6233             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
    6234             :             {
    6235             :                 return lhs.m_value.number_unsigned <
    6236             :                        rhs.m_value.number_unsigned;

    6245             :             }

    6249             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)

    6251             :             return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_integer) <

    6261             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_float)
    6262             :         {
    6263             :             return static_cast<number_float_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) <
    6264             :                    rhs.m_value.number_float;
    6265             :         }
    6266             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_float and
    6267             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
    6268             :         {
    6269             :             return lhs.m_value.number_float <
    6270             :                    static_cast<number_float_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6271             :         }
    6272             :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and
    6273             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_unsigned)
    6274             :         {
    6275             :             return lhs.m_value.number_integer <
    6276             :                    static_cast<number_integer_t>(rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6277             :         }

    6279             :                  rhs_type == value_t::number_integer)
    6280             :         {
    6281             :             return static_cast<number_integer_t>(lhs.m_value.number_unsigned) <
    6282             :                    rhs.m_value.number_integer;
    6283             :         }
    6284             : 
    6285             :         // We only reach this line if we cannot compare values. In that case,
    6286             :         // we compare types. Note we have to call the operator explicitly,
    6287             :         // because MSVC has problems otherwise.
    6288             :         return operator<(lhs_type, rhs_type);
    6289             :     }
    6290             : 
    6291             :     /*!
    6292             :     @brief comparison: less than or equal
    6293             : 
    6294             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than or equal to another
    6295             :     JSON value by calculating `not (rhs < lhs)`.
    6296             : 
    6297             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
    6298             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
    6299             :     @return whether @a lhs is less than or equal to @a rhs
    6300             : 
    6301             :     @complexity Linear.
    6302             : 
    6303             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
    6304             :     types.,operator__greater}
    6305             : 
    6306             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6307             :     */
    6308             :     friend bool operator<=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6309             :     {
    6310             :         return not(rhs < lhs);
    6311             :     }
    6312             : 
    6313             :     /*!
    6314             :     @brief comparison: greater than
    6315             : 
    6316             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than another
    6317             :     JSON value by calculating `not (lhs <= rhs)`.
    6318             : 
    6319             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
    6320             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
    6321             :     @return whether @a lhs is greater than to @a rhs
    6322             : 
    6323             :     @complexity Linear.
    6324             : 
    6325             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
    6326             :     types.,operator__lessequal}
    6327             : 
    6328             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6329             :     */
    6330             :     friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6331             :     {
    6332             :         return not(lhs <= rhs);
    6333             :     }
    6334             : 
    6335             :     /*!
    6336             :     @brief comparison: greater than or equal
    6337             : 
    6338             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than or equal to another
    6339             :     JSON value by calculating `not (lhs < rhs)`.
    6340             : 
    6341             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
    6342             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
    6343             :     @return whether @a lhs is greater than or equal to @a rhs
    6344             : 
    6345             :     @complexity Linear.
    6346             : 
    6347             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
    6348             :     types.,operator__greaterequal}
    6349             : 
    6350             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6351             :     */
    6352             :     friend bool operator>=(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
    6353             :     {
    6354             :         return not(lhs < rhs);
    6355             :     }
    6356             : 
    6357             :     /// @}
    6358             : 
    6359             :     ///////////////////
    6360             :     // serialization //
    6361             :     ///////////////////
    6362             : 
    6363             :     /// @name serialization
    6364             :     /// @{
    6365             : 
    6366             :     /*!
    6367             :     @brief serialize to stream
    6368             : 
    6369             :     Serialize the given JSON value @a j to the output stream @a o. The JSON
    6370             :     value will be serialized using the @ref dump member function. The
    6371             :     indentation of the output can be controlled with the member variable
    6372             :     `width` of the output stream @a o. For instance, using the manipulator
    6373             :     `std::setw(4)` on @a o sets the indentation level to `4` and the
    6374             :     serialization result is the same as calling `dump(4)`.
    6375             : 
    6376             :     @param[in,out] o  stream to serialize to
    6377             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
    6378             : 
    6379             :     @return the stream @a o
    6380             : 
    6381             :     @complexity Linear.
    6382             : 
    6383             :     @liveexample{The example below shows the serialization with different
    6384             :     parameters to `width` to adjust the indentation level.,operator_serialize}
    6385             : 
    6386             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6387             :     */
    6388             :     friend std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& o, const basic_json& j)
    6389             :     {
    6390             :         // read width member and use it as indentation parameter if nonzero
    6391             :         const bool pretty_print = (o.width() > 0);
    6392             :         const auto indentation = (pretty_print ? o.width() : 0);
    6393             : 
    6394             :         // reset width to 0 for subsequent calls to this stream
    6395             :         o.width(0);
    6396             : 
    6397             :         // do the actual serialization
    6398             :         j.dump(o, pretty_print, static_cast<unsigned int>(indentation));
    6399             : 
    6400             :         return o;
    6401             :     }
    6402             : 
    6403             :     /*!
    6404             :     @brief serialize to stream
    6405             :     @copydoc operator<<(std::ostream&, const basic_json&)
    6406             :     */
    6407             :     friend std::ostream& operator>>(const basic_json& j, std::ostream& o)
    6408             :     {
    6409             :         return o << j;
    6410             :     }
    6411             : 
    6412             :     /// @}
    6413             : 
    6414             :     /////////////////////
    6415             :     // deserialization //
    6416             :     /////////////////////
    6417             : 
    6418             :     /// @name deserialization
    6419             :     /// @{
    6420             : 
    6421             :     /*!
    6422             :     @brief deserialize from an array
    6423             : 
    6424             :     This function reads from an array of 1-byte values.
    6425             : 
    6426             :     @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
    6427             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
    6428             :     with a static assertion.**
    6429             : 
    6430             :     @param[in] array  array to read from
    6431             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
    6432             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
    6433             :     (optional)
    6434             : 
    6435             :     @return result of the deserialization
    6436             : 
    6437             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    6438             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
    6439             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
    6440             : 
    6441             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    6442             : 
    6443             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
    6444             :     from an array.,parse__array__parser_callback_t}
    6445             : 
    6446             :     @since version 2.0.3
    6447             :     */
    6448             :     template <class T, std::size_t N>
    6449             :     static basic_json parse(T (&array)[N], const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    6450             :     {
    6451             :         // delegate the call to the iterator-range parse overload
    6452             :         return parse(std::begin(array), std::end(array), cb);
    6453             :     }
    6454             : 
    6455             :     /*!
    6456             :     @brief deserialize from string literal
    6457             : 
    6458             :     @tparam CharT character/literal type with size of 1 byte
    6459             :     @param[in] s  string literal to read a serialized JSON value from
    6460             :     @param[in] cb a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
    6461             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
    6462             :     (optional)
    6463             : 
    6464             :     @return result of the deserialization
    6465             : 
    6466             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    6467             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
    6468             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
    6469             : 
    6470             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    6471             :     @note String containers like `std::string` or @ref string_t can be parsed
    6472             :           with @ref parse(const ContiguousContainer&, const parser_callback_t)
    6473             : 
    6474             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
    6475             :     and without callback function.,parse__string__parser_callback_t}
    6476             : 
    6477             :     @sa @ref parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t) for a version that
    6478             :     reads from an input stream
    6479             : 
    6480             :     @since version 1.0.0 (originally for @ref string_t)
    6481             :     */
    6482             :     template <typename CharT,
    6483             :               typename std::enable_if<
    6484             :                   std::is_pointer<CharT>::value and
    6485             :                       std::is_integral<
    6486             :                           typename std::remove_pointer<CharT>::type>::value and
    6487             :                       sizeof(typename std::remove_pointer<CharT>::type) == 1,
    6488             :                   int>::type = 0>
    6489             :     static basic_json parse(const CharT s, const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    6490             :     {
    6491             :         return parser(reinterpret_cast<const char*>(s), cb).parse();
    6492             :     }
    6493             : 
    6494             :     /*!
    6495             :     @brief deserialize from stream
    6496             : 
    6497             :     @param[in,out] i  stream to read a serialized JSON value from
    6498             :     @param[in] cb a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
    6499             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
    6500             :     (optional)
    6501             : 
    6502             :     @return result of the deserialization
    6503             : 
    6504             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    6505             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
    6506             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
    6507             : 
    6508             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    6509             : 
    6510             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
    6511             :     and without callback function.,parse__istream__parser_callback_t}
    6512             : 
    6513             :     @sa @ref parse(const CharT, const parser_callback_t) for a version
    6514             :     that reads from a string
    6515             : 
    6516             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6517             :     */
    6518             :     static basic_json parse(std::istream& i,
    6519             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    6520             :     {
    6521             :         return parser(i, cb).parse();
    6522             :     }
    6523             : 
    6524             :     /*!
    6525             :     @copydoc parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t)
    6526             :     */
    6527             :     static basic_json parse(std::istream&& i,
    6528             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    6529             :     {
    6530             :         return parser(i, cb).parse();
    6531             :     }
    6532             : 
    6533             :     /*!
    6534             :     @brief deserialize from an iterator range with contiguous storage
    6535             : 
    6536             :     This function reads from an iterator range of a container with contiguous
    6537             :     storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container types include
    6538             :     `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`, `std::valarray`, and
    6539             :     `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style arrays can be used with
    6540             :     `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined containers can be used as long
    6541             :     as they implement random-access iterators and a contiguous storage.
    6542             : 
    6543             :     @pre The iterator range is contiguous. Violating this precondition yields
    6544             :     undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an assertion.**
    6545             :     @pre Each element in the range has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
    6546             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
    6547             :     with a static assertion.**
    6548             : 
    6549             :     @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
    6550             :              the function is called with noncompliant iterators and with
    6551             :              assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
    6552             :              likely yield segmentation violation.
    6553             : 
    6554             :     @tparam IteratorType iterator of container with contiguous storage
    6555             :     @param[in] first  begin of the range to parse (included)
    6556             :     @param[in] last  end of the range to parse (excluded)
    6557             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
    6558             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
    6559             :     (optional)
    6560             : 
    6561             :     @return result of the deserialization
    6562             : 
    6563             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    6564             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
    6565             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
    6566             : 
    6567             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    6568             : 
    6569             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
    6570             :     from an iterator range.,parse__iteratortype__parser_callback_t}
    6571             : 
    6572             :     @since version 2.0.3
    6573             :     */
    6574             :     template <class IteratorType,
    6575             :               typename std::enable_if<
    6576             :                   std::is_base_of<std::random_access_iterator_tag,
    6577             :                                   typename std::iterator_traits<
    6578             :                                       IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value,
    6579             :                   int>::type = 0>
    6580           0 :     static basic_json parse(IteratorType first, IteratorType last,
    6581             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    6582             :     {
    6583             :         // assertion to check that the iterator range is indeed contiguous,
    6584             :         // see http://stackoverflow.com/a/35008842/266378 for more discussion
    6585           0 :         assert(std::accumulate(
    6586             :                    first, last, std::pair<bool, int>(true, 0),
    6587             :                    [&first](std::pair<bool, int> res, decltype(*first) val) {
    6588             :                        res.first &=
    6589             :                            (val ==
    6590             :                             *(std::next(std::addressof(*first), res.second++)));
    6591             :                        return res;
    6592             :                    })
    6593             :                    .first);
    6594             : 
    6595             :         // assertion to check that each element is 1 byte long
    6596             :         static_assert(
    6597             :             sizeof(typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::value_type) ==
    6598             :                 1,
    6599             :             "each element in the iterator range must have the size of 1 byte");
    6600             : 
    6601             :         // if iterator range is empty, create a parser with an empty string
    6602             :         // to generate "unexpected EOF" error message
    6603           0 :         if (std::distance(first, last) <= 0)
    6604             :         {
    6605           0 :             return parser("").parse();
    6606             :         }
    6607             : 
    6608           0 :         return parser(first, last, cb).parse();
    6609             :     }
    6610             : 
    6611             :     /*!
    6612             :     @brief deserialize from a container with contiguous storage
    6613             : 
    6614             :     This function reads from a container with contiguous storage of 1-byte
    6615             :     values. Compatible container types include `std::vector`, `std::string`,
    6616             :     `std::array`, and `std::initializer_list`. User-defined containers can be
    6617             :     used as long as they implement random-access iterators and a contiguous
    6618             :     storage.
    6619             : 
    6620             :     @pre The container storage is contiguous. Violating this precondition
    6621             :     yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an
    6622             :     assertion.**
    6623             :     @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
    6624             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
    6625             :     with a static assertion.**
    6626             : 
    6627             :     @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
    6628             :              the function is called with a noncompliant container and with
    6629             :              assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
    6630             :              likely yield segmentation violation.
    6631             : 
    6632             :     @tparam ContiguousContainer container type with contiguous storage
    6633             :     @param[in] c  container to read from
    6634             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
    6635             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
    6636             :     (optional)
    6637             : 
    6638             :     @return result of the deserialization
    6639             : 
    6640             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    6641             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
    6642             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
    6643             : 
    6644             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    6645             : 
    6646             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
    6647             :     from a contiguous container.,parse__contiguouscontainer__parser_callback_t}
    6648             : 
    6649             :     @since version 2.0.3
    6650             :     */
    6651             :     template <class ContiguousContainer,
    6652             :               typename std::enable_if<
    6653             :                   not std::is_pointer<ContiguousContainer>::value and
    6654             :                       std::is_base_of<
    6655             :                           std::random_access_iterator_tag,
    6656             :                           typename std::iterator_traits<decltype(std::begin(
    6657             :                               std::declval<ContiguousContainer const>()))>::
    6658             :                               iterator_category>::value,
    6659             :                   int>::type = 0>
    6660           0 :     static basic_json parse(const ContiguousContainer& c,
    6661             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr)
    6662             :     {
    6663             :         // delegate the call to the iterator-range parse overload
    6664           0 :         return parse(std::begin(c), std::end(c), cb);
    6665             :     }
    6666             : 
    6667             :     /*!
    6668             :     @brief deserialize from stream
    6669             : 
    6670             :     Deserializes an input stream to a JSON value.
    6671             : 
    6672             :     @param[in,out] i  input stream to read a serialized JSON value from
    6673             :     @param[in,out] j  JSON value to write the deserialized input to
    6674             : 
    6675             :     @throw std::invalid_argument in case of parse errors
    6676             : 
    6677             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
    6678             :     LL(1) parser.
    6679             : 
    6680             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
    6681             : 
    6682             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how a JSON value is constructed by
    6683             :     reading a serialization from a stream.,operator_deserialize}
    6684             : 
    6685             :     @sa parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t) for a variant with a
    6686             :     parser callback function to filter values while parsing
    6687             : 
    6688             :     @since version 1.0.0
    6689             :     */
    6690             :     friend std::istream& operator<<(basic_json& j, std::istream& i)
    6691             :     {
    6692             :         j = parser(i).parse();
    6693             :         return i;
    6694             :     }
    6695             : 
    6696             :     /*!
    6697             :     @brief deserialize from stream
    6698             :     @copydoc operator<<(basic_json&, std::istream&)
    6699             :     */
    6700             :     friend std::istream& operator>>(std::istream& i, basic_json& j)
    6701             :     {
    6702             :         j = parser(i).parse();
    6703             :         return i;
    6704             :     }
    6705             : 
    6706             :     /// @}
    6707             : 
    6708             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
    6709             :     // binary serialization/deserialization //
    6710             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
    6711             : 
    6712             :     /// @name binary serialization/deserialization support
    6713             :     /// @{
    6714             : 
    6715             : private:
    6716             :     /*!
    6717             :     @note Some code in the switch cases has been copied, because otherwise
    6718             :           copilers would complain about implicit fallthrough and there is no
    6719             :           portable attribute to mute such warnings.
    6720             :     */
    6721             :     template <typename T>
    6722             :     static void add_to_vector(std::vector<uint8_t>& vec, size_t bytes,
    6723             :                               const T number)
    6724             :     {
    6725             :         assert(bytes == 1 or bytes == 2 or bytes == 4 or bytes == 8);
    6726             : 
    6727             :         switch (bytes)
    6728             :         {
    6729             :         case 8:
    6730             :         {
    6731             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(
    6732             :                 (static_cast<uint64_t>(number) >> 070) & 0xff));
    6733             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(
    6734             :                 (static_cast<uint64_t>(number) >> 060) & 0xff));
    6735             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(
    6736             :                 (static_cast<uint64_t>(number) >> 050) & 0xff));
    6737             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(
    6738             :                 (static_cast<uint64_t>(number) >> 040) & 0xff));
    6739             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 030) & 0xff));
    6740             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 020) & 0xff));
    6741             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 010) & 0xff));
    6742             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(number & 0xff));
    6743             :             break;
    6744             :         }
    6745             : 
    6746             :         case 4:
    6747             :         {
    6748             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 030) & 0xff));
    6749             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 020) & 0xff));
    6750             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 010) & 0xff));
    6751             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(number & 0xff));
    6752             :             break;
    6753             :         }
    6754             : 
    6755             :         case 2:
    6756             :         {
    6757             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>((number >> 010) & 0xff));
    6758             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(number & 0xff));
    6759             :             break;
    6760             :         }
    6761             : 
    6762             :         case 1:
    6763             :         {
    6764             :             vec.push_back(static_cast<uint8_t>(number & 0xff));
    6765             :             break;
    6766             :         }
    6767             :         }
    6768             :     }
    6769             : 
    6770             :     /*!
    6771             :     @brief take sufficient bytes from a vector to fill an integer variable
    6772             : 
    6773             :     In the context of binary serialization formats, we need to read several
    6774             :     bytes from a byte vector and combine them to multi-byte integral data
    6775             :     types.
    6776             : 
    6777             :     @param[in] vec  byte vector to read from
    6778             :     @param[in] current_index  the position in the vector after which to read
    6779             : 
    6780             :     @return the next sizeof(T) bytes from @a vec, in reverse order as T
    6781             : 
    6782             :     @tparam T the integral return type
    6783             : 
    6784             :     @throw std::out_of_range if there are less than sizeof(T)+1 bytes in the
    6785             :            vector @a vec to read
    6786             : 
    6787             :     In the for loop, the bytes from the vector are copied in reverse order into
    6788             :     the return value. In the figures below, let sizeof(T)=4 and `i` be the loop
    6789             :     variable.
    6790             : 
    6791             :     Precondition:
    6792             : 
    6793             :     vec:   |   |   | a | b | c | d |      T: |   |   |   |   |
    6794             :                  ^               ^             ^                ^
    6795             :            current_index         i            ptr        sizeof(T)
    6796             : 
    6797             :     Postcondition:
    6798             : 
    6799             :     vec:   |   |   | a | b | c | d |      T: | d | c | b | a |
    6800             :                  ^   ^                                     ^
    6801             :                  |   i                                    ptr
    6802             :            current_index
    6803             : 
    6804             :     @sa Code adapted from <http://stackoverflow.com/a/41031865/266378>.
    6805             :     */
    6806             :     template <typename T>
    6807             :     static T get_from_vector(const std::vector<uint8_t>& vec,
    6808             :                              const size_t current_index)
    6809             :     {
    6810             :         if (current_index + sizeof(T) + 1 > vec.size())
    6811             :         {
    6812             :             JSON_THROW(std::out_of_range("cannot read " +
    6813             :                                          std::to_string(sizeof(T)) +
    6814             :                                          " bytes from vector"));
    6815             :         }
    6816             : 
    6817             :         T result;
    6818             :         auto* ptr = reinterpret_cast<uint8_t*>(&result);
    6819             :         for (size_t i = 0; i < sizeof(T); ++i)
    6820             :         {
    6821             :             *ptr++ = vec[current_index + sizeof(T) - i];
    6822             :         }
    6823             :         return result;
    6824             :     }
    6825             : 
    6826             :     /*!
    6827             :     @brief create a MessagePack serialization of a given JSON value
    6828             : 
    6829             :     This is a straightforward implementation of the MessagePack specification.
    6830             : 
    6831             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
    6832             :     @param[in,out] v  byte vector to write the serialization to
    6833             : 
    6834             :     @sa https://github.com/msgpack/msgpack/blob/master/spec.md
    6835             :     */
    6836             :     static void to_msgpack_internal(const basic_json& j,
    6837             :                                     std::vector<uint8_t>& v)
    6838             :     {
    6839             :         switch (j.type())
    6840             :         {
    6841             :         case value_t::null:
    6842             :         {
    6843             :             // nil
    6844             :             v.push_back(0xc0);
    6845             :             break;
    6846             :         }
    6847             : 
    6848             :         case value_t::boolean:
    6849             :         {
    6850             :             // true and false
    6851             :             v.push_back(j.m_value.boolean ? 0xc3 : 0xc2);
    6852             :             break;
    6853             :         }
    6854             : 
    6855             :         case value_t::number_integer:
    6856             :         {
    6857             :             if (j.m_value.number_integer >= 0)
    6858             :             {
    6859             :                 // MessagePack does not differentiate between positive
    6860             :                 // signed integers and unsigned integers. Therefore, we
    6861             :                 // used the code from the value_t::number_unsigned case
    6862             :                 // here.
    6863             :                 if (j.m_value.number_unsigned < 128)
    6864             :                 {
    6865             :                     // positive fixnum
    6866             :                     add_to_vector(v, 1, j.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6867             :                 }
    6868             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    6869             :                          std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max())
    6870             :                 {
    6871             :                     // uint 8
    6872             :                     v.push_back(0xcc);
    6873             :                     add_to_vector(v, 1, j.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6874             :                 }
    6875             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    6876             :                          std::numeric_limits<uint16_t>::max())
    6877             :                 {
    6878             :                     // uint 16
    6879             :                     v.push_back(0xcd);
    6880             :                     add_to_vector(v, 2, j.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6881             :                 }
    6882             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    6883             :                          std::numeric_limits<uint32_t>::max())
    6884             :                 {
    6885             :                     // uint 32
    6886             :                     v.push_back(0xce);
    6887             :                     add_to_vector(v, 4, j.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6888             :                 }
    6889             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
    6890             :                          std::numeric_limits<uint64_t>::max())
    6891             :                 {
    6892             :                     // uint 64
    6893             :                     v.push_back(0xcf);
    6894             :                     add_to_vector(v, 8, j.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6895             :                 }
    6896             :             }
    6897             :             else
    6898             :             {
    6899             :                 if (j.m_value.number_integer >= -32)
    6900             :                 {
    6901             :                     // negative fixnum
    6902             :                     add_to_vector(v, 1, j.m_value.number_integer);
    6903             :                 }
    6904             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_integer >=
    6905             :                              std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::min() and
    6906             :                          j.m_value.number_integer <=
    6907             :                              std::numeric_limits<int8_t>::max())
    6908             :                 {
    6909             :                     // int 8
    6910             :                     v.push_back(0xd0);
    6911             :                     add_to_vector(v, 1, j.m_value.number_integer);
    6912             :                 }
    6913             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_integer >=
    6914             :                              std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::min() and
    6915             :                          j.m_value.number_integer <=
    6916             :                              std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max())
    6917             :                 {
    6918             :                     // int 16
    6919             :                     v.push_back(0xd1);
    6920             :                     add_to_vector(v, 2, j.m_value.number_integer);
    6921             :                 }
    6922             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_integer >=
    6923             :                              std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::min() and
    6924             :                          j.m_value.number_integer <=
    6925             :                              std::numeric_limits<int32_t>::max())
    6926             :                 {
    6927             :                     // int 32
    6928             :                     v.push_back(0xd2);
    6929             :                     add_to_vector(v, 4, j.m_value.number_integer);
    6930             :                 }
    6931             :                 else if (j.m_value.number_integer >=
    6932             :                              std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::min() and
    6933             :                          j.m_value.number_integer <=
    6934             :                              std::numeric_limits<int64_t>::max())
    6935             :                 {
    6936             :                     // int 64
    6937             :                     v.push_back(0xd3);
    6938             :                     add_to_vector(v, 8, j.m_value.number_integer);
    6939             :                 }
    6940             :             }
    6941             :             break;
    6942             :         }
    6943             : 
    6944             :         case value_t::number_unsigned:
    6945             :         {
    6946             :             if (j.m_value.number_unsigned < 128)
    6947             :             {
    6948             :                 // positive fixnum
    6949             :                 add_to_vector(v, 1, j.m_value.number_unsigned);
    6950             :             }
    6951             :             else if (j.m_value.number_unsigned <=
